column4: Abruzzi ai SS Apostoli’s wide selection of cold appetizers make an excellent start to a meal of specialities from the Abruzzo region.

Named after St Luke, who was supposedly a painter, Accademia Nazionale di San Luca is Rome’s academy of fine arts. Appropriately, the gallery contains a work of St Luke Painting a Portrait of the Virgin by Raphael and his followers.

The academy’s heyday was in the 17th and 18th centuries, when many members gave their artworks to the collection, including Canova who donated a model for his famous marble group, The Three Graces. Of particular interest are the academy’s three fascinating self-portraits painted by women: the 17th-century Italian Lavinia Fontana; the 18th-century Swiss Angelica Kauffmann, whose painting was copied from a portrait of her by Joshua Reynolds; and Elisabeth Vigée-Lebrun, the pre-1789 Revolution French painter.

column4:
In 1816 the pope gave English residents and visitors the right to hold Anglican services in Rome, but it wasn’t until the early 1880s that they acquired a site to build their own church, All Saints.

The architect was G E Street, best-known in Britain for his Neo-Gothic churches and London’s Law Courts, and his style can be seen in the Victorian Neo-Gothic exterior of All Saints. Inside, though splendidly decorated with different coloured Italian marbles, the church has a very English air.

The street on which All Saints stands got its name from the Fontana del Sileno, known as Babuino (baboon) due to the sad condition in which the fountain and its statue was found.

column4: Dating from the 3rd century, well-preserved Amphitheatrum Castrense was used for games and baiting animals. It owes its good condition to the fact that it was incorporated into the Aurelian Wall, which included several existing high buildings in its fortifications. Amphitheatrum Castrense is best seen from outside the walls, from where there is also a good view of the bell tower of Santa Croce in Gerusalemme.

column4: Rome’s premier literary café since 1760, Antico Caffè Greco is best-known for its popularity with the 19th-century English Romantic poets. Writers such as Keats, Byron and Goethe and composers including Liszt, Wagner and Bizet all frequented here. So too did Casanova, and mad King Ludwig of Bavaria. Today, Italians stand in the crowded foyer to sip a quick espresso coffee, and visitors sit in a cozy back room whose walls are studded with portraits of the café’s illustrious customers.

column3: Aqueduct of Nero and the Freedmen’s Tombs
column4:
Built as an extension of the Aqua Claudia to supply Nero’s Golden House, and later extended to the Imperial residences on the Palatine, the Aqueduct of Nero was constructed in the 1st century AD. Partly incorporated into later buildings, the imposing arches make their way via the Lateran to the Celian Hill.

Along the first section of the aqueduct, in Via Statilia, is the Freedmen’s Tombs – a small tomb in the shape of a house. These date from the 1st century BC, and bear the names and likenesses of a group of freed slaves. Their name, Statilii, indicates that they had been freed by the Statilii, the family of Claudius’s notorious wife, Messalina. Servants of families often pooled funds in this way to pay for a dignified burial in a common resting place.
column6: Intersection of Via Statilia and Via di Santa Croce in Gerusalemme

column249: Pyramid of Caius Cestius, Tomb of the Scipios, Columbarium of Pomponius Hylas

column4:
Constructed under Emperor Augustus, the Ara Pacis, or Altar of Peace, is one of the most significant monuments of ancient Rome. It was erected in 9 BC to celebrate the peace and prosperity Augustus had brought to the Roman Empire after his victorious campaigns in Gaul and Spain.

Commissioned by the Senate, the Ara Pacis was positioned so that the shadow of the huge obelisk sundial on Campus Martius would fall upon it on Augustus’ birthday. Carved along the sides of the altar in Carrara marble are figures depicting a procession that took place on 4 July 13 BC – lictors (guards), augurs (soothsayers) and flamines (priests) are followed by Augustus and his family. The emperor’s relatives can be identified, ranked by their position in the succession. At the time the heir apparent was Marcus Agrippa, husband of Augustus’s daughter Julia. All the portraits in the relief are carved with extraordinary realism, even the innocent toddler clinging to his mother’s skirts. A scale model of the Ara Pacis with a key helps to identify the characters, while a huge Caesar family tree makes it easier to work out who is related to whom.

The tale of the rediscovery of the Ara Pacis dates back to the 16th century, when the first panels were unearthed. One section ended up in Paris, another in Florence. Further discoveries were made in the late 19th century, when archaeologists finally realized just what they had found. What we see today has all been pieced together since 1938, in part original, in part facsimile. Since 2006 it has been encased in an ultramodern building of glass and travertine designed by the New York architect Richard Meier.

Visible from the Ara Pacis is an overgrown brick cylinder that is actually the Mausoleum of Augustus, where the emperor and his family were buried. The mausoleum is currently undergoing restoration and there are plans to re-open it – exactly 2,000 years after Augustus died in AD 14 – as part of a pedestrianized Tridente zone.

column63: A retrospective dedicated to Henri Cartier-Bresson, widely considered to be the father of photojournalism, this exhibition features more than 500 photos, drawings, paintings, films and documents. On the tenth anniversary of his death, visitors can take an in-depth look at Cartier-Bresson’s life and work.

column72: The Art of Command: The Legacy of Augustus is an exhibit divided into 12 sections that include etchings, paintings, coins, mosaics, oil paintings, sculptures and jewels. It explores the most important cultural policies and the propaganda executed by the emperor during his reign.

column4: The Aracoeli Staircase numbers 124 marble steps (122 if you start from the right) and was completed in 1348, some say in thanks for the passing of the Black Death, but probably in view of the 1350 Holy Year. Cola di Rienzo, the 14th-century tribune-turned-tyrant, used to harangue the masses from here, and in the 17th century foreigners used to sleep on the steps, until Prince Caffarelli, who lived on the hill, scared them off by rolling barrels filled with stones at them. Climb all the way up to the top on your knees (it is a popular belief that you can win the Italian national lottery this way) to enjoy the view of Rome, with the domes of Sant’ Andrea della Valle and St Peter’s slightly to the right.
column56: Historic Buildings, Streets and Piazzas | CAPITOL |

column4:
Dedicated in AD 315, the Arch of Constantine was one of the last Imperial monuments to be erected in Rome, and marks the victory of the first Christian emperor over his rival, Emperor Maxentius. Constantine credited his victory at the Battle of the Milvian Bridge in AD 312 to a dream in which he had a vision of the Cross and heard the words “in this sign you shall conquer”. However, there is nothing Christian about the arch – in fact, it is mostly a pastiche of pagan elements taken from several earlier monuments. The beautiful roundels depicting hunting scenes come from a temple dedicated to Emperor Hadrian’s male lover, Antinous, and there are statues of Dacian prisoners taken from Trajan’s Forum and reliefs of Marcus Aurelius, including one in which he is distributing bread to the poor. Inside the arch are reliefs of Trajan’s victory over the Dacians. These were probably by the artist who worked on Trajan’s Column.

The Arch of Constantine is located in the Roman Forum, facing the Colosseum.
column6: Between Via di San Gregorio & the Colosseum

column4: The Arch of Dolabella was built in AD 10 by consuls Caius Junius Silanus and Cornelius Dolabella, possibly on the site of one of the old Servian Wall’s gateways. Made of travertine blocks, it was later used to support Nero’s extension of the Claudian aqueduct, built to supply the Imperial Palace on the Palatine Hill.
column6: Via di San Paolo della Croce
column56: Monuments and Tombs | CARACALLA |

column4: Once mistakenly identified as a triumphal arch, the so-called Arch of Drusus merely supported the branch aqueduct that supplied the Baths of Caracalla. It was built in the 3rd century AD, so had no connection with Drusus, a stepson of Emperor Augustus. The arch carried the aqueduct across the important route Via Appia, hence its monumental appearance. The Arch of Drususstill spans the old cobbled road, just 50 m (160 ft) short of the gateway Porta San Sebastiano.
column52: Ancient Ruins, Historic Sights and Landmarks
column56: Monuments and Tombs | CARACALLA |

column4: Squashed between two buildings just off Via Carlo Alberto is the Arch of Gallienus, the central arch of an originally three-arched gate erected in memory of the eponymous emperor, who was assassinated by his Illyrian officers in AD 262. It was built on the site of the old Esquiline Gate in the Servian Wall, parts of which are visible nearby.
column56: Monuments and Tombs | ESQUILINE |

column4: Probably dating from the reign of Constantine, the Arch of Janus is an imposing four-faced marble arch that stood at the crossroads on the edge of the Forum Boarium, near the ancient docks. Merchants bartared in its shade. The small figures of the goddesses Roma, Juno, Ceres and Minerva can be seen on the keystones above the four arches. In medieval times the Arch of Janus formed the base of a tower fortress, but it was restored to its original shape in 1827.
column56: AVENTINE |

column4:
In the centre of the Area Sacra dell’Argentina are the remains of four temples (known simply as A, B, C & D) which date back to the Republican era and are among the oldest in Rome.

In Roman times, the area was dominated by an 8-m (24-ft) high acrolith of Fortuna Huiusce Diei, Roman goddess of fate. Parts of her body, including a head, are on show at the Centrale Montemartini. The temple dedicated to Fortuna (Temple B) was circular, and can clearly be seen from the pavement above. The tufa blocks behind it belonged to the vast Curia di Pompeo. It was here that the Senate met and Julius Caesar was murdered on 15 March 44 BC.

The oldest (Temple C) dates from the early 3rd century BC. It was placed on a high platform preceded by an altar and is typical of Italic plans. Temple A is from later in the 3rd century BC. In medieval times the church of San Nicola de’ Cesarini was built over its podium: the remains of its two apses are still visible. The north column stumps belonged to a great portico, the Hecatostylum (portico of 100 columns). In Imperial times two marble lavatories were built here – the remains of one are visible behind Temple A.

column4: The most authentic restaurant in the busy Vatican area, Arlù is run by a husband and wife team who serve up delectable Roman cuisine. Try the saltimbocca, or the gnocchi with spinach and ricotta.
Two brothers own and run Armando al Pantheon, a typical Roman trattoria. In addition to the classic dishes, some interesting vegetarian options are also on the menu.

With a sleek interior and unequalled views of the Colosseum, Aroma presents a seasonal menu of regional favourites. Try the morel mushroom risotto with quail breast and poached egg or the roasted cod on a bed of “Spello“ beans.
A surprising combination of flavours enliven the mostly meat-based dishes at Ethiopian restaurant Asmara. Many vegetarian options are also available at this lively restaurant.

Astute adviser and colleague of Emperor Augustus, Maecenas was also a fop, a gourmet, a patron of the arts and enormously wealthy, allowing him to create a fantastic villa and gardens on the Esquiline Hill, most of which has long disappeared beneath the modern city. The partially reconstructed Auditorium of Maecenas, isolated on a traffic island, is all that remains today.

The purpose of the auditorium has been debated by archaeologists. Inside, a semicircle of tiered seats suggests that it may have been a place for readings and performances. If it was, then Maecenas would have been entertained here by his protégés – the lyric poet Horace and Virgil, author of The Aeneid – reading their latest works.

Water ducts have also been discovered, indicating that it may well have been a nympheum – a kind of summerhouse – with fountains and water cascading down the flight of steps at the back. Traces of frescoes remain on the walls: you can make out garden scenes and a procession of miniature figures – including one of a characteristically drunken Dionysus (the Greek god of wine) being propped upright by a satyr.

column4:
Italian architect Renzo Piano’s Auditorium Parco della Musica is the beating heart of Rome’s cultural life, with three whale-shaped concert halls hosting daily classical, rock, pop and jazz performances. The “theatre hall” is for dance shows and electronic nights, while revolving art exhibitions adorn the complex’s hallways.

Piano’s vision was not merely to create a concert venue, but a multipurpose space with an outdoor amphitheatre, shops and restaurants. The building complex is so integrated with its surroundings that it is almost invisible from a distance, and the sound quality inside is second to none – Piano studied acoustics with contemporary composers such as Pierre Boulez, Luciano Berio and Luigi Nono while designing the buildings. Stepping inside one of the auditoriums can feel like a voyage into the interior of a musical instrument thanks to its complex geometries and use of fine wood.

Visitors can take a guided tour of the incredible concert spaces, or a casual walk around the interior, which is punctuated by neon signs beaming a selection of aphorisms in several languages.

column3: Aurelian Wall and Porta San Sebastiano
column4:
Most of the Aurelian Wall, begun by Emperor Aurelian (AD 270–75) and completed by his successor Probus (AD 276–82), has survived, including its largest gateway, Porta San Sebastiano. Aurelian ordered the wall’s construction as a defence against Germanic tribes, whose raids were penetrating deeper and deeper into Italy. Some 18 km (11 miles) round, with 18 gates and 381 towers, the wall took in all the seven hills of Rome. Maxentius (AD 306–12) then raised the wall to almost twice its original height, making it near impassable. It acted as Rome’s main defence until 1870, when it was breached by Italian artillery just by Porta Pia, close to today’s British Embassy.

Of the Aurelian Wall’s 18 gates, many are still in use. Porta San Sebastiano is the largest and the best-preserved, having been rebuilt by Emperor Honorius in the 5th century AD. Originally the Porta Appia, after the Via Appia Antica it leads to, in Christian times it gradually became known as the Porta San Sebastiano, because the Via Appia led to the basilica and catacombs of San Sebastiano, which were popular places of pilgrimage. It was at Porta San Sebastiano that the last triumphal procession to enter the city by the Appian Way was received in state – that of Marcantonio Colonna after the victory of Lepanto over the Turkish fleet in 1571.

Today the gate’s towers house a museum with prints and models showing the walls’ history. From here you can take a short walk along the restored walls and enjoy the spectacular views.
column6: Museo delle Mura, Via di Porta San Sebastiano 18

column4:
The august, old-fashioned Babington’s Tea Rooms were opened by two Englishwomen to serve homesick British tourists with scones, jam and pots of Earl Grey tea. In 1896, Anna Maria and Isabel Cargill Babington came to Rome with £100, intending to start a business. As Rome was full of English people, they decided to set up an authentic English tea room – at that time the only place people could buy tea in Rome was from a pharmacy! It was so successful that they soon set up another branch on St Peter’s Square which is, however, no longer open.

Today, Babington’s Tea Rooms is inevitably crowded with tourists, being so close to Piazza di Spagna, but the food remains homely. Try the traditional shepherd’s pie and chicken supreme for lunch, muffins and cinnamon toast for tea – although these days the menu offers pancakes with maple syrup for breakfast as well as the classic bacon and eggs.
column54: Babington’s Tea Rooms Rome

column4: In the middle of the tram junction near Porta Maggiore stands the Baker’s Tomb, the final resting place of the rich breadmaker Eurysaces and his wife Atistia. Roman custom forbade burials within city walls, and so the roads leading out of cities became lined with middle and upper class monuments and tombs like this one. Built in 30 BC, the tomb is shaped like a baking oven: a low-relief frieze at the top shows Eurysaces presiding over his slaves in the various phases of breadmaking. The inscription proudly asserts his origins and reveals him as a freed slave, probably of Greek origin. Many men like him saved money from their meagre slave salaries to earn their freedom and set up businesses, becoming the backbone of Rome’s economy.

column4:
The most popular spa of ancient Rome, the Baths of Caracalla included exercise areas, gardens, hot and cold pools, social lounges, art centres, brothels and libraries – a true leisure centre. Completed by Emperor Caracalla in AD 217, the baths functioned for about 300 years, until the plumbing was destroyed by invading Goths. Over 1,600 bathers at a time could enjoy these luxurious thermae free of charge.

A Roman bath was a serious business, beginning with a sort of Turkish bath, followed by a spell in the caldarium, a large hot room with pools of water to provide humidity. Then came the lukewarm tepidarium, a visit to the large central meeting place known as the frigidarium, and finally a plunge into the natatio, an open-air Olympic-sized swimming pool. For the rich, this was followed by a rub-down with scented woollen cloth.

Surrounded by grass and umbrella pines, the Baths of Caracalla is one of the most enjoyable ancient sites in the city. The marked route through the baths has lively information boards in English and Italian and takes visitors first to the apodyterium (dressing room), which has remains of mosaic pavements, and then to the huge frigidarium. The two granite bathtubs on Piazza Farnese were once here, with water cascading out of them into what was the natatio. Beyond this is evidence that part of the baths was originally on two levels – there is a stairway leading to nowhere, and fragments of the upper storey’s mosaic pavements, decorated with tritons, dolphins, cupids and marine monsters, can be seen in the grass.

Although there are remnants of mosaics dotted throughout the site, most of the rich marble decorations of the baths were removed by the Farnese family in the 16th century to adorn the interior of Palazzo Farnese. The family’s ancient sculpture collection was also found here, including Hercules, a signed Greek original.

column3: Baths of Diocletian and Aula Ottagona
column4:
Built in AD 298–306 under the infamous Emperor Diocletian, who murdered thousands of Christians, the Baths of Diocletian were the most extensive in Rome and could accommodate up to 3,000 bathers at a time.

A large section of this huge complex is now part of the Museo Nazionale Romano and houses an excellent archaeological museum. It holds a vast collection of inscriptions, stele (funeral stones) and Roman statues, including a marble sculpture of Mithras that still retains its gold leaf and paint. The most atmospheric branch of the museum, the Aula Ottagona (open for special events only), features two 2nd-century BC bronze sculptures of great beauty, which were discovered lovingly hidden in a trench 6 m (20 ft) below the concrete floor of the Temple of the Sun, on the steep hillside of the Quirinal. The complex incorporates the former Carthusian monastery of Santa Maria degli Angeli, which has a beautiful cloister designed by Michelangelo.

The Bioparco, once a depressing conglomeration of badly kept cement cubicles, where performing animals were considered to be there solely for the entertainment of the public, has been overhauled to create a pretty “biological garden” set into a corner of Villa Borghese park.

Today, much of the zoo’s work is dedicated to research and the preservation of animals in danger of extinction. It houses more than 1,300 animals, ranging from lions, hippos and elephants to snakes and crocodiles. There are excellent information boards and a little train to take visitors through the park, as well as the opportunity to watch animals being fed at weekends.

column4:
Originally part of Palazzo Corsini, the graceful Botanical Gardens provide one of the most relaxing places to while away an hour or two and breathe in air richly perfumed by the more than 7,000 plant species that thrive here.

Rome has a long history of gardens, dating back to the 13th century, when a garden of medicinal plants was cultivated within the walls of the Vatican. Since then, there have been several botanical gardens in the city, but it was only in 1883 that the University of Rome was given this permanent site – perfectly located between the Janiculum Hill and the Tiber – away from the chaos of the city.

Sequoias, palm trees and a splendid collections of orchids and bromeliads are among the plants here. Indigenous and exotic species are grouped to illustrate their botanical families and their adaptation to different climates and eco-systems. There are also plants such as the ginkgo that have survived virtually unchanged from earlier eras.

column4:
Once a meadow, the Campo de’ Fiori (field of flowers) bursts with colour during the morning fruit, vegetable and fish market, and again after dark when its pubs and bars make it a centre of Roman nightlife.

Since the Middle Ages, it has been one of Rome’s liveliest areas, a backdrop for princes and pilgrims alike; cardinals and noblemen rubbing shoulders with fishmongers and foreigners in the piazza’s market. On the darker side, it was also the locus of the Inquisition’s executions, as demonstrated by the hooded statue of the philosopher Giordano Bruno, burned at the stake for heresy here in the Jubilee celebrations of 1600. The neighbourhood’s grisly history doesn’t end there – saunter down the cobbled streets to find where Julius Caesar was murdered, painter Caravaggio killed his tennis opponent and goldsmith Benvenuto Cellini murdered a business rival.

Campo de’ Fiori was once surrounded by inns for pilgrims and other travellers. Many of these were once owned by the successful 15th-century courtesan Vannozza Catanei, mistress of Pope Alexander VI Borgia. On the corner between the piazza and Via del Pellegrino you can see Catanei’s shield, which she had decorated with her own coat of arms and those of her husband and her lover, the Borgia pope.

column4: Dine amid dozens of artworks in the studio of the legendary 18th-century sculptor at the Canova-Tadolini Museum Atelier.

One of the seven hills of Rome, the Capitoline Hill was first the fortified centre of ancient Rome and later home to its most important temples.

The Capitoline was originally two peaks: one, called the Arx, was graced by the Temple of Juno, and the other, the Cavo, with the Temple of Jupiter, now mostly occupied by the Palazzo dei Conservatori. The huge Tabularium (Record Office) was built between them in 78 BC, thus forming one hill called the Capitol; and over that the Palazzo Senatorio was built in the 12th century.

The broad flight of steps leading up the Capitoline Hill was designed by Michelangelo, as was the Piazza del Campidoglio at its head. At the centre of the piazza is a gilded bronze statue of Marcus Aurelius, the original of which is in the Capitoline Museums. Legend has it that when the last gold leaf flakes off the statue, the world will end.
column39: Santa Maria in Aracoeli: free |

column4:
Housed within two majestic Renaissance palaces flanking Michelangelo’s trapezoid Piazza del Campidoglio, the Capitoline Museums contain Rome’s finest and most famous collection of Classical sculpture, as well as a gallery of Renaissance art.

The collection began in the mid-15th century, when Pope Sixtus IV donated several bronze statues to the people of Rome, making the Capitoline Museums the oldest public museum in the world. A gallery below the Piazza del Campidoglio links Palazzo dei Conservatori to Palazzo Nuovo.

Palazzo dei Conservatori

Built by Giacomo della Porta (1533–1602) to Michelangelo’s designs, the Palazzo dei Conservatori became the seat of hated papal counsellors, who ran the city by “advising” the Senators. Its frescoed halls are still used occasionally for political meetings, and the ground floor houses the municipal registry office.

While much of the museum is given over to sculpture, including the equestrian statue of Marcus Aurelius, the Pinacoteca (picture gallery) on the second floor holds works by Caravaggio, Van Dyck and Titian, among others.

Palazzo Nuovo

The Palazzo Nuovo is devoted chiefly to sculpture, and most of its finest works, such as the Capitoline Venus, are Roman copies of Greek masterpieces. For visitors eager to identify the philosophers and poets of ancient Greece and the rulers of ancient Rome, there are excellent collections of 18th-century busts.

column4:
Letters written by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749–1832) are on display in Casa di Goethe.

The German poet, dramatist and novelist lived in this house from 1786 until 1788 and worked on a journal that eventually formed part of his travel book The Italian Journey. He was a little perturbed by the number of murders in his neighbourhood, but Rome energized him and his book became one of the most influential ever written about Italy.
column63: German photographer Isolde Ohlbaum’s work is exhibited throughout the world, and she has photographed many important players in the international art and literature scene, such as Andy Warhol and David Bowie. Photos 1975–2014 features portraits of German and Italian writers, including photos from the Petrarca Award of Poetry ceremony.
column249: Antico Caffè Greco, Keats-Shelley Memorial House

column4:
In 1468 Lorenzo Manilio built a great house for his family, decorating it with an elegant Classical plaque. The Latin inscription dates the building according to the ancient Roman method – 2,221 years after the foundation of the city – and gives the owner’s name. Before the Renaissance, most Romans had only a vague idea about their city’s past, but the 15th-century revival of interest in the philosophy and arts of antiquity inspired residents to build houses recalling the splendour of ancient Rome.

Original reliefs are embedded in the façades, as well as a fragment of an ancient sarcophagus. The Piazza Costaguti façade’s windows are inscribed with the words Ave Roma (Hail Rome).
column56: CAMPO DE’ FIORI |

column3: Caserma dei Vigili della VII Coorte
column4: Not all Roman ruins are Imperial villas or grand temples; one that illustrates the daily life of a busy city is Caserma dei Vigili della VII Coorte – the barracks of the guards of the VII Coorte (7th Cohort) of the Roman fire brigade. It was built in Augustus’s reign, in the 1st century AD, and the excavated courtyard is where the men would rest while waiting for a call out.

column4: The Casino dell’Aurora was a summerhouse in the grounds of the Ludovisi Palace. It was built by Cardinal Ludovisi in the 17th century, and frescoed by Guido Reni. The ceiling fresco creates the impression that the Casino has no roof, but lies open to a cloudy sky, across which horses pull the carriage of Aurora, the goddess of dawn, from the darkness of night towards the light of day.

column4:
A huge brick cylinder rising from the banks of the Tiber, Castel Sant’Angelo began life as a mausoleum for Emperor Hadrian in AD 139. Since then it has played several roles: as part of a city wall, as a medieval citadel, as a prison and as a retreat for popes in times of political unrest.

From the dank cells in the lower levels to the fine apartments of the Renaissance popes above, a 58-room museum covers all aspects of the castle’s history, featuring frescoed Renaissance papal apartments and a small arms and armour collection. The most theatrical approach to the castle is from across the Ponte Sant’Angelo, a bridge adorned with marble statues of angels by Bernini.

column63: “Apotheosis, from men to gods: Hadrian’s Mausoleum” explores the historical significance of the mausoleum and the high architectural quality of the structure. Beginning with the foundations and the ritual spaces for emperial tombs, the exhibit follows the historical-religious origins of the deification of the emperor.

column81: The Popes of Hope: Art and Religiosity in 1600s Rome is an exhibit organized in three sections: Recovery of the Origins of Christianity, The Jubilees, and Art and Devotion. Visitors can explore the Catholic journey through paintings, etchings, text and archaeological findings.

column4:
Castor and Pollux – the patrons of horsemanship – and their prancing horses stand in splendour in the Piazza del Quirinale.

Over 5.5 m (18 ft) high, these statues are huge Roman copies of 5th-century BC Greek originals. They once stood at the entrance to the nearby Baths of Constantine. Pope Sixtus V had them restored and placed here in 1588. Formerly known as the “horse tamers”, they gave the square its familiar name of Monte Cavallo (horse hill). The obelisk which stands between them was brought here in 1786 from the Mausoleum of Augustus. In 1818 the composition was completed by the addition of a massive granite basin, once a cattle trough in the Forum.
column56: Monuments and Tombs | QUIRINAL |

column4: The gastronomic temple of Rome since 1932, Castroni is piled high with packaged and prepared speciality foods from countries the world over, including Japan, Greece, India and China.
column56: Trastevere and Prati | Locals’ Favourite Shops | Shopping |

column4:
The Catacombs, burial tunnels of Rome’s early Christians, are like a honeycomb beneath the consular roads out of Rome, especially along Via Appia Antica. Grave niches stacked like shelving along dark corridors are carved into the tufa.

The soft volcanic rock under Rome is highly suitable for tunnelling, as it is softer when first exposed to air, hardening afterwards. There are some precious remnants of fresco and engraved marble slabs.
column56: Beyond the City Walls | Attraction |

column4: Beneath the basilica of Santi Nereo e Achilleo, the Catacombs of Domitilla is the largest network of burial tunnels in Rome. Many of the tombs from the 1st and 2nd centuries AD have no Christian connection. In the burial chambers there are frescoes of both Classical and Christian scenes, including one of the earliest depictions of Christ as the Good Shepherd.

The 1st-century AD Catacombs of Priscilla extend for 15 km (9 miles) in tunnels on three different levels below the country estate of an aristocratic Roman woman, Priscilla.

Rarely visited, the catacombs are run by Benedictine sisters and hold the tombs of around 40,000 Christians. Visitors can take a guided tour to see several frescoed tombs belonging to wealthy families, contrasting with the lowly burial places of the poor, which are simply sealed with a slab of stone or terracotta. The guide will point out lucernari – light shafts which also allowed workers to climb in and take excavated soil and stone out – and little niches in which perfumed oil was burned to mask the smell of decaying corpses.

These catacombs contain the oldest known image of the Madonna and Child, a fresco thought to date back to the late 1st or early 2nd century AD. Although the tombs were heavily plundered after their rediscovery in the 16th century, they are known as the “queen of catacombs” for the number of early Christian martyrs who were buried here.

column4:
The rooms and connecting passageways of the Catacombs of San Callisto are on four different levels and have only been partly explored.

In burying their dead in underground cemeteries outside the city walls, the early Christians were obeying the laws of the time: it was not because of persecution. So many saints were buried that the catacombs became shrines and places of pilgrimage. The dead were placed in niches, known as loculi, which held two or three bodies. The most important rooms were decorated with stucco and frescoes.

The area that can be visited includes the Crypt of the Popes, where many of the early popes were buried, and the Crypt of Santa Cecilia, where the saint’s body was discovered in 820 before being moved to her church in Trastevere.
column31: Wed, 1 Jan, 30 Jan–26 Feb, Easter Sun, 25 Dec

column4: The 17th-century church of San Sebastiano, above the catacombs, occupies the site of a basilica. Preserved at the entrance to the catacombs is the triclia, a building that once stood above ground and was used by mourners for taking funeral refreshments. Its walls are covered with graffiti invoking St Peter and St Paul, whose remains may have been moved here during one of the periods of Christian persecution.
column56: FURTHER AFIELD |

column4:
Largely undeveloped save for a vast military hospital and a handful of churches, the Celian Hill rises, green and tranquil, across the road from the Palatine Hill.

Although it was heavily populated in the latter years of the Empire, the hill was almost abandoned after the Goths sabotaged the aqueducts in AD 530, thereby cutting off its water supply. Jagged fragments of the aqueducts can be seen today.

A good starting point for a tour of the Celian Hill is from the church of San Gregorio Magno, from where the Clivo di Scauro leads up to the top of the hill. The steep, narrow street passes the ancient porticoed church of Santi Giovanni e Paolo with its beautiful Romanesque bell tower soaring above the surrounding medieval monastery buildings.

Of the parks on the hill, the best-kept and most peaceful is the villa Celimontana, with its formal walks and avenues. It is a good place for a picnic, since there are few bars or restaurants in the area.

column4:
In 1997, the enormous early 20th-century thermo-electric power plant Centrale Montemartini was restored and reopened to house part of the collections of the Capitoline Museums.

Two huge generators from Rome’s first power plant still occupy the central machine room, creating an intriguing contrast to the exhibitions. Many of the statues on display were discovered during excavations in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The finds from Largo Argentina, including five toes, a finger, an arm and a head from an 8-m (26-ft) high statue of the goddess Fortuna, are on display here. Other highlights include finds from the horti (gardens) of Imperial Rome and mosaics of two hunting scenes from the Horti Liciniani.
column63: This double personal exhibition of Franco Losvizzero and Vito Bongiorno unites two very different artists in a project developed specifically for the Centrale Montemartini. With a backdrop that contrasts classical archaeology with industrial machinery, Superfoetations explores the dialectical connections between antiquity, modernity and the contemporary.

column4: One of the great Roman restaurants, Checchino dal 1887 offers offal-based delicacies such as rigatoni alla pajata (pasta with calf intestine).

Designed in 1568, at the height of the Thirty Years’ War, the Gesù was the first Jesuit church to be built in Rome. Its design epitomizes Counter-Reformation Baroque architecture and has been much imitated throughout the Catholic world.

The layout proclaims the church’s two major functions: a large nave with side pulpits for preaching to great crowds, and a main altar as the centrepiece for the celebration of the mass. The church was built in a time when the Catholics were fast losing followers to the Protestants; by providing people with prayer books and filling the nave with enough light to read, the Jesuits hoped to make Catholicism more popular.

The impressive illusionistic decoration in the nave and dome was added a century later. Its message is clear and confident: faithful Catholic worshippers will be joyfully uplifted into the heavens while Protestants and other heretics are flung into hell’s fires.
column249: Sant’Ignazio di Loyola, Sant’Andrea della Valle

column4:
With the help of Pope Gregory XIII, San Filippo Neri built this church in place of an old medieval church, Santa Maria in Vallicella, and it has been known ever since as the Chiesa Nuova (new church).

A highly unconventional reformer, San Filippo Neri required his noble Roman followers to humble themselves in public. He made aristocratic young men parade through the streets of Rome in rags or even with a fox’s tail tied behind them, and set noblemen to work as labourers building his church.

Begun in 1575 by Matteo da Città di Castello and continued by Martino Longhi the Elder, it was consecrated in 1599 (although the façade, by Fausto Rughesi, was only finished in 1606). Against San Filippo’s wishes, the interior was decorated after his death; Pietro da Cortona frescoed the nave, dome and apse, taking nearly 20 years. San Filippo is buried in his own chapel, to the left of the altar.
Ciampini al Café du Jardin is an enchanting spot to enjoy a drink while watching the sunset. Open in summer only.

column4:
Rome’s newest attraction, Cinecittà si Mostra, or Cinecittà Shows Off, not only offers the opportunity to step behind the scenes at Italy’s most famous film studio, but also the chance to see films being shot at the studio.

The main lawn is dotted with impressive props, including two giant claw-footed mock-bronze braziers used in the film Gladiator (2000), while a nearby pavilion has replicas of several famous statues ranging from the ancient Roman Capitoline Wolf to Pauline Borghese.

The section entitled “How a Film Is Made" has more props, as well as costumes including Elizabeth Taylor’s from the film Cleopatra (1963). Tours of the film sets take visitors through “Broadway”, created for the Martin Scorsese film Gangs of New York (2002), and then to an ancient Rome built with polystyrene, resin and printed cement for the British-American TV series Rome.

column4:
Once ancient Rome’s largest stadium the Circus Maximus is today little more than a long grassy esplanade.

Set in the valley between the Palatine and Aventine hills, the Circus Maximus was continually embellished and expanded from the 4th century BC until AD 549, when the last races were held. The grandstands held some 300,000 spectators, cheering wildly at the horse and chariot races, athletic contests and wild animal fights, and betting furiously throughout.

In 10 BC, Augustus built the Imperial box under the Palatine and decorated the spina with the obelisk that now stands in the centre of Piazza del Popolo. A second obelisk, which was added in the 4th century by Constantine II, is now in Piazza di San Giovanni in Laterano.
Part of an Italian chain of high-class toy shops, Città del Sole sells the very best in educational playthings.

column4: The speciality at Colline Emiliane is Emilia-Romagna cuisine, which highlights a variety of prosciutto (ham) dishes and tortellini in brodo (meat-filled pasta in broth).

Inaugurated in 1857, the Colonna dell’Immacolata commemorates Pope Pius IX’s proclamation of the doctrine of the Immaculate Conception, holding that the Virgin Mary was the only human being ever to have been born “without the stain of original sin”.

The column itself dates from ancient, pagan Rome, but is crowned with a statue of the Virgin Mary. On 8 December the pope, assisted by the fire brigade, places a wreath around the head of the statue.

column4:
The Colosseum, Rome’s greatest amphitheatre, was commissioned by Emperor Vespasian in AD 72 on the marshy site of a lake in the grounds of Nero’s palace, the Domus Aurea. Here, the Imperial passion for bloody spectacle reached its peak of excess.

Emperors held shows here that often began with animals performing circus tricks. Then came the gladiators, who fought each other to the death. When one was killed, attendants dressed as Charon, the mythical ferryman of the dead, carried his body off on a stretcher, and sand was raked over the blood to prepare for the next bout. The games held in AD 248 to mark the thousandth anniversary of Rome’s founding saw the deaths of a host of lions, elephants, hippos, zebras and elks brought over from North Africa.

The Colosseum was built to a practical design, with 80 arched entrances allowing easy access for 55,000 spectators, but it is also a building of great beauty. It was one of several similar amphitheatres built in the Roman Empire, and some survive at El Djem in North Africa, Nîmes and Arles in France, and Verona in northern Italy. Despite being damaged over the years by neglect and theft, the Colosseum remains a majestic sight.

column4:
The Columbarium of Pomponius Hylas is an example of the vaulted tombs usually built by rich Romans to house the cremated remains of their freed slaves. Known as columbariums because they resemble a dovecote (columba is the Latin word for dove), many similar tombs have been uncovered in this part of Rome, which up until the 3rd century AD lay outside the city wall.

Excavated in 1831, this tomb dates from the 1st century AD and an inscription informs us that it is the Tomb of Pomponius Hylas and his wife, Pomponia Vitalinis. The “V” above her name indicates that she was still living when the inscription was made.

The tomb was probably a commercial venture – niches in the interior walls of the columbarium were sold to people who could not afford to build vaults of their own.
column52: Historic Sights and Landmarks, Ancient Ruins
column56: CARACALLA |

column4:
Built in honour of the Roman emperor to commemorate his victories over the barbarian tribes of the Danube, the AD 180 Column of Marcus Aurelius stands 30 m (100 ft) high and is composed of 28 marble drums.

The monument is clearly an imitation of the Column of Trajan, but the 80-year gap between the two works shows a great artistic change: the German and Sarmatic wars of Marcus Aurelius are rendered with simplified pictures in stronger relief, sacrificing Classical proportions for the sake of clarity and immediacy. In fact, the impression of the work is more like that of the 4th-century Arch of Constantine than Trajan’s monument. Gone are the heroic qualities of the Roman soldiers, by now mostly barbarian mercenaries, and a sense of respect for the vanquished. A new emphasis on the supernatural points to the end of the Hellenistic tradition and the beginning of Christianity.

The column was restored in 1588 by Domenico Fontana on the orders of Pope Sixtus V. The statue of Marcus Aurelius and his wife on the monument’s summit was replaced by a bronze of St Paul.

The Column of Marcus Aurelius is 3.7 m (12 ft) in diameter and has an internal spiral staircase that leads to the top. The easiest way to appreciate the sculptural work, however, is to visit the Museo della Civiltà Romana at EUR and study the casts of the reliefs.
column54: Column of Marcus Aurelius Rome | Marcus Aureluis Column

column4: The Cordonata is a gently rising, subtly widening ramp connecting Piazza Venezia and the Capitol. The top of the Cordonata is guarded by Classical statues of the Dioscuri – Castor and Pollux.

column4:
Part of the former 19th-century Delle Carceri Nuove prison, the Criminology Museum takes visitors on a harrowing voyage into the world of crime and punishment. The themes of criminal anthropology and psychology, capital punishment and the modern prison system are covered in different sections.

The journey begins with replicas of ancient and medieval instruments of torture made by young offenders in the 1930s, including a spiked torture chair used to punish witches in medieval Nuremberg and a hollow bronze bull used to roast offenders in ancient Agrigento. Beyond this is the red hooded cloak used by Rome’s 19th-century executioner, Mastro Titta.

There is a room full of various objects smuggled into prisons – shoes, a hairbrush and books concealing knives – and letters from prisoners written on underpants and one written on a handkerchief and rolled up inside a cigarette.
column39: Adm |
column56: Hidden Rome | Attraction |

column4:
The newest branch of the Museo Nazionale Romano, the Crypta Balbi tells the story of how this piece of land and buildings directly behind it were used, abused and reused over the centuries.

The Crypta Balbi comprises a jumble of excavations from several eras, including a private 13 BC theatre built on an abandoned plot of land between two convents. It was discovered by archaeologists in the 1980s, and on excavating the esedra (curved part of the theatre), they found fragments of a marble semicircle of seats set above a drain – an ancient latrine which dates back to the 1st century AD and seems to have been designed for the wealthy. By the 3rd century, the area had fallen from grace and was used for a different purpose – blocks of flats for the poor were built, one of them with a Mithraeum in the basement.

The Crypta Balbi’s didactic panels are an excellent introduction to Rome’s layer effect, and it is possible to walk along a series of Roman drains and water cisterns below the museum itself. Visitors can also see medieval frescoes, and displays show finds from the site, including fragments of glass from the glassworks and the graves of two children and an adult discovered in the esedra.

column4: Dar Poeta captures the perfect medium between thick- and thin-crusted pizza. There’s a merry war going on between the two varieties, but this pizzeria goes its own road, letting the dough rise for a full day (rather than the usual hour), resulting in a thin yet light and airy pizza loaded down with the freshest of toppings. Tucked into a quiet Trastevere side street, Dar Poeta has tables out front and an air-conditioned brick-walled dining room.

column4:
After allegedly setting fire to Rome in AD 64, Nero built himself an outrageous new palace. The Domus Aurea (sometimes called Nero’s Golden House) occupied part of the Palatine and most of the Celian and Esquiline hills – an area approximately 25 times the size of the Colosseum.

According to ancient Roman literature, the Domus Aurea’s landscaped grounds had a huge artificial lake, complete with real ships and fake seaside villages, bath complexes, gardens, zoos, woods, grottos and elegant porticoes. The palace walls were allegedly adorned with gold and mother-of-pearl, rooms were designed with ceilings that showered guests with flowers or perfumes, the dining hall rotated and the baths were fed with both sulphurous water and sea water. As Nero killed himself in AD 68, he did not have long to enjoy his new home.

Nero’s successors, anxious to distance themselves from the monster-emperor, did their utmost to erase all traces of the palace. Vespasian drained the lake and built the Colosseum in its place; Titus and Trajan each erected a complex of baths over the palace; and Hadrian placed the Temple of Venus and Rome over the vestibule.

Rooms from one wing of the palace have survived, buried beneath the ruins of the Baths of Trajan on the Oppian Hill. Excavations have revealed large frescoes and mosaics which are thought to be a panorama of Rome from a bird’s-eye perspective. The site is currently closed for safety reasons, but hopefully more areas will open to the public when considered safe from landslides.

column4:
Located south of the city, Esposizione Universale di Roma (EUR) was built by Mussolini for an international exhibition, a kind of “Work Olympics”, that was planned for 1942 but never took place because of the war.

The architecture was intended to glorify Fascism, and the style of the public buildings is overblown and rhetorical. The critic Robert Hughes described the so-called Square Colosseum as “the most frightening building in the world”, yet the aesthetic inspired many postwar architects.

In terms of town planning, EUR has been quite successful and people are still keen to live here. The great marble halls house several government offices and museums. To the south is a lake and park, and the huge domed Palazzo dello Sport built for the 1960 Olympics. The impressive Museo della Civilitá Romana is also located here, and showcases items that explore the history of Rome. The area is currently being renovated, with many new buildings constructed.
column29: Museo della Civiltà Romana: Closed for restoration
column52: Historic Sights and Landmarks, Art Galleries and Museums, Green Spaces

column4:
Rome’s children’s museum, Explora, offers plenty of activities, but it is not so big as to be overwhelming. The emphasis is on learning through play – there is a supermarket with working cash registers and weighing scales, a TV studio where kids can become news presenters and a water play area with pumps, hose pipes and waterproof overalls.

The museum also offers a Kitchen Studio where children can learn about nutrition while making and eating biscuits, and ice cream in summer, with a series of changing interactive exhibitions. The museum operates by letting children in at set times for a session; the café and playground mean there is plenty to keep everyone busy while they wait.

column4: Flavio al Velavevodetto does simple and satisfying Roman pasta and meat dishes, plus a few seafood options, at great prices. There is a lot of outdoor seating space in good weather too.

Built for Pope Innocent X in front of his family home, the Palazzo Pamphilj, the magnificent Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi (Fountain of the Four Rivers) was unveiled in 1651 in the centre of Piazza Navona.

Neapolitan architect Gian Lorenzo Bernini designed the fountain, which was paid for by means of taxes on bread and other staples. The pope’s coat of arms, the dove and the olive branch, decorate the pyramid rock formation supporting the Roman obelisk, which once stood in the Circus of Maxentius on the Appian Way.

The great rivers – the Ganges, the Danube, the Nile and the River Plate – are represented by four giants. The Nile’s veiled head symbolizes the river’s unknown source, but there is also a legend that the veil conveys Bernini’s dislike for the nearby Sant’Agnese in Agone, designed by his rival Francesco Borromini. Similarly, the athletic figure of the River Plate, cringing with arm upraised, is supposed to express Bernini’s fear that the church would collapse. Sadly, these widely believed stories have no basis in fact: Bernini had completed the fountain before Borromini started work on his church.
column54: Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi Rome | Fountain Of The Four Rivers
column55: Built for Pope Innocent X in 1651Fountain Of The Four Riversiumi lies in the centre of Piazza Navona. Plan a visit to the Fountain of the Four Rivers today.

column249: Fontana del Tritone, Fontane delle Api, Bernini’s Elephant Obelisk

column4:
In the centre of busy Piazza Barberini is one of Bernini’s liveliest creations, the Fontana del Tritone (Triton Fountain), created for Pope Urban VIII Barberini in 1642. The fountain was commissioned by the pope not long after the completion of his palace, the Palazzo Berberini, on the ridge above the square.

Acrobatic dolphins stand on their heads, twisting their tails together to support a huge scallop shell on which the sea god Triton kneels, blowing a spindly column of water up into the air through a conch shell. Entwined artistically among the dolphins’ tails are the papal tiara, the keys of St Peter and the Barberini coat of arms.

The monumental Fontana dell’Acqua Paola commemorates the reopening in 1612 of an aqueduct originally built by Emperor Trajan in AD 109. The fountain’s source is Lake Bracciano, to the northwest of Rome, which is connected to the city via the aqueduct.

When it was first built, the fountain had five small basins but the design was altered by Carlo Fontana in 1690, adding the huge basin you see today.

Built into a wall like a miniature Trevi Fountain, the Fontana dell’Acqua Paola is best visited at night, when it is illuminated and its marble columns – taken from the original St Peter’s basilica – and statues gleam with the light bouncing off its waters. In ancient times the water powered the many flour mills that existed in this area. Despite many laws intended to deter them, generations of Romans used this convenient pool of fresh water for bathing and washing their vegetables.

Just below the fountain, on the other side of the road, is a flight of steps that lead to the Tempietto.

Tucked away in a corner of Piazza Barberini, and quite easy to miss, the Fontana delle Api (Fountain of the Bees) is one of Bernini’s more modest works.

Dating from 1644, it pays homage to Pope Urban VIII Barberini, and features rather crab-like bees – a symbol of the Barberinin family – which appear to be sipping the water as it dribbles down into the basin.

A Latin inscription informs us that the water is for the use of the public and their animals.
column56: VIA VENETO |

column4:
Piazza Mattei is one of the prettiest and quietest piazzas in the centro storico and at its centre is the Fontana delle Tartarughe, or tortoise fountain, with sculptures of boys on dolphins.

It was created by the Italian architects Giacomo della Porta and Taddeo Landini in 1585, allegedly in a single night. The fountain, however, ran into problems straight away – the pressure of the water was too low for it to work properly, and so it had to be redesigned. Four of the original eight dolphins were removed, and instead of trying to make the water gush dramatically, the designers settled for a single small jet of water into the basin and a gentle stream of water from each of the remaining dolphins’ mouths.

The crowning touch came almost a century later, when an unknown artist (some say Bernini) added the tortoises which gave the fountain its name.
column54: Fontana delle Tartarughe Rome
column55: Rome’s Fontana delle Tartarughe lies in the Piazza Mattei and features sculptures of boys on dolphins. Plan a visit to the Fontana delle Tartarughe today.

column4:
The Fontanella del Facchino (Fountain of the Porter), set in the wall of the Banco di Roma, features the statue of a man whose barrel forever spouts fresh water.

Created around 1590, the fountain may have been based on a drawing by painter Jacopino del Conte. The statue most likely represents a member of the Università degli Acquaroli (Fraternity of Water-Carriers), though it is also said to be of Martin Luther, or of the porter Abbondio Rizzio, who died carrying a barrel.
column6: Via Lata, off Via del Corso

column4:
As Rome became an international power and the city expanded, the original Roman Forum became too small and emperors began to build new fora – the Fori Imperiali.

Building a new forum was also a very good way for an emperor to demonstrate his importance to the populace and the world. All had temples, were surrounded by walls and were symmetrical, and all but one were built to celebrate a victory.

Caesar built his forum, complete with a heated public toilet, to celebrate his conquest over Gaul. He spent a fortune buying up and demolishing houses on the site he had selected, and dedicated a temple to Venus, with statues of himself and Cleopatra inside.

Augustus’ forum celebrated his victory over Caesar’s assassins, Brutus and Cassius, and the temple at its centre was dedicated to Mars the Avenger, whose statue looked suspiciously like Augustus.

Domitian’s forum, of which little remains, celebrated his capture of Jerusalem, while Nerva’s was the smallest – little more than a corridor leading to a temple dedicated to the goddess Minerva.

The Forum of Trajan – built after the emperor’s victory over the Dacians – was probably the most ambitious. An entire slice of the Quirinal Hill was dug away to make room for it. Dominated by Trajan’s Column, it included two libraries and was overlooked by Trajan’s Markets.

Recent excavations reveal more and more of this forum. All are closed to the public, though visitors can view them from Via dei Fori Imperiali.

column4:
The name Foro Boario refers to the ancient cattle market that was once found here. Now the area is a mini-archaeological park, with two 2nd-century BC temples and the Arch of Janus from a little later.

If it wasn’t for the ferocious traffic, it would be a wonderful place to linger. Dating from the reign of Constantine or later, the arch is unprepossessing, but the temples are amazingly well preserved. The rectangular shrine is to Portunus, god of rivers and ports, while the circular one is a Temple of Hercules.
column56: Campo de’ Fiori to the Capitoline | Attraction | Attraction |

column3: Foro Italico and Stadio dei Marmi
column4:
Benito Mussolini built the Foro Italico sports complex in the hope of following in the footsteps of Hitler and snaring the Olympic Games. Its original name, Foro Mussolini, was understandably changed in the late 1940s after the dictator’s death, even though the 16-m (55-ft) obelisk still shouts out, “Mussolini Dux” (“Mussolini the Leader”).

The stadium, Stadio dei Marmi, is surrounded by 60 colossal travertine statues of Fascist athletes, each donated by one of the 60 Italian provinces and sculpted by unknown young sculptors. The running track in the centre is open for public use – people even walk their dogs here!

column63: The Central Live at Foro Italico hosts various outdoor concerts throughout the summer. This year’s concerts are some of today’s biggest names in Italian rock and pop: Bandabardò, Gigi d'Alessio and Alex Britti.

column4:
Fosse Ardeatine, the site of a grim Nazi massacre, is now a memorial to the values of the Resistance against the occupation, which gave birth to the modern Italian Republic.

On the evening of 24 March 1944, Nazi forces took 335 prisoners to this abandoned quarry south of Rome and shot them at point blank range. The execution was a reprisal for a bomb attack that had killed 32 German soldiers. The victims included various political prisoners, 73 Jews and ten other civilians, among them a priest and a 14-year-old boy.

The Germans blew up the tunnels where the horror had taken place, but a local peasant had witnessed the scene and later helped find the corpses.

A forbidding, bunker-like monument houses the rows of identical tombs containing the victims. Beside it is a museum of the Resistance. Interesting works of modern sculpture include The Martyrs by Francesco Coccia and the gates shaped like a wall of thorns by Mirko Basaldella.

column4:
Water gushes from the central figure of the Greek sea god Glaucus, who is surrounded by the water nymphs that give the Fountain of the Naiads its name.

Completed in 1888, the original statues of horses were replaced by sculptor Mario Rutelli’s Naiads in 1901. The fountain stands at the centre of the roundabout in Piazza della Republica.

column4:
Rome’s Galleria Nazionale d’Arte Moderna, a collection of 19th- and 20th-century art, makes its first impact with a stunning cracked-mirror floor designed by the contemporary Italian artist Alfredo Pirri.

The collections are spread over two floors. On the ground floor is a section called “Excuse me, is this art?”, which includes several pieces by French Surrealist Marcel Duchamp that make imaginative use of coat hooks, hat stands and a spade. In the same section are pierced and slashed canvasses created by Lucio Fontana in the 1950s. Paintings include Ritratti (portraits) by 20th-century Italian painter Felice Casorati, showing five generations of a family with their black cat; Watery Paths by the American Abstract Expressionist Jackson Pollock and the scribbly Second Voyage to Italy by American artist Cy Twombly, who lived in Rome for 50 years.

Sculptures include Coppa Chimerica, a curvaceous abstract bronze by Dadaist Jean Arp; two skinny scrunched bronzes of women by the Swiss-born Alberto Giacometti and a classic Figura Distesa o Forma Esterna by British sculptor Henry Moore. The most interesting pieces by earlier artists are in rooms 34–38 on the second floor, which display works by Futurists such as Gino Severini, Mario Sironi and Giacomo Balla. Exhibits include a haunting self-portrait by Giorgio De Chirico and vibrant scenes of everyday life and erupting volcanoes by the Sicilian Renato Guttuso.
column54: National Gallery of Modern Art Rome | Galleria Nazionale d’Arte Moderna
column55: The Galleria Nazionale d’Arte Moderna houses a collection of fine art in Rome. Plan your trip to Rome’s National Gallery of Modern Art today with DK Trip Planner.

column4:
Aventine Hill is one of the seven hills of Rome – lush, leafy and residential, and with stunning public gardens. One of the few locations in central Rome where the birdsong is louder than the traffic, it is a good place for a quiet picnic after sightseeing in the ancient centre.

In May and June, over 1,200 varieties of roses from all over the world are cultivated in the Roseto Comunale (Public Rose Garden). Among them are primordial species that existed 40 million years ago, and roses that were famous in antiquity, such as the Damascene Rose. Parco Savello, better known as the Giardino degli Aranci, is planted with orange trees and offers fantastic views over the Tiber to the Vatican City.

column4: The huge equestrian Garibaldi Monument is part of a commemorative park recalling the heroic events witnessed on Janiculum Hill when the French army attacked the city in 1849. Garibaldi’s Republicans fended off the greatly superior French forces for weeks until the Italians were overwhelmed and Garibaldi and his men escaped. The monument, erected in 1895, was the work of Emilio Gallori. Around the pedestal are four smaller sculptures in bronze showing battle scenes and allegorical figures.

column4:
The oldest hospital in Rome, Hospital of Santo Spirito is said to have been founded as a result of a nightmare experienced by Pope Innocent III (1198–1216). In the dream, an angel showed him the bodies of Rome’s unwanted babies dredged up from the River Tiber in fishing nets. As a result, the pope hastened to build a hospice for sick paupers.

In 1475, the hospital was reorganized by Pope Sixtus IV to care for the poor pilgrims expected for the Holy Year. Sixtus’s hospital was a radical building, with cloisters dividing the different types of patients; one area is still reserved for orphans and their nurses. Unwanted infants were passed through a revolving barrel-like contraption called the rota – still visible to the left of the central entrance in Borgo Santo Spirito – to guarantee anonymity. Martin Luther, who visited in 1511, was shocked by the number of abandoned children he saw, believing them to be “the sons of the pope himself”.

In the centre, under the hospital’s conspicuous drum, is an octagonal chapel where mass was said for patients. This room can be visited while the rest of the building still functions as a hospital.

column4: The inn Hostaria dell’Orso has been welcoming guests for over 500 years, and has a 15th-century portico and loggia built with columns from Roman ruins. Visitors to the inn have included the 16th-century French writers Rabelais and Montaigne, and Dante is also believed to have stayed here. Today it houses a legendary restaurant and nightclub.
Hosteria St Ana is renowned for its classic Roman cookery, served in a warren of basement rooms plastered with photos of famous patrons.

Officially known as the Altar of the Nation, and unofficially as the typewriter or wedding cake, Il Vittoriano is an enormous white marble building which opened in 1911 in honour of Vittorio Emanuele II and the unified Italy, of which he was king.

The building is so immense – the equestrian statue of the king in the centre measures 12 m (40 ft) from the horse’s nose to its tail, which makes it as huge as the statue of Constantine – that it dwarfs the soldiers guarding it. For most of its life the monument has been closed to the public, but it is now open and well worth a visit. The views from Il Vittoriano are spectacular, whether from the lower levels, the glass elevator or the terrace. The small museums inside are of limited interest, but the building often hosts interesting exhibitions.

column4: The long hike to the top of Janiculum Hill is rewarded by wonderful views over the city. The park’s monuments include a lighthouse and statues of Italian general Garibaldi and his wife Anita, who is buried underneath hers. There is also a cannon that is fired at noon each day. In Via della Lungara, between the Janiculum and the Tiber, stand Palazzo Corsini with its national art collection and the Villa Farnesina, decorated by Raphael for the fabulously wealthy banker Agostino Chigi.

column4:
Rome’s former Jewish Ghetto is full of narrow streets and alleys and still has a strong Jewish presence, with a synagogue and several restaurants serving traditional Jewish dishes such as carciofi alla giudia (deep-fried artichokes) and pizza dolce (a singed scone filled with candied fruit).

The first Jews came to Rome as traders in the 2nd century BC and there has been a Jewish community in Rome ever since. Jews were much appreciated for their financial and medical skills during the time of the Roman Empire. In 1555, Pope Paul IV, one of the leaders of the Inquisition, confined Rome’s Jews to one area. This region was surrounded by a wall with five gates that were opened at dawn and closed at sunset, while the inhabitants were forced to wear a yellow badge. Future popes banned Jews from all trades except the selling of old clothes and scrap iron.

Persecution started again in 1943 with the German occupation. Although many Jews were helped to escape or hidden by Roman citizens, thousands were deported to Nazi concentration camps.

column4:
The pink-stuccoed apartment overlooking the Spanish Steps in which 25-year-old John Keats breathed his last, consumptive breath in 1821 has been turned into the Keats-Shelley Memorial House, dedicated to the Romantic-era British poets who lived part of their lives in Rome.

In November 1820 the English poet John Keats came to stay with his friend, the painter Joseph Severn, in a dusty pink house, the Casina Rossa, on the corner of the Spanish Steps. Keats was suffering from consumption, and had been sent to Rome by his doctor in the hope that the mild, dry climate would help his recovery. Depressed about scathing criticism of his work, and tormented by his love for a young girl named Fanny Brawne, Keats died the following February, aged 25. His death inspired poet Percy Bysshe Shelley to write the poem Mourn not for Adonais. In July 1822, Shelley himself was drowned in a boating accident. Keats, Shelley and Severn are all buried at the Protestant cemetery in Testaccio.

In 1906 Casina Rossa house was bought by an Anglo-American association and preserved as a memorial and library in honour of English Romantic poets. The relics include a lock of Keats’s hair, some fragments of Shelley’s bones in a tiny urn and a garish carnival mask picked up by Lord Byron as a souvenir of a trip to Venice. You can visit the room where Keats died, though all the original furniture was burned after his death, on the order of the pope.

column4:
This pretty church, which epitomizes the love of light and movement of the late Baroque, is always referred to as La Maddalena out of respect for the Virgin Mary. Catholics did not want the name Mary to be associated with Mary Magdalene, a sinner who had repented.

Built in 1735, the church’s curves are reminiscent of Borromini’s San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane. The façade has been lovingly restored, although die-hard Neo-Classicists dismiss its painted stucco as “icing sugar”.

The small size of the Maddalena did not deter the 17th- and 18th-century decorators from filling the interior with ornaments, from the floor to the top of the elegant cupola. The organ loft and choir are particularly powerful examples of the Baroque’s desire to fire the imagination of the faithful. Many of the paintings and sculptures adopt the Christian imagery of the Counter-Reformation. In the niches of the nave, the statues are personifications of virtues such as Humility and Simplicity.

There are also scenes from the life of San Camillo, who died in the adjacent convent in 1614. The church belonged to his followers, the Camillians, a preaching order active in Rome’s hospitals. Like the Jesuits, they commissioned powerful works of art to convey the force of their religious message.

La Maddalena’s façade is best admired while enjoying an ice cream from one of the great ice-cream parlours nearby.

La Pallacorda is a sophisticated restaurant that strays from tradition and excels at preparing both raw and cooked seafood with a touch of imagination. A generous antipasto buffet boasts delicacies such as salmon tartare. Oysters are the house speciality and several different varieties are available. Many good pasta options are also on the menu, along with excellent desserts. A miniature chocolate cake with a liquid centre makes the perfect end to an unforgettable meal.

Le Quatrro Fontane are four small Renaissance fountains sited at the intersection of two narrow, busy streets that date from the great redevelopment of Rome during the reign of Sixtus V (1585–90).

Each fountain features a statue of a reclining deity. The river god accompanied by the she-wolf is clearly the Tiber; the other male figure may be the Arno. The female figures represent Strength and Fidelity or the goddesses Juno and Diana.

The crossroads is at the highest point of the Quirinal Hill and commands splendid views of three distant landmark obelisks: those placed by Sixtus V in front of Santa Maria Maggiore and Trinità dei Monti, and the one that stands in Piazza del Quirinale.

column4:
Below the 16th-century church of San Giuseppe dei Falegnami (St Joseph of the Carpenters) is the Mamertine Prison, a dank dungeon in which, according to Christian legend, St Peter was imprisoned.

Built between the 7th and 8th centuries BC, this was Rome’s central lockdown located within the Roman Forum. The prison, also known as Tullianum, was in an old cistern with access to the city’s main sewer (the Cloaca Maxima). The lower cell was used for executions and bodies were thrown into the sewer.

Among the enemies of Rome to be executed at the Mamertine was the Gaulish leader Vercingetorix, defeated by Julius Caesar in 52 BC.

Now just a weedy mound of ruins ringed with cypresses and sadly strewn with litter, the Mausoleum of Augustus was once the most prestigious burial place in Rome.

Augustus had the mausoleum built in 28 BC, the year he became sole ruler, as a tomb for himself and his descendants. The circular building was 87 m (285 ft) in diameter with two obelisks (now in Piazza del Quirinale and Piazza dell’Esquilino) at the entrance. Inside were four concentric passageways linked by corridors where the urns containing the ashes of the Imperial family were placed.

The first person to be buried here was Augustus’s favourite nephew, Marcellus, who had married Julia, the emperor’s daughter. He died in 23 BC, possibly poisoned by Augustus’s second wife Livia, who felt that her son, Tiberius, would make a more reliable emperor. When Augustus died in AD 14, his ashes were placed in the mausoleum, Tiberius duly became emperor and dynastic poisonings continued to fill the family vault with urns.

This sinister monument was later used as a medieval fortress, a vineyard, a private garden, and even, in the 18th century, as an auditorium and theatre. Under renovation, the mausoleum is now fenced off to the public but visitors can still admire this impressive and important site. There are plans to re-open the mausoleum exactly 2,000 years after Augustus died in AD 14 as part of a pedestrianized Tridente zone.

column4:
Built in a complex of disused barracks in the north of Rome, MAXXI (National Museum of 21st Century Arts) was the first museum of architecture established in Italy. Located in a stunning modern building designed by Iraqi architect Zaha Hadid, it also showcases emerging Italian and international artists.

MAXXI presents a permanent collection of 20th- and 21st-century architectural drawings and models, specially commissioned photography, and contemporary art in a series of concurrent thematic exhibitions that change frequently. The permanent collection contains more than 350 works, and the museum is divided into two sections, one for visual arts and the other for architecture.

Filled with stalls selling fresh produce of every kind, Mercato di Testaccio, the local market for this most Roman of areas, is a theatre set of seductive colours and textures.

Uniquely, it also houses the Roman remains found on the site during the construction of the present building; appropriately enough, archaeologists reckon that the ruins testify to a market that stood here in ancient times.

Popular with local residents, who insist on high-quality produce at reasonable prices, the market also appeals to visitors for its relaxed and friendly atmosphere.

column4:
Believed to have been created between 140 BC and AD 250, Monte Testaccio is a 36-m (118-ft) high artificial hill composed of the waste pieces of around 53 million amphorae.

Amphorae were ceramic containers used in ancient Rome to transport various dry or liquid products. The fragments of broken amphorae that make up Monte Testaccio were used to import olive oil to the booming city of Rome, which was the largest city in the world at the time.

The full architectural significance of this huge site was not realized until excavations began in the late 19th century.
column56: AVENTINE |

column4: Montevecchio is a tiny, sophisticated restaurant where well-heeled locals converse in hushed tones over delectable pasta and meat dishes.

Officially known as the Fontana dell’Acqua Felice, the Moses Fountain owes its popular name to the grotesque statue of Moses in the central niche that has caused controversy ever since it was unveiled.

The massive structure, with its three elegant arches, was designed by Domenico Fontana to mark the terminal of the Acqua Felice aqueduct, so called because it was one of the many great improvements commissioned by Felice Peretti, Pope Sixtus V. Completed in 1587, it brought clean piped water to this quarter of Rome for the first time.

The notorious statue of Moses striking water from the rock is larger than life and the proportions of the body are obviously wrong. Sculpted either by Prospero Bresciano or by Leonardo Sormani, it is a clumsy attempt to recreate the awesome appearance of Michelangelo’s Moses in the church of San Pietro in Vincoli. As soon as it was unveiled, it was said to be frowning at having been brought into the world by such an inept sculptor.

The side reliefs also illustrate water stories from the Old Testament: Aaron leading the Israelites to water and Joshua pointing the army towards the Red Sea. The fountain’s four lions are copies of Egyptian originals (now in the Vatican Museums), which Sixtus V had put there for the public’s “convenience” and “delight”.

column59: location: Fontana dell’Acqua Felice, Piazza San Bernardo. |

column4:
A large park with several villas, Villa Torlonia was created in the 19th century for a wealthy banker, Prince Giovanni Torlonia. It came to fame in the 1920s, when Torlonia’s nephew rented it out, for the tiny sum of one lira per year, to Benito Mussolini. The villa remained Mussolini’s main residence until 1943, when he was ousted from power.

After being restored in the 1990s the grounds now house a number of museums, as well as Rome’s innovative science space, Technotown. To find out more about the life of the Mussolini family, visitors can take a tour of the Casino Nobile, where exhibits include the bed in which Mussolini slept and the anti-air raid and anti-gas bunkers that he constructed, as well as old film footage of the villa.

It is a lovely walk through the grounds to the diminutive Casina delle Civette, literally “The Little House of the Owls”, which looks like a fairy-tale gingerbread house and was designed as a retreat to which the Torlonia family could escape to avoid their formal lives in the main villa. The house was almost destroyed by vandalism, fire and the Allied troops who occupied it after the fall of Mussolini. Today, its stained glass, enamelled-tile roofs and delicate wrought iron and stucco have been painstakingly restored.

column4: The select collection at Museo Barracco traces the development of sculptural art in the ancient world. The artworks were amassed during the last century by the politician Baron Giovanni Barracco, a bust of whom can be seen in the courtyard. Assyrian and Egyptian works are highlighted, along with Etruscan, Roman and paleo-Christian art. Highlights include an Egyptian relief of the scribe Nofer, a delicate Etruscan ceramic female head and a head of Apollo located in the Greek collection.

In 2003, American-Italian perfume executive and art collector Carlo Bilotti approached the mayor of Rome with the idea of a museum to house part of his collection. Three years later the Museo Carlo Bilotti opened in what had been a dilapidated villetta (chalet) used for storing oranges on the Borghese estate.

The permanent collection consists of just 22 works, 18 of which are paintings, sculptures and sketches by De Chirico. Do not miss Mistero e malinconia di una strada (1960s), which shows a girl with a hoop in a bleak futuristic city. Other works on show are a portrait of Bilotti’s wife and daughter – who died of cancer at the age of 20 – by Andy Warhol, the bronze Grande Cardinale (outside the museum) by Giacomo Manzù, Summer by the Futurist artist Gino Severini and a portrait of Bilotti by the American artist Larry Rivers. The museum is also a venue for contemporary art and photography exibitions.

column4:
One of Europe’s greatest small museums, worth seeing for its setting alone, the Galleria Borghese houses a superb collection of sculptures and paintings.

The villa and park were laid out by Cardinal Scipione Borghese, favourite nephew of Paul V, who had the house designed for pleasure and entertainment. The hedonistic cardinal was also an extravagant patron of the arts and he commissioned sculptures from the young Bernini which now rank among the artist’s most famous works. Half a dozen of Bernini’s best sculptures and Caravaggio paintings casually occupy the same rooms as Classical, Renaissance and Neo-Classical works.
