column55: San Giovanni in Laterano, known as the "Mother of All Churches", is the seat of the Pope in Rome. Plan a trip to San Giovanni church with DK Trip Planner.

column4:
Legend has it that the diminutive San Giovanni in Oleo (“St John in Oil”) marks the spot where St John was boiled in oil – and came out unscathed, or even refreshed.

Built on the site of an earlier chapel, this charming octagonal Renaissance chapel is thought to have been designed by either Baldassare Peruzzi or Antonio da Sangallo the Younger. It was restored by Borromini, who altered the roof, crowning it with a cross supported by a sphere decorated with roses. He also added a terracotta frieze of roses and palm leaves. The wall paintings inside the chapel include one of St John in a cauldron of boiling oil.
column29: Upon request; ask at the Church of San Giovanni a Porta Latina
column39: ask at San Giovanni a Porta Latina
column56: Churches, Temples and Shrines | CARACALLA |

column4:
San Girolamo della Carità was built on the same site as the home of San Filippo Neri, the 16th-century saint from Tuscany whose open, progressive approach towards religion renewed Rome’s spiritual and cultural life. He would have loved the frolicking putti shown surrounding his statue, in his chapel, as they would have reminded him of the Roman urchins he cared for during his lifetime.

The church’s breathtaking Spada Chapel was designed by Borromini, and is unique both as a work of art and as an illustration of the spirit of the Baroque age. All architectural elements are concealed so that the space of the chapel’s interior is defined solely by decorative marblework and statues. Veined jasper and precious multicoloured marbles are sculpted to imitate flowery damask and velvet hangings. Even the altar rail is a long swag of jasper drapery held up by a pair of kneeling angels with wooden wings. Although there are memorials to former members of the Spada family, oddly there is no indication as to which of the Spadas was responsible for endowing the chapel. It was probably art-lover Virgilio Spada, a follower of San Filippo Neri.
column56: CAMPO DE’ FIORI |

column4:
It was from San Gregorio Magno that St Augustine was sent on his mission to convert England to Christianity, and so, to the English, this is one of the most important churches in Rome. Founded in AD 575 by San Gregorio Magno (St Gregory the Great), who turned his family home on this site into a monastery, the church was rebuilt in medieval times and restored in 1629–33 by Giovanni Battista Soria.

San Gregorio Magno is reached via a flight of steps from the street. The forecourt contains some interesting tombs. To the left is that of Sir Edward Carne, who came to Rome several times between 1529 and 1533 as King Henry VIII’s envoy to gain the pope’s consent to the annulment of Henry’s marriage to Catherine of Aragon. The interior, remodelled by Francesco Ferrari in the mid-18th century, is Baroque, apart from the fine mosaic floor and some ancient columns. At the end of the right aisle is the chapel of St Gregory. Leading off it, another small chapel, believed to have been the saint’s own cell, houses his episcopal throne – a Roman chair of sculpted marble. The Salviati Chapel on the left contains a picture of the Virgin said to have spoken to St Gregory. Outside, amid the cypresses to the left of the church, stand three small chapels dedicated to St Andrew, St Barbara and St Sylvia (Gregory the Great’s mother). The chapels contain frescoes by Domenichino and Guido Reni.
column56: CARACALLA |

column4: San Lorenzo fuori le Mura, situated just outside the eastern wall of the city, is dedicated to San Lorenzo, one of the most revered of Rome’s early Christian martyrs, who roasted slowly to death in AD 258. The first basilica erected over his burial place by Constantine was largely rebuilt in 576 by Pope Pelagius II. Close by stood a 5th-century church dedicated to the Virgin Mary. The intriguing two-level church we see today is the result of these two churches being knocked into one. This process was started in the 8th century and finished in the 13th century by Pope Honorius III, when the nave, the portico and much of the decoration were added. The remains of San Lorenzo are in the choir of the 6th-century church (beneath the 13th-century high altar).
column56: Churches, Temples and Shrines | Children’s Rome | FURTHER AFIELD |

column4: Founded in the 5th century, San Lorenzo in Lucina is one of the city’s oldest Christian churches. Probably built on a well sacred to Juno, protectress of women, the church was rebuilt during the 12th century. Today’s external appearance is quite typical of the period, featuring a portico with reused Roman columns crowned by medieval capitals, a plain triangular pediment and a Romanesque bell tower with coloured marble inlay. The interior was totally rebuilt in 1856–8. The old basilical plan was destroyed and the two side naves were replaced by Baroque chapels. Don’t miss the fine busts in the Fonseca Chapel, designed by Bernini, or the Crucifixion by Guido Reni above the main altar. There is also a 19th-century monument honouring French painter Nicolas Poussin, who died in Rome in 1655 and was buried in the church.

The star sight inside San Luigi dei Francesi, the national church of France in Italy, is Caravaggio’s famous trio of enormous paintings in the Chapel of St Matthew. These were the artist’s first great religious works. The first, The Calling of St Matthew, shows the saint being called by Jesus and St Peter from the tax office. Light glints on the rims of coins, shimmers on velvets, brocades and an ostrich plume, and spotlights the faces of the main subjects. The second, The Martyrdom of St Matthew, is bathed in a sickly, greenish light and depicts the saint’s martyrdom. The third, The Inspiration of St Matthew, reveals how the artist’s plebeian, naturalistic approach often ran foul of Counter-Reformation tastes. This is Caravaggio’s second attempt at the scene and shows St Matthew talking to an airborne angel. Caravaggio’s first attempt at this scene was rejected by the priests of San Luigi, who objected to Matthew appearing as a dishevelled and apparently illiterate peasant – the angel appears to be teaching him to read. The rejected painting ended up in Berlin, where it was destroyed during World War II.

The church, founded in 1589, serves as a last resting place for many illustrious French people, including Chateaubriand’s lover Pauline de Beaumont.
column249: Palazzo Barberini, Sant’Agostino, Santa Maria del Popolo, Palazzo Doria Pamphilj

column4: San Marcello al Corso is believed to have been one of the city’s original places of Christian worship, which were known as tituli. A later Romanesque building burned down in 1519, and was rebuilt by Jacopo Sansovino with a single nave and many richly decorated private chapels on either side. The imposing travertine façade was designed by Fontana in late Baroque style. The third chapel on the right has fine frescoes of the Virgin Mary by Francesco Salviati. The decoration of the next chapel was interrupted by the Sack of Rome in 1527. Raphael’s follower Perin del Vaga fled, leaving the ceiling frescoes to be completed by Daniele da Volterra and Pellegrino Tibaldi when peace returned to the city. In the nave stands a splendid Venetian-style double tomb by Sansovino, a memorial to Cardinal Giovanni Michiel (victim of a Borgia poisoning in 1503) and his nephew, Bishop Antonio Orso.
column56: QUIRINAL |

column4: Founded in 336 by Pope Mark, whose relics lie underneath the altar, San Marco was created in honour of St Mark the Evangelist. The church was restored by Pope Gregory IV in the 9th century – the magnificent apse mosaics date from this period. Further major rebuilding took place in 1455–71, when Pope Paul II Barbo made San Marco the church of the Venetian community in Rome. The blue and gold coffered ceiling is decorated with Pope Paul’s heraldic crest, the lion rampant, recalling the lion of St Mark, the patron saint of Venice. The appearance of the rest of the interior, with its colonnades of Sicilian jasper, was largely the creation of Filippo Barigioni in the 1740s. Complemented by an interesting array of funerary monuments in the aisles, the style is typical of the late Roman Baroque. Leon Battista Alberti, whose name is also mentioned tentatively in connection with Palazzo Venezia, may have been the architect of the elegant travertine arcade and loggia of the façade.
column56: CAPITOL |

column4: Dine at San Marco – part pizzeria, part wine bar, part grill – to experience some of the finest pizza in Rome. The chalkboard-covered walls list the day’s specials.
column52: Food and Drink, Cafés and Bars

column4: The piece of land occupied by San Martino ai Monti has long been a site of Christian worship. In the 3rd century, devotees would meet on this spot in the house of a man named Equitius, the remains of which can still be seen today beneath the church. In the 4th century, after Constantine had legalized Christianity, Pope Sylvester I built a church here – this was one of very few things he did during his pontificate. His church was replaced in about AD 500 by St Symmachus, rebuilt in the 9th century and then transformed completely in the 1630s. The only immediate signs of its age are the ancient Corinthian columns dividing the nave and aisles. The most interesting interior features are a series of frescoed landscapes of the countryside around Rome by the 17th-century French artist Gaspare Dughet, Poussin’s brother-in-law, in the right aisle. The frescoes by Filippo Gagliardi, at either end of the left aisle, show old St Peter’s and the interior of San Giovanni in Laterano before Borromini’s redesign.
column56: ESQUILINE |
column59: transport - local_railway: Cavour, Vittorio Emanuele. | church |

column4: San Michele a Ripa Grande is a large, imposing edifice that houses the Ministry of Culture. The 17th-century building, built on the initiative of Pope Innocent XII, stretches 300 m (985 ft) along the river Tiber. In its day, it contained a home for the elderly, a boys’ reform school, a woollen mill and various chapels. Today, contemporary exhibitions are occasionally held here.
column52: Historic Sights and Landmarks, Art Galleries and Museums
column56: Historic Buildings, Streets and Piazzas | TRASTEVERE |

column4: Three Roman temples of the Republican era, which were turned into a carcere (prison), used to stand on the site of the medieval San Nicola in Carcere. The temples of Juno, Spes and Janus faced a city gate leading from the Forum Holitorium, the city’s vegetable and oil market, to the road down to the port on the Tiber. The church was rebuilt in 1599 and restored in the 19th century, but the bell tower and Roman columns are part of the original design. The columns that are embedded in the walls of the church belonged to two flanking temples whose platforms are now marked by grass lawns.
column38: Tours of excavations
column39: for tours. |
column56: CAMPO DE’ FIORI |

column4:
Though San Paolo fuori le Mura underwent a rather soulless reconstruction in the 19th-century following a fire, the grandeur of this 4th-century basilica can still impress. Some restored 5th-, 12th- and 13th-century mosaics survive, along with the original 11th-century bronze door and a grand Paschal candlestick. Fortunately, the cloisters of inlaid double columns (1214), considered the most beautiful in Rome, escaped the flames.

Rome’s second-largest church has had a history of violent ups and downs. It was built by Constantine in the 4th century, over the spot where St Paul was buried, and for about 400 years it was the largest church in Europe, until it was sacked by the Saracens in 846. It was rebuilt and fortified, but its position outside the walls left it mostly ignored until the mid-11th century, when it underwent a renewal. Then came the 1823 fire, which led to the reworking we see today.

Founded in the Middle Ages near the spot where St Peter was presumed to have been crucified, San Pietro in Montorio – church of St Peter on the Golden Hill – is the city’s Spanish church. It was rebuilt by order of Ferdinand and Isabella of Spain at the end of the 15th century, and decorated by outstanding artists of the Renaissance.

The façade is typical of a time when clean, geometric shapes derived from Classical architecture were in vogue. The single nave ends in a deep apse that once contained Raphael’s Transfiguration, now in the Vatican. Two wide chapels, one on either side of the nave, were decorated by some of Michelangelo’s most famous pupils. The left-hand chapel was designed by one of the few artists Michelangelo openly admired, Daniele da Volterra, who was also responsible for the altar painting, The Baptism of Christ. The chapel on the right was the work of Giorgio Vasari, who included a self-portrait (in black, on the left) in his altar painting, The Conversion of St Paul. The first chapel to the right of the entrance contains a powerful Flagellation by the Venetian artist Sebastiano del Piombo (1518); Michelangelo is said to have provided the original drawings. Work by Bernini and his followers can be seen in the second chapel on the left and in the flanking Raimondi tombs.
column6: Piazza di San Pietro in Montorio 2

column4:
San Pietro in Vincoli is best-known for Michelangelo’s Tomb of Pope Julius II, and its powerful sculpture, Moses. When the tomb was commissioned in 1505, Michelangelo spent eight months searching for perfect blocks of marble at Carrara in Tuscany, but Pope Julius became more interested in the building of a new St Peter’s and the project was laid aside. After the pope’s death in 1513, Michelangelo resumed work on the tomb, but had only finished the statues of Moses and The Dying Slaves when Pope Paul III persuaded him to start work on the Sistine Chapel’s Last Judgment. Michelangelo had planned a vast monument with over 40 statues, but the tomb that was built – mainly by his pupils – is simply a façade with six niches for statues. The Dying Slaves are in Paris and Florence, but the tremendous bearded Moses remained in situ. The marble from which he is chiselled is warm-toned and gleaming, almost as if he might rise to his feet at any moment and remonstrate with the world in a thunderous voice.

The original 4th-century shrine was built here to house the vincoli (chains) thought to have been used to bind St Peter in prison. In the 5th century, Empress Eudoxia deposited one of the chains in a church in Constantinople and sent the other to her daughter Eudoxia in Rome. She in turn gave hers to Pope Leo I, who had this church built to house it. Some years later the second chain was brought to Rome, where it linked miraculously with its partner. Today, you can see the chains displayed in an illuminated gold and glass box below the high altar.

San Pietro in Vincoli was rebuilt in the 8th century and again in the 15th century.
column6: Piazza di San Pietro in Vincoli 4A
column39: Free; 50 c to illuminate the statue of Moses |
column249: St Peter’s, Santa Maria sopra Minerva, Mamertine Prison

column4: San Rocco, which is named after a healer of the plague-stricken, began life as the chapel of a 16th-century hospital with beds for 50 men. A maternity wing was added for the wives of Tiber bargees to save them from having to give birth in the insanitary conditions of a boat. The hospital came to be used by unmarried mothers, and one section was set aside for women who wished to be unknown. They were even permitted to wear a veil for the duration of their stay. Unwanted children were sent to an orphanage, and if any mothers or children died they were buried in anonymous graves. The hospital was abandoned in the early 20th century, and demolished in the 1930s during the excavation of the Mausoleum of Augustus. The restrained Neo-Classical façade of the church was created by Giuseppe Valadier, the designer of Piazza del Popolo. In the sacristy is an interesting Baroque altarpiece (c.1660) by Il Baciccia, the artist who decorated the ceiling of the Gesù church.
column56: PIAZZA DI SPAGNA |

column4:
San Saba, which is hidden away in a residential street on the Little Aventine Hill, served as an oratory for Palestinian monks fleeing their homeland in the 7th century. The present building is a 10th-century renovation, with many additions.

The portico houses a fascinating collection of archaeological fragments. The church has three naves in the Greek style plus a short 11th-century nave to the left with vestiges of 13th-century frescoes of the life of St Nicholas of Bari. Particularly intriguing is a scene of three naked young ladies lying in bed, who are saved from penury by the gift of a bag of gold from St Nicholas, the future Santa Claus. The beautiful marble inlay in the main door, the floor and the remains of the choir are all 13th-century Cosmati work.

San Salvatore in Lauro – named after the laurel grove that grew here in ancient times – was built at the end of the 16th century by Ottaviano Mascherino. The bell tower and sacristy were 18th-century additions by Nicola Salvi, who is famous for the Trevi Fountain. The church contains the first great altarpiece by the 17th-century artist Pietro da Cortona, The Birth of Jesus, in the first chapel to the right. The adjacent convent of San Giorgio, to the left, has a pretty Renaissance cloister, a frescoed refectory and the monument to Pope Eugenius IV (reigned 1431–47), which was moved here when the old St Peter’s was pulled down. An extravagant Venetian, Eugenius would willingly spend thousands of ducats on his gold tiara, but requested a “simple, lowly burial place” near his predecessor Pope Eugenius III. His portrait, painted by Salviati, hangs in the refectory. In 1669, San Salvatore in Lauro became the seat of a pious association, the Confraternity of the Piceni, who were inhabitants of the Marche region. Fanatically loyal to the pope, the Piceni were traditionally employed as papal soldiers and tax collectors.
column6: Piazza di San Salvatore in Lauro 15
column63: Each year on the anniversary of his death, Padre Pio is honored with celebrations and a procession leading from the church to Piazza Navona, with thousands of devotees participating. Mass is held in the piazza in front of the church on this day due to the large number of attendees.

column4: A small church with a significant place in history, San Sisto Vecchio was granted to St Dominic in 1219 by Pope Honorius III. The founder of the Dominican order soon moved his own headquarters to Santa Sabina on the Aventine, and San Sisto became the first home of the order of Dominican nuns. The church, with its 13th-century bell tower and frescoes, is a popular venue for weddings.
column56: Churches, Temples and Shrines | CARACALLA |

column4: The round, compact 6th-century Greek Orthodox San Teodoro, located at the foot of the Palatine, is one of Rome’s hidden gems. St Theodore was martyred on this spot, and this church was built into the ruins of a great grain warehouse that stood here. The 6th-century apse mosaic showing Christ seated upon an orb is original, but the Florentine cupola (1454) and other treatments are mostly 15th-century restorations ordered by Pope Nicholas V. The fetching outer courtyard was designed by Carlo Fontana in 1705. If you are in the area on a Sunday morning, you will find the church a delight to visit for the Greek Orthodox services.
Try the tempting tasting menu of traditional recipes from Rome and the area immediately south at Sangallo ai Coronari. Consult the in-house sommelier for wine suggestions.

The work of Antonio da Sangallo the Younger at the request of Pope Paul III, the Sangallo Bastion is a fortification in the Aurelian Wall dating from 1537. The pope was haunted by the memory of the Sack of Rome in 1527 and feared an attack by the Turks. Today, the bastion’s massive bulk can only be admired from the outside.
column56: Monuments and Tombs | CARACALLA |

column4: Sant’Agata dei Goti was built for the Goths who occupied Rome in the 6th century AD. They were Arian heretics who denied the divinity of Christ. The church was founded between AD 462 and 470, shortly before the main Gothic invasions, and the beautiful granite columns date from this period. The main altar has a well-preserved 12th-century Cosmatesque tabernacle, but the most delightful part of the church is the charming 18th-century courtyard built around an ivy-draped well.
column56: QUIRINAL |

column4:
Located in an Early Christian complex, Sant’Agnese fuori le Mura stands among the ruins of a covered cemetery, some extensive catacombs and the crypt where the 13-year-old martyr St Agnes was buried in AD 304. According to legend, Agnes was exposed naked by order of Emperor Diocletian, furious that she should have rejected the advances of a young man at his court, but her hair miraculously grew to protect her modesty.

This church is said to have been built at the request of Emperor Constantine’s daughter, Constantia, after she had prayed at the Tomb of St Agnes for delivery from leprosy. Though altered over the centuries, the form and much of the structure of the 4th-century basilica remain intact. In the sublime 7th-century apse mosaic, St Agnes appears as a bejewelled Byzantine empress in a stole of gold and a violet robe. According to tradition she appeared like this eight days after her death holding a white lamb. Every year on 21 January two lambs are blessed on the church altar and a vestment called the pallium is woven from their wool. Every newly appointed archbishop is sent a pallium by the pope.
column39: to catacombs. |

column4:
Sant’Agnese in Agone, which was commissioned by Pope Innocent X in 1652, is thought to be located on the site of the brothel where the 13-year-old St Agnes was stripped to force her to renounce her faith. A marble relief in the crypt shows how the saint’s hair grew miraculously to protect her modesty. The young woman was martyred on this site and is buried in the catacombs that bear her name along the Via Nomentana.

The first architects of the church you see today were father and son Girolamo and Carlo Rainaldi, but they were replaced by Borromini in 1653, whose façade is a wonderful play of concave and convex shapes. Note the statue of St Agnes on the façade.
column249: Sant’Agnese fuori le Mura, Sant’Ivo alla Sapienza, San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane, Palazzo Spada

column4:
The highlight of Sant’Agostino is an elegant marble statue of the Madonna by the 15th-century Italian artist Jacopo Sansovino, which looks like a Roman goddess; indeed, it may have been inspired by a statue of Juno. Known as the Madonna del Parto (Madonna of Childbirth), the statue is surrounded by photographs of babies, children’s drawings and embroidered hearts – gifts from those whose prayers to the Madonna for a child were answered. To one side is a book in which people from all over the world have written their prayers.

The church also displays Caravaggio’s Madonna dei Pellegrini (Madonna of the Pilgrims). The sculpture shows a pair of scandalously scruffy pilgrims, with the filthy soles of their feet in full view, kneeling before the Madonna, who stands barefoot in the doorway of a house with a flaking wall, holding her overly large Christ child. The painting caused a shock on its unveiling in 1603 – people were accustomed to seeing the Madonna on an altar, not standing barefoot in a doorway, and what is more, with dirty toenails.
column249: Santa Maria del Popolo, San Luigi dei Francesi

column4:
It is widely agreed that Sant’Andrea al Quirinale represents Bernini’s architectural peak – it was, after all, the only construction over which he was able to exercise total artistic control. The church, which was built between 1658 and 1670, has long been dubbed the “Pearl of the Baroque” because of its beautiful roseate marble interior. It was built for the Jesuits, hence the many IHS emblems (Iesus Hominum Salvator – Jesus Saviour of Mankind).

The church is oval in shape and set on its short axis so that the first thing people see upon entry is the high altar niche in which sculpted angels appear to be positioning a painting of the saint being crucified on his diagonal cross. Higher up is a statue of the saint floating on a cloud, as if he has just slipped through the gap in the broken pediment behind him, on his way to heaven. The eye is drawn around the theatrical space, which combines architecture, painting and sculpture to re-enact the martyrdom and subsequent journey to heaven of St Andrew. The impact of Sant’Andrea al Quirinale is surprisingly grand, for so small a church.

The rooms of St Stanislas Kostka in the adjacent convent should not be missed. The quarters of the Jesuit novice, who died in 1568 aged 19, reflect not his own spartan taste, but the richer style of the 17th-century Jesuits. The Polish saint has been brilliantly immortalized in marble by Pierre Legros (1666–1719).
column54: Sant’Andrea al Quirinale Rome | Church of Saint Andrew’s Quirinal
column55: Sant’Andrea al Quirinale is a domed church in Rome that has long been dubbed the "Pearl of Baroque". Plan your trip to St Andrew’s in Quirinale here.

column4:
There’s a lot to take in at the Counter-Reformation giant Sant’Andrea della Valle. People usually visit for one of three reasons. Firstly, to see, first hand, the setting of the first act of Puccini’s opera Tosca. Secondly, to marvel at the curiously asymmetrical façade, which came about as a result of architect Carlo Rainaldi’s incredibly artistic temperament. And thirdly, to be dazzled by the city’s second-largest dome, built by Carlo Maderno in 1622–5 and covered on the inside with splendid frescoes by Domenichino and Lanfranco. Staring up at the ceiling frescoes, all the clouds will start to seem real, and the figures above them will seem to float out from the walls and hang suspended in three-dimensional space. This optical illusion was Lanfranco’s creation; his rival, Domenichino, was so angry when he lost most of the commission that he tampered with the scaffolding erected in the dome, hoping that Lanfranco would fall and break his neck.

The church’s interior is illuminated by golden light that filters through high windows, showing off the gilded interior. Here lie the two popes of the Sienese Piccolomini family: on the left of the central nave is the tomb of Pius II, the first Humanist pope (reigned 1458–64); Pope Pius III lies opposite – he reigned for less than a month in 1503.

The name Sant’Andrea delle Fratte (fratte means thickets) conjures up images of what would have been, in the 12th century, the church’s semi-rural setting. Though the church is now firmly embedded in Rome, its location once marked the northern edge of the city.

The church was completely rebuilt in the 17th century, partly by Borromini. His bell tower and dome, best viewed from the higher ground further up Via Capo le Case, are remarkable for the complex arrangement of concave and convex surfaces. The bell tower is particularly fanciful, with angel caryatids, flaming torches, and exaggerated scrolls like semi-folded hearts supporting a spiky crown.

In 1842, the Virgin Mary appeared in the church to a Jewish banker, who promptly converted to Christianity and became a missionary. Inside, the chapel of the Miraculous Madonna is the first thing you notice. The church is better known, however, for the angels that Borromini’s rival, Bernini, carved for the Ponte Sant’Angelo. Pope Clement IX declared they were too lovely to be exposed to the weather, so they remained with Bernini’s family until 1729, when they were moved to the church.
column56: PIAZZA DI SPAGNA |
column249: Sant Agnese in Agone, San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane

column4: The Baroque Sant’Antonio dei Portoghesi faces the Torre della Scimmia, a rare remnant of medieval Rome.
column39: Free |
column56: Around Piazza Navona | Best of the Rest | Attraction |

column3: Sant’Egidio and Museo di Roma in Trastevere
column4: The 17th-century Sant’Egidio once served the neighbouring Carmelite convent, one of many founded in the area to shelter the poor and destitute. The convent is now home to the fascinating Museo di Roma in Trastevere, which exhibits a wealth of material relating to the festivals, pastimes, superstitions and customs of the Romans when they lived under papal rule. Don’t miss the old paintings and prints of the city, or the tableaux showing scenes of everyday life in 18th- and 19th-century Rome, including reconstructions of shops and a tavern. The museum also has manuscripts by the much-loved poets Belli and Trilussa, who wrote in local dialect.
column63: With 134 photos on display, “The Italian Landscape: Photographs from 1950–2010” highlights different approachs to photographing the Italian landscape over the last 60 years. From the pictorialists to the neorealists, the photographers touch on themes like “invaded city” and “the beauty of the Mediterranean”.
column69: Paola Binante. Generazioni pluralità del femminile
column72: The photography of Paola Binante is featured in the personal exhibition Generations Plurality of the Feminine. Her work explores the family and the role of the matriarch, with the goal of revealing the most intimate changes during the metamorphosis of the feminine through the generations.
column81: The World Press Photo Award is one of the most important recognitions in photojournalism. For the past 57 years, an independent jury has voted on the year’s outstanding journalistic photos. This selection takes a look at the most significant events in our collective recent history.
column90: Born Invisible features photos by Sheila McKinnon, who shines the spotlight on the role of young women and adolescent girls, particularly those “without a voice” or “invisible”. Their role is put into a context of the female condition together with social and humanitarian aspects of development.
column96: Una Capitale allo specchio, il rione Trevi tra età moderna e contemporanea
column99: Reflections of a Capital: the Trevi District Between the Modern and the Contemporary explores the process of modernization in this particularly significant neighborhood over a long period. Documents and photographs tracing the history of the development of the area are on display.

column4: As its name suggests, early 16th-century Sant’Eligio degli Orefici was commissioned by a corporation of goldsmiths (orefici). The original design was by Raphael, who, like his master Bramante, had acquired a sense of the grandiose from the remains of Roman antiquity. The influence of some of Bramante’s works, such as the choir of Santa Maria del Popolo, is evident in the simple way the arches and pilasters here define the structure of the walls. The cupola of Sant’ Eligio is attributed to Baldassarre Peruzzi, while the façade was added in the early 17th century by Flaminio Ponzio. Among the various 16th-century painters who decorated the interior was Taddeo Zuccari, who worked on Palazzo Farnese.
column29: 9:30am–1pm Mon–Fri (ring bell first at Via di Sant’Eligio 7)
column56: Churches, Temples and Shrines | CAMPO DE’ FIORI |

column4:
The Romanesque bell tower of Sant’Eustachio is one of the few surviving remains of the medieval church, which was completely renovated in the 17th and 18th centuries.

In the early Christian era, the church on this spot offered relief to the poor. In medieval times, many charitable brotherhoods elected Sant’Eustachio as their patron and had chapels here. While you’re here, stop by the excellent Caffè Sant’Eustachio nearby.
column56: PIAZZA DELLA ROTONDA |

column4:
The Baroque Sant’Ignazio di Loyola is at its loveliest in the evening, when its marble columns and pavements gleam, and its polished brass glints in the lamplight. The beautiful church was built by Pope Gregory XV in 1626 in honour of St Ignatius of Loyola, founder of the Society of Jesus and the man who most embodied the zeal of the Counter-Reformation. Together with the Gesù church, Sant’Ignazio forms the centre of the Jesuit area in Rome.

When this church was finished in 1685, it still lacked a dome. So the master of trompe-l’oeil, Andrea Pozzo, used his flawless technique to create the illusion of an airy dome on the flat circle of ceiling over the church’s crossing; stand on the yellow marble disc for the full effect, then walk directly under the “dome” to see how skewed the painting actually is.

Sant’Ignazio di Loyola has a Latin-cross plan, with an apse and many side chapels. It cannot be denied that its vast interior, lined with precious stones, marble, stucco and gilt, creates a distinct sense of theatre. The frescoes in the nave celebrate the missionary work done by the Jesuits all over the world, with four women representing Europe, Asia, America and Africa.
column38: Free guided tours

column4: Sant’Ivo alla Sapienza stands in the city’s most gorgeous courtyard, part of the Palazzo della Sapienza, seat of the old University of Rome from the 15th century until 1935. Its crowning glory is the spiralling ellipse of the dome – a highly distinctive landmark from Rome’s roof terraces. The hexagonal church is based on a ground design of astonishing geometrical complexity, and the walls are a breathtaking combination of concave and convex surfaces. There is also a scalloped cupola. Sant’Ivo is one of the most ingenious of the churches built by the 17th-century architect Francesco Borromini, though it must be said that the interior disappoints, despite its flower shape and the Pietro da Cortona altarpiece. In the courtyard, Borromini incorporated elements from the coats of arms of six popes. Look for bees (Pope Urban VIII Barberini), doves with olive branches in their beaks (Pope Innocent X Pamphilj), a star and jelly-mould (Pope Alexander VI Chigi), dragon (Pope Gregory VIII Buoncampagni), dragon and eagle (Pope Paul VI Borghese) and a lion holding some pears (Pope V Montalto). When the courtyard is closed, you can see the dome from Piazza Sant’Eustachio.
column249: Sant’Agnese in Agone, San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane, Palazzo Spada

column4: Sant’Onofrio was founded in 1419 in honour of the hermit Sant’Onofrio by the Blessed Nicola da Forca Palena, whose tombstone can still be seen today at the entrance. The simple shapes of the portico and the cloister retain the flavour of the 15th century. In the early 17th century the portico was decorated with frescoes by Domenichino. The monastery next to the church houses a small museum dedicated to the 16th-century Italian poet Torquato Tasso, who died here.
column29:
Church: 9am–1pm Mon–Fri, Sun; closed Aug (except 12 Aug)

Museum: by appointment only
column52: Religious Buildings, Art Galleries and Museums
column56: JANICULUM |

column4: One of Rome’s oldest churches, Santa Balbina was built in the 5th century on the remains of a Roman villa overlooking the Baths of Caracalla. The isolated church, which is dedicated to a 2nd-century virgin martyr, served as a fortified monastery in the Middle Ages. Over time it has changed in appearance several times, regaining its Romanesque aspect in the 1920s. From the piazza in front of the church, a staircase leads up to a three-arched portico. Inside, light streams in from a series of high windows along the length of the nave. The remains of St Balbina and her father, St Quirinus, are in an urn at the high altar, though the church’s real treasure is situated in the far right-hand corner: the magnificent sculpted and inlaid tomb of Cardinal Stefanis de Surdis by Giovanni di Cosma (1303). Other features worth seeing are a 13th-century episcopal throne and various fragments of frescoes. These include a lovely Madonna and Child, an example of the school of Pietro Cavallini, in the second chapel on the left. Fragments of 1st-century Roman mosaics were discovered in the 1930s. Depicting birds and signs of the zodiac, these are now set in the church’s floor.
column56: CARACALLA |

column4: Santa Bibiana was Bernini’s first attempt at building design, as its clean lines and unadorned façade suggest. The church was built on the site of the palace belonging to Bibiana’s family, and it is where the saint was buried after she was flogged to death with leaded cords during the brief persecution of the Christians in the reign of Julian the Apostate (361–3). Just inside the church is a small column against which Bibiana is said to have been whipped. Her remains, along with those of her mother, Dafrosa, and her sister, Demetria, who also suffered martyrdom, are preserved in an alabaster urn below the altar. In a niche above the altar stands a statue of Santa Bibiana by Bernini – the first fully clothed figure he sculpted. He depicts her standing beside a column, holding the cords with which she was whipped, apparently on the verge of a deadly swoon.
column56: ESQUILINE |
column59: transport - tram: 5, 14. | transport - local_railway: Vittorio Emanuele. | church |

column4:
It is said that Santa Cecilia in Trastevere was built over the house of the martyred aristocrat and patron saint of music who gives the church its name. After an attempt to suffocate Cecilia to death failed, she was beheaded here in AD 230. Her body was lost but it turned up in the Catacombs of San Callisto and was buried here in the 9th century by Pope Paschal I, who also rebuilt the church.

A fine apse mosaic survives from this period. The altar canopy by Arnolfo di Cambio and the fresco of The Last Judgment by Pietro Cavallini, reached through the adjoining convent, date from the 13th century, one of the few periods when Rome had a distinctive artistic style of its own. In front of the altar is a statue of St Cecilia by Stefano Maderno, who used sketches of her miraculously preserved remains as a model when she was briefly disinterred in 1599. Her house, beneath the church with the remains of a Roman tannery, is well worth a visit.
column39: for excavations. |
column54: Santa Cecilia in Trastevere | Visit Santa Cecilia Church Rome
column55: Santa Cecilia in Trastevere is a church in Rome said to be built over the house of Saint Cecilia. Plan your trip to the Santa Cecilia church in Rome today.

column4: The smooth, round Santa Costanza has a very distinctive look in a city of angular churches and tall spires. It was built in the 4th century as a mausoleum for Emperor Constantine’s daughters, Constantia and Helena. The dome and its drum are supported by a circular arcade resting on 12 pairs of magnificent granite columns. The ambulatory around the interior has truly delightful, richly detailed scenes of an ancient Roman grape harvest. In a niche on the side of the church furthest from the entrance is a replica of Constantia’s ornately carved porphyry sarcophagus. The original was moved to the Vatican Museums in 1790. The sanctity of Constantia is debatable – she was described by the historian Marcellinus as a fury incarnate, constantly goading her equally unpleasant husband, Hannibalianus, to violence. Her canonization was probably the result of some confusion with a saintly nun of the same name.
column56: FURTHER AFIELD |

column4: Santa Croce in Gerusalemme was founded in AD 320 in the grounds of the private palace of Emperor Constantine’s mother, St Helena. Although the church stood at the edge of the city, the relics of the Crucifixion that St Helena had brought back from Jerusalem made it a centre of pilgrimage. Most important were the pieces of Christ’s Cross (croce means cross) and part of Pontius Pilate’s inscription in Latin, Hebrew and Greek reading: “Jesus of Nazareth King of the Jews”. In the crypt is a Roman statue of Juno, found at Ostia, transformed into a statue of St Helena by replacing the head and arms and adding a cross. The 15th-century apse fresco shows the medieval legends that arose around the Cross. Helena is shown holding it over a dead youth and restoring him to life. Another episode shows its recovery from the Persians by the Byzantine Emperor Heraclitus after a bloody battle. In the centre of the apse is a magnificent tomb by Jacopo Sansovino made for Cardinal Quiñones, Emperor Charles V’s confessor (died 1540).
column6: Piazza di Santa Croce in Gerusalemme 12
column54: Santa Croce Gerusalemme | Santa Croce Rome
column55: Santa Croce in Gerusalemme is a church in Rome that was founded in AD 320. Plan your trip to the Basilica di Santa Croce in Rome with DK Trip Planner.
column56: LATERAN |

column3: Santa Maria degli Angeli e dei Martiri
column4:
Sadly, not much of Michelangelo’s 1563 design for Santa Maria degli Angeli e dei Martiri is in evidence today – the building was so altered in the 18th century that it has lost most of its original character. But the exhibition in the sacristy gives a detailed account of the original structure.

Commissioned by the pope, Michelangelo transformed the central hall of Diocletian’s Baths, the frigidarium (cold plunge room), into a church. The result was an overwhelming space. He had to raise the floor by 2 m (6 ft) in order to use the ancient 15-m (50-ft), rose-red granite columns the way he wanted to.
column249: Baths of Diocletian and Aula Ottagona, Palazzo Farnese

column3: Santa Maria dei Miracoli and Santa Maria in Montesanto
column4: Santa Maria dei Miracoli and Santa Maria in Montesanto, a pair of 17th-century churches at the southern end of Piazza del Popolo, are known for the optical illusion that was so central to their design. To provide a focal point for the piazza, the churches had to appear symmetrical, but the site on the left was narrower. Local architect Carlo Rainaldi (1611–91) decided to give Santa Maria dei Miracoli (on the right) a circular dome and Santa Maria in Montesanto an oval one to squeeze it into the narrower site, while keeping the sides of the supporting drums that face the piazza identical. The clever design gives creates the illusion that the three streets cutting down through the centro storico, known as “Il Tridente“, form a perfect triangle, when they actually do not. A great feat of design, the twin churches proved beyond doubt that Rainaldi could be as ingenious as his peers, Bernini and Borromini. Stand in the centre of the piazza, in front of the obelisk, to judge this visual trick.
column5: EWTG_ROME136SANMAR, TT_ROME112BESRES_005_R13, EWFG_ROME150SANMAR, TT_ROME112BESRES_031_R13, TT_ROME112BESRES_029_R13, EWTG_ROME136SANMAR_003, EWTG_ROME136SANMAR_004

column4: Santa Maria ai Monti, designed by Giacomo della Porta in 1580, is renowned for its splendid dome. Inside, don’t miss the stunning medieval painting of the Madonna, patroness of this quarter of Rome, positioned over the high altar. The altar in the left transept houses the tomb and effigy of the unworldly French saint Benoît-Joseph Labre, who died here in 1783 having spent his life as a solitary pilgrim. He slept rough in the ruins of the Colosseum, gave away any charitable gifts he received, and came regularly to Santa Maria ai Monti to worship. His faith could not sustain his body: still in his mid-thirties, he collapsed and died outside the church. The foul rags he wore are preserved.
column56: QUIRINAL |

column4:
One of Rome’s greatest stores of artistic treasure, Santa Maria del Popolo is one of the few churches with its major chapels still intact, preserving the artworks inside.

According to legend, the church occupies the site where Emperor Nero’s nurse and girlfriend secretly buried his body after his death. They planted walnut trees over the grave, and for centuries the ravens nesting there were believed to be demons fleeing from Nero’s soul. In 1099, the pope decided to exorcise the site, dig up the walnut trees and have a chapel built. The church that stands here today was commissioned by Pope Sixtus IV della Rovere in 1472.

Many illustrious families have chapels here, all decorated with appropriate splendour. The della Rovere Chapel has delightful Pinturicchio frescoes, the Cerasi Chapel has two Caravaggio masterpieces – The Conversion of St Paul and The Crucifixion of St Peter – but the finest of all is the Chigi Chapel, designed by Raphael for his patron, the banker Agostino Chigi. Bernini later altered the chapel to help clarify the interplay of art across the small space. The most striking of the church’s many Renaissance tombs are the two by Andrea Sansovino behind the main altar.
column5: EWTG_ROME138SANMAR, TT_ROME032-033SANMAR, TT_ROME006ROMHIG_008, TT_ROME044CHURCH_002, TT_ROME108SPASTE_002, EWFG_ROME148SANMAR

column4: Santa Maria dell’Anima is the German church in Rome, and some of its paintings illustrate events connected with the history of Germany. The Miracle of St Benno by Carlo Saraceni (1618) is one such example. Also inside is the superb tomb by Baldassarre Peruzzi of Pope Adrian VI (reigned 1522–3). This son of a shipbuilder from Utrecht, the last non-Italian pope before John Paul II, would have disapproved of its design, however – it is redolent of the pagan Renaissance spirit he had so condemned during his brief, rather gloomy reign, when patronage of the arts ground to a halt.

In the 16th century, Santa Maria dell’Orazione e Morte was the meeting place of a pious confraternity who collected bodies of the unknown dead and gave them a Christian burial. Unsurprisingly, the theme of death is stressed throughout the church, which is dedicated to St Mary of Prayer and Death. The doors and windows of Ferdinando Fuga’s dramatic Baroque façade are decorated with winged skulls, and above the central entrance there is a clepsydra (an ancient hourglass), symbolizing death.
column56: CAMPO DE’ FIORI |
column249: Santa Maria della Concezione, San Giovanni Decollato

column4: Santa Maria della Concezione is a plain, unassuming church at the foot of the Via Veneto. It was founded in 1626 by Antonio Barberini, Pope Urban VIII’s brother, who was a cardinal and a Capuchin friar. When he died he was buried not in a grand marble sarcophagus, like most cardinals, but below a simple flagstone near the altar, with the bleak epitaph in Latin: “Here lies dust, ashes, nothing”. The grim reality of death is illustrated even more graphically in the crypt beneath the church, where generations of Capuchin friars decorated the walls of the five vaulted chapels with the bones and skulls of their departed brethren.
column56: VIA VENETO |

column4: Santa Maria della Consolazione stands near the foot of the Tarpeian Rock, the site where traitors were executed in the 8th-century BC Sabine War, a function it retained for centuries after. In 1385, Giordanello degli Alberini, a condemned nobleman, paid two gold florins to have an image of the Virgin Mary placed here to provide consolation to prisoners in their final moments before execution – hence the name of the church that was built here in 1470. It was reconstructed between 1583 and 1600 by Martino Longhi, who provided the early Baroque façade. The church’s 11 side chapels were owned by noble families and local crafts guild members. In the presbytery is a famed image of Mary attributed to Antoniazzo Romano.
column56: AVENTINE |

column4:
Santa Maria della Pace was one of the most fashionable churches in Renaissance Rome, frequented by artists, aristocrats and bankers, as well as by women who considered going to Mass a great opportunity to show off their best clothes and find wealthy husbands and admirers.

The church was built to mark the site where a drunken soldier allegedly pierced the breast of a painted Madonna, and caused it to bleed. Pope Sixtus IV della Rovere (reigned 1471–84) placated the Virgin by ordering Baccio Pontelli to build her a church if she would bring the war with Turkey to an end. Peace was restored and the church was named St Mary of Peace.

The church’s lovely and surprising façade (1656–7), its curved portico squeezed into a tiny piazza, is a Baroque masterpiece by Pietro da Cortona. The cloister was added by Bramante in 1504. As in his famous Tempietto, he scrupulously followed Classical rules of proportion and achieved a monumental effect in a relatively small space. Pietro da Cortona may also have had Bramante’s Tempietto in mind when he added the church’s charming semi-circular portico in 1656.

The church’s interior, a short nave ending under an octagonal cupola, houses Raphael’s famous frescoes of four Sybils (1514), which were influenced by the then recently unveiled Sistine Chapel ceiling. The Sibyls range from a beautiful young blonde woman to a very old lady, each receiving a revelation from an angel. They are best seen from Bramante’s cloister. The four Prophets by Raphael’s pupil Timoteo Viti, painted for the banker Agostino Chigi in 1514, are also on display here. Baldassarre Peruzzi also did some work in the church (the fresco in the first chapel on the left), as did the architect Antonio da Sangallo the Younger, who designed the second chapel on the right.
column249: Villa Farnesina, Tempietto, Vatican Museums, Palazzo Barberini

column4: The simple façade of Santa Maria della Scala belies its richly decorated interior, which boasts multi-coloured marbles and a number of spirited Baroque altars and reliefs. This charming church belongs to a time of great building activity that lasted for about 30 years from the end of the 16th century. In 1849, the church was used as a hospital to treat Garibaldi’s soldiers. When visiting, don’t miss the beautiful Virgin and Child by Cavalier d’Arpino (Caravaggio’s teacher).

Boasting one of the most ornate church interiors in Rome, the 17th-century Santa Maria della Vittoria really is an unmissable sight. The intimate, candlelit space, which is caked in stucco, coloured marbles and gold, is mainly the work of Bernini and his students. It contains one of Bernini’s most ambitious sculptural works, The Ecstasy of St Teresa (1646), centrepiece of the Cornaro Chapel, which was built to resemble a miniature theatre. It even has an audience: sculptures of the chapel’s benefactor, Cardinal Federico Cornaro, and his ecclesiastical family members, past and present, sit in boxes, as if watching and discussing the scene occurring in front of them. Visitors may be shocked or thrilled by the physical nature of St Teresa’s ecstasy. She lies on a cloud, her mouth half open and her eyelids closed, with rippling drapery covering her body. Looking over her with a smile, which from different angles can appear either tender or cruel, is a curly-haired angel holding an arrow with which he is about to pierce the saint’s body for a second time. The marble figures are framed and illuminated by rays of divine light materialized in bronze.
column249: Piazza San Pietro, San Francesco a Ripa, Museo e Galleria Borghese

column4:
The 6th-century Santa Maria in Aracoeli stands on the site of the ancient Temple of Juno Moneta, which also housed the Roman mint – explaining the origin of the word “money”. Superstition claims that you can win the Italian lottery by climbing the 14th-century staircase leading to the unfinished façade on your knees – who knows if you’ll strike it rich, but what is certain is that you’ll be rewarded by a fine view.

The church stands on the northern summit of the Capitoline, hence its name, which translates as St Mary of the Altar in the Sky. Its 22 columns were taken from various ancient buildings; the inscription on the third column to the left tells us that it comes “a cubiculo Augustorum” – from the bedroom of the emperors.

The church of the Roman senators and people, Santa Maria in Aracoeli has been used to celebrate many triumphs over adversity. Its ceiling, with naval motifs, commemorates the Battle of Lepanto (1571), and was built under Pope Gregory XIII Boncompagni, whose family crest, the dragon, can be seen towards the altar end. Many other Roman families and individuals are honoured by memorials in the church. To the right of the entrance door, the tombstone of archdeacon Giovanni Crivelli, rather than being set into the floor of the church, stands eternally to attention, partly so that the signature “Donatelli” (by Donatello) can be read at eye-level.

The frescoes in the first chapel on the right, painted by Pinturicchio in the 1480s in the beautifully clear style of the Early Renaissance, depict St Bernardino of Siena. On the left wall, the perspective of The Burial of the Saint slants to the right, taking into account the position of the viewer just outside the chapel. The church is most famous, however, for an icon with apparently miraculous powers, the Santo Bambino, a 15th-century olive-wood figure of the Christ Child that was carved from wood taken from a tree in the garden of Gethsemane. Its powers are said to include resurrecting the dead, and it is sometimes summoned to the bedsides of the gravely ill. The original figure was stolen in 1994, but it has been replaced by a replica. At Christmas, the Christ Child takes its place in the centre of a picturesque crib (second chapel to the left), but is usually to be found in the sacristy, as is the panel of the Holy Family from the workshop of Giulio Romano.
column63: Hundreds of people climb the 124 steps up to the church as bagpipers play traditional medieval tunes. At midnight, the Santa Bambino statue is brought from a private chapel to a ceremonial throne before the high altar.

column4:
Santa Maria in Campitelli was built in 1667 to house an icon of the Virgin, the Madonna del Portico, to which many Romans prayed for a cure for the plague. When a particularly lethal outbreak of the plague abated in 1656, public gratitude was so strong that this church was built to contain the sacred icon.

Carlo Rainaldi, a pupil of Bernini, designed the church. The main elements of the lively Baroque façade are the graceful columns, symbolizing the supporters of the true faith. Inside stands a fabulously ornate, gilded altar tabernacle with spiral columns, which was designed by Giovanni Antonio de Rossi to contain the icon of the Virgin. The side chapels were decorated by some of Rome’s finest Baroque painters: Sebastiano Conca, Giovanni Battista Gaulli (known as Il Baciccia) and Luca Giordano.

To see inside Santa Maria in Campo Marzio, you must first walk through a courtyard – as you do, be sure to look out for the fascinating remnants of medieval houses around the edge. The church was rebuilt in 1685 by Antonio de Rossi, using a square Greek-cross plan with a cupola. Above the altar is a 12th-century painting of the Madonna.
column56: PIAZZA DELLA ROTONDA |

column4:
Santa Maria in Cosmedin, which is located on the site of the ancient city’s food market, is a beautiful, unadorned church built in the 6th century. Two hundred years later, it became the focus of Rome’s Greek community. The Greek epithet in Cosmedin means “decorated”. Very little of the earlier ornamentation remains; most of it is from the 12th and 13th centuries, although there is a graceful altar screen that’s characteristic of Eastern Orthodox churches. The elegant Romanesque bell tower and portico you see today were added during the 12th century. In the 19th century, a Baroque façade was removed and the church was restored to its original simplicity.

Inside, you’ll find many magnificent examples of Cosmati work, in particular the mosaic pavement, the raised choir, the bishop’s throne and the canopy over the main altar. Set into the wall of the portico is the Bocca della Verità (Mouth of Truth). This may have been a drain cover, dating back to before the 4th century BC. Medieval tradition had it that the jaws would snap shut over the hands of those who told lies – a useful way of testing the faithfulness of spouses.

The 7th-century Santa Maria in Domnica, which overlooks Piazza della Navicella today, is thought to have been built on the site of an ancient Roman firemen’s barracks, which became a meeting place for Christians. In the 16th century, Pope Leo X added the portico and the coffered ceiling. In the apse, behind the modern altar, is a superb 9th-century mosaic commissioned by Pope Paschal I. Wearing the square halo of the living, the pope appears at the feet of the Virgin and Child. The Virgin, surrounded by a throng of angels, holds a handkerchief like a fashionable lady at a Byzantine court.
column56: Churches, Temples and Shrines | CARACALLA |
column249: Santa Maria Maggiore, Santa Maria in Trastevere, Santa Prassede, Santa Pudenziana

column4:
Santa Maria in Monserrato is home to some fine works of art, including Annibale Carracci’s painting San Diego de Alcalà and, in the third chapel on the left, a copy of a Sansovino statue of St James. In the courtyard and side chapels are some beautiful 15th-century tombs by Andrea Bregno and Luigi Capponi, and in the annexe is Bernini’s bust of Pedro Foix de Montoya, the church’s benefactor.

The origins of the Spanish national church in Rome go back to 1506, when a hospice for Spanish pilgrims was begun by a brotherhood of the Virgin of Montserrat in Catalonia.
column29: 5–7pm Sat, 10am–1pm & 5–7pm Sun; the church can be visted on weekdays by calling 06 688 9651
column56: CAMPO DE’ FIORI |

column4:
Santa Maria in Traspontina marks the site of an ancient Roman pyramid, which, in the Middle Ages was believed to have been the tomb of Romulus. The pyramid was destroyed by Pope Alexander VI Borgia, but representations of it can be seen in the bronze doors at the entrance to St Peter’s and in a Giotto triptych housed in the Vatican Pinacoteca.

The present church was begun in 1566 to replace an earlier one that had been in the line of fire of the cannons defending Castel Sant’Angelo during the Sack of Rome in 1527. The papal artillery officers insisted that the dome of the new church should be as low as possible, so it was built without a supporting drum. The first chapel to the right is dedicated to the gunners’ patron saint, Santa Barbara, and is decorated with warlike motifs. In the third chapel on the left are two columns, popularly thought to be the ones which saints Peter and Paul were bound to before going to their martyrdom nearby.
column56: VATICAN |

column4:
Legend has it that Santa Maria in Trastevere was founded in the 3rd century on the site where a miraculous font of olive oil spouted the day Christ was born, and it was probably the first official place of Christian worship.

Today’s church is largely a 12th-century building, remarkable for its mosaics, in particular those by Pietro Cavallini. There’s also a rare 7th-century panel painting of the Madonna della Clemenza in the chapel to the left of the altar. The 22 mismatched granite columns in the nave were taken from the ruins of ancient Roman buildings. Despite some 18th-century Baroque additions, Santa Maria has retained its medieval character. At night, the glittering mosaics on the façade are illuminated.
column6: Via della Paglia 14c, Piazza Santa Maria in Trastevere
column54: Santa Maria in Trastevere Rome | Basilica di Santa Maria in Trastevere
column55: Santa Maria in Trastevere is one of the oldest churches in Rome. Plan your trip to the Basilica di Santa Maria in Trastevere with DK Trip Planner today.
column249: Santa Maria Maggiore, Santa Prassede, Santa Pudenziana, Santa Maria in Domnica

column4: It has been said that Italian architecture is one of façades, and nowhere is this clearer than in the 1570s façade of Santa Maria in Trivio. Note the false windows. There is illusion inside too, particularly in the ceiling frescoes, which show scenes from the New Testament by Antonio Gherardi (1644–1702). The name of the tiny church probably means “St Mary-at-the-meeting-of-three-roads”.
column56: QUIRINAL |

column4: The façade and vestibule of Santa Maria in Via Lata were designed by Pietro da Cortona in 1660; the high altar was the work of Bernini in 1639–43. The church’s 6th-century frescoes can now be seen in the Crypta Balbi.
column38: Guided tours to the excavations 10am–6pm Fri–Sun
column56: Around the Pantheon | Best of the Rest | Attraction |

column4:
The biggest of the 26 churches in Rome dedicated to the Virgin Mary, Santa Maria Maggiore has a beautiful interior lined with superb mosaics.

The church has been renovated and improved by many popes over the centuries, leaving it with an unusual mix of architectural styles. Its colonnaded nave is part of the original 5th-century building. The Cosmatesque marble floor and delightful Romanesque bell tower, with its blue ceramic roundels, are medieval. The Renaissance saw a new coffered ceiling, and the Baroque gave the church twin domes and its imposing front and rear façades.

The mosaics are Santa Maria’s most famous feature. From the 5th century come the biblical scenes in the aisle. Medieval highlights include the spectacular mosaics in the nave and a 13th-century enthroned Christ in the loggia.
column38: Audioguides (€5) available in English, Italian, Spanish, French & German
column54: Church of Santa Maria Maggiore Rome | Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore
column55: Santa Maria Maggiore is the largest of the 26 churches in Rome dedicated to the Virgin Mary. Plan your trip to the Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore here.
column63: According to legend, the Virgin Mary appeared to Pope Liberius and a nobleman in August, asking that a church be built in the place where snow would fall that night. Now, every 5th August, the miraculous event is recreated with an artificial snowfall, a light show and classical music.
column249: Santa Maria in Domnica, Santa Prassede, Santa Pudenziana, Santa Maria in Trastevere

column4:
The only Florentine Gothic church in Rome, Santa Maria sopra Minerva was built in around 1280, possibly – as its name suggests – atop a temple to Minerva. The simple T-shaped, vaulted building is celebrated for its impressive collection of Italian art, largely acquired from its wealthy patrons, who wished to be remembered by their gifts.

Near the steps of the choir is the beloved sculpture of the Risen Christ (1514–21), a muscular rendition of the Saviour so shockingly nude that Church officials added the bronze wisp of drapery. Note the Cosmatesque 13th-century tombs and the exquisite works by 15th-century Tuscan and Venetian artists. Local talent of the Early Renaissance period is represented by Antoniazzo Romano, whose Annunciation (1482), features the uncle of the infamous Spanish Inquisitor, Cardinal Juan de Torquemada. The more monumental style of the Roman Renaissance is well represented in the tombs of the 16th-century Medici popes, Leo X and his cousin Clement VII. The church contains the tombs of other famous Italians: St Catherine of Siena, who died here in 1380; the Venetian sculptor Andrea Bregno (died 1506); the Humanist Cardinal Pietro Bembo (died 1547); and Fra Angelico, the Dominican friar and painter, who died in Rome in 1455. There are also splendid works of art from the Baroque period, including a tomb and a bust by Bernini.

Santa Maria sopra Minerva was the traditional stronghold of the Dominicans, whose anti-heretical zeal earned them the nickname Domini Canes (the hounds of the Lord).

Parts of the original 9th-century Santa Prassede are still in evidence today, despite several rounds of renovation over the centuries. The church, which was founded by Pope Paschal II and built over a 2nd-century oratory, features three aisles separated by rows of granite columns. In the central nave, there is a round stone slab covering the well where, according to legend, St Prassede is said to have buried the remains of 2,000 martyrs. Artists from Byzantium decorated the church with glittering, jewel-coloured mosaics. Those in the apse and choir depict stylized white-robed elders, the haloed elect looking down from the gold and blue walls of heaven, spindly legged lambs, feather-mop palm trees and bright red poppies.

In the apse, Santa Prassede and Santa Pudenziana stand on either side of Christ, with the fatherly arms of St Paul and St Peter on their shoulders. Beautiful mosaics of saints, the Virgin, and Christ and the Apostles also cover the walls and vault of the Chapel of St Zeno, built as a mausoleum for Pope Paschal’s mother, Theodora. Part of a column brought back from Jerusalem, allegedly the one to which Christ was bound and flogged, also stands here.

In order to appreciate the full impact of the church’s mosaics, one of your group should go in first with a supply of €1 coins. The rest can then walk into the gloom before the first person drops a coin into a slot to turn the lights on – turning the church into a jewel box.
column54: Santa Prassede Rome | Visit Basilica of Saint Praxedes
column55: Santa Prassede is an old church in Rome with parts of the original 9th-century building still existing. Plan your trip to the Basilica of Saint Praxedes here.
column249: Santa Maria in Domnica, Santa Maria in Trastevere, Santa Maria Maggiore.

column4:
It’s common for a church to be dedicated to an existing saint, but far less usual for the church, through a linguistic accident, to create a brand new saint, but that’s exactly what happened with Santa Pudenziana.

In the 1st century AD, a Roman senator called Pudens lived on this site, and, according to legend, allowed St Peter to lodge with him. In the 2nd century, a bath house was built here and in the 4th century, a church, known as the Ecclesia Pudentiana (the church of Pudens), was established inside the baths. In time it was assumed that “Pudentiana” was a woman’s name and a life was created for her – she became the sister of Prassede and was credited with caring for Christian victims of persecution. In 1969, both saints were declared invalid, though their churches both kept their names.

The 19th-century façade of the church retains an 11th-century frieze depicting both Prassede and Pudenziana dressed as crowned Byzantine empresses. The apse has a remarkable 4th-century mosaic, clearly influenced by Classical pagan art in its subtle use of colour. In it, the Apostles are represented as Roman senators in togas, but a clumsy attempt at restoration in the 16th century destroyed two of the Apostles and left other figures without legs.

Santa Sabina, perched high on the Aventine, is a beautifully restored example of a Roman basilica-style church. It was founded by Peter of Illyria in AD 425, and built over the Temple of Juno Regina to honour a martyred Roman matron.

In the 1930s, Santa Sabina was restored almost to its original condition, while retaining 9th-century additions such as the Cosmatesque work and the bell tower. Its windows are made of thin slices of selenite, a milky white mirror-like stone that the Greeks named after Selene, goddess of the moon. Twenty-four perfectly matched Corinthian columns are surmounted by arcades with marble friezes.

The church has retained its original wood-panelled doors, carved with scenes from the Bible, including one of the earliest surviving images of the Crucifixion. These are visible from the narthex, the porch-like structure in front of the church.

In the nave is the magnificent mosaic tombstone of one of the first leaders of the Dominican Order, Muñoz de Zamora (d.1300).

A place of worship for Christians since at least the 4th century, Santa Susanna’s most striking feature is its vigorous Baroque façade by Carlo Maderno, which was finished in 1603. In the nave, there are four huge frescoes by Baldassarre Croce (1558–1628), painted to resemble tapestries. These depict scenes from the life of Susanna, an obscure Roman saint who was martyred here, and the rather better-known life of the Old Testament Susanna, who was spotted bathing in her husband’s garden by two lecherous judges. Santa Susanna is the Catholic church for Americans in Rome and holds services in English every day.
column56: Churches, Temples and Shrines | VIA VENETO |

column3: Santi Ambrogio e Carlo al Corso
column4: The church of Rome’s Lombard community, Santi Ambrogio e Carlo al Corso was built in honour of two canonized bishops of Milan, Lombardy’s capital. In 1471, Pope Sixtus IV gave the Lombards a church, which they dedicated to Sant’Ambrogio, who died in 397. Then in 1610, when Carlo Borromeo was canonized, the church was rebuilt in his honour. Most of the new church was the work of father and son Onorio and Martino Longhi, but the fine tribune, cupola and stuccoes were created by Pietro da Cortona. The altarpiece by Carlo Maratta (1625–1713) is the Gloria dei Santi Ambrogio e Carlo. An ambulatory leads behind the altar to a chapel housing the heart of San Carlo in a richly decorated reliquary.
column56: Churches, Temples and Shrines | PIAZZA DI SPAGNA |

column4: Originally constructed in the 6th century, Santi Apostoli was rebuilt in the 15th century by popes Martin V Colonna and Sixtus IV della Rovere, whose oak tree crest decorates the capitals of the church’s late 15th-century portico. Inside the portico, on the left, is Canova’s 1807 memorial to the engraver Giovanni Volpato. The church itself contains a much larger monument by Canova, his Tomb of Clement XIV (1789). The Baroque interior by Francesco and Carlo Fontana was completed in 1714. Note the 3-D effect of Giovanni Odazzi’s painted Rebel Angels, who really look as though they are falling from the sky. A huge 18th-century altarpiece by Domenico Muratori shows the martyrdom of the apostles James and Philip, whose tombs are in the crypt.

The Santi Bonifacio e Alessio is dedicated to two early Christian martyrs whose remains lie under the church’s main altar. Legend has it that Alessio, the son of a rich senator living on the site, fled east to avoid an impending marriage and became a pilgrim. Returning home after many years, he died as a servant, unrecognized, under the staircase of the family’s entrance hall, clutching the manuscript of his story for posterity. The original 5th-century church has undergone many changes over time. Particularly noteworthy are the 18th-century façade with its five arches, the restored Cosmati doorway and pavement, and the magnificent Romanesque five-storey bell tower (1217). An 18th-century Baroque chapel by Andrea Bergondi houses part of the famous staircase. Other relics include the well from Alessio’s family home and the glowing Byzantine Madonna of the Intercession brought from Damascus to Rome at the end of the 10th century.
column56: AVENTINE |

column4: Home to many artistic gems, Santi Domenico e Sisto has a tall, slender Baroque façade rising above a steep flight of steps. This divides into two curving flights that sweep up to the terrace in front of the entrance. The pediment of the façade is crowned by eight flaming candlesticks. The church’s interior has a vaulted ceiling with a large fresco of The Apotheosis of St Dominic by Domenico Canuti (1620–84). The first chapel on the right was decorated by Bernini, who may also have designed the sculpture of Mary Magdalene meeting the risen Christ in the Garden of Gethsemane. This fine marble group was executed by Antonio Raggi (1649). Above the altar is a 15th-century terracotta plaque of the Virgin and Child. On the left over a side altar is a large painting of the Madonna from the same period, attributed to Benozzo Gozzoli (1420–97), a pupil of Fra Angelico.
column56: QUIRINAL |

column4:
Dedicated to two martyred Roman officers whose house originally stood on this site, Santi Giovanni e Paolo is made up of a series of buildings, including a frescoed nymphaeum dating from the 1st to the 4th centuries.

Giovanni (John) and Paolo (Paul) had served the first Christian emperor, Constantine. When they were later called to arms by the pagan emperor Julian the Apostate, they refused and were beheaded and buried in secret in their own house in AD 362. Built towards the end of the 4th century, the church retains many elements of its original structure. The Ionic portico dates from the 12th century, and the apse and bell tower were added by Nicholas Breakspeare, the only English pope, who reigned as Adrian IV (1154–9). The base of the superb Romanesque bell tower was part of the Temple of Claudius that stood on this site. The interior of the church, which was remodelled in 1718, has granite piers and columns. A tomb slab in the nave marks the burial place of the martyrs, whose relics are preserved in an urn under the high altar. In a tiny room near the altar, a magnificent 13th-century fresco depicts the figure of Christ flanked by his Apostles (ask the sacristan to unlock the door).

Excavations beneath the church have revealed two 2nd- and 3rd-century Roman houses used as Christian burial places. These are well worth a visit. The two-storey construction, with 20 rooms and a labyrinth of corridors, has well-preserved pagan and Christian paintings. The arches to the left of the church were part of a 3rd-century street of shops.
column6: Piazza dei Santi Giovanni e Paolo 13

column4:
Originally founded for St Peter, Santi Nereo e Achilleo was later re-dedicated to the 1st-century AD eponymous martyrs. According to legend, St Peter, after escaping from prison, was fleeing the city when he lost a bandage from his wounds. The original church was founded here in the 4th century, on the spot where the bandage fell.

Re-dedicated to St Nereus and St Achilleus, the church was restored at the end of the 16th century, and it retains many medieval features, including some fine 9th-century mosaics on the triumphal arch. A magnificent pulpit rests on an enormous porphyry pedestal which was found nearby in the Baths of Caracalla. The walls of the side aisles are decorated with grisly 16th-century frescoes by Niccolò Pomarancio, showing in clinical detail how each of the Apostles was martyred.
column56: CARACALLA |

column4: A fortified convent known for its magnificent frescoes, Santi Quattro Coronati’s name (Four Crowned Saints) refers to four Christian soldiers martyred after refusing to worship a pagan god. For centuries it was the bastion of the pope’s residence, the Lateran Palace. Its high apse looms over the houses below, while a Carolingian tower dominates the entrance. Erected in the 4th century AD, it was rebuilt after the invading Normans set fire to the neighbourhood in 1084. Hidden within is the garden of the delightful inner cloister (admission on request), one of the earliest of its kind, built c.1220. The remains of medieval frescoes can be seen in the Chapel of Santa Barbara, but the convent’s main feature is the Chapel of St Sylvester – its remarkable frescoes (1246) recount the legend of the conversion to Christianity of Emperor Constantine by Pope Sylvester I (reigned 314–35), then living as a hermit on Monte Soratte, north of Rome. Stricken by the plague, Constantine is prescribed a bath of children’s blood, to the horror of the matrons of Rome. Unable to bring himself to obey, Constantine is visited in a dream by St Peter and St Paul. They advise him to find Sylvester, who cures him and baptizes him. The final scene shows the emperor kneeling before the pope. The implied idea of the pope as heir to the Roman Empire would affect the whole course of medieval European history.
column56: LATERAN |

column4: Overlooking the famous Trevi Fountain, Santi Vincenzo e Anastasio has one of the most over-the-top Baroque façades in Rome. Its thickets of columns are crowned by the huge coat of arms of Cardinal Raimondo Mazzarino, who commissioned Martino Longhi the Younger to build the church in 1650. The female bust above the door is of one of the cardinal’s famous nieces, either Louis XIV’s first love, Maria Mancini (1639–1715), or her younger sister, Ortensia. In the apse, memorial plaques record the popes whose praecordia (a part of the heart) are enshrined behind the wall. This gruesome tradition was started at the end of the 16th century by Pope Sixtus V and continued until Pius X stopped it in the early 20th century.
column56: QUIRINAL |

column4: In the 16th century, Santissima Trinità dei Pellegrini was donated to a charitable organization founded by San Filippo Neri to care for the poor and sick, in particular the thousands of paupers who flocked in pilgrimage to Rome during the special holy years known as Jubilees. The church’s 18th-century façade has niches with statues of the Evangelists by Bernardino Ludovisi. The interior, with Corinthian columns, ends in a horseshoe vault and apse dominated by Guido Reni’s striking altarpiece of the Holy Trinity (1625). The frescoes in the lantern are also by Reni. Other interesting paintings include St Gregory the Great Freeing Souls from Purgatory, by Baldassarre Croce (third chapel to the left); Cavalier d’Arpino’s Virgin and Saints (second chapel to the left); and a painting by Borgognone (1677) of the Virgin and recently canonized saints, including San Filippo Neri. In the sacristy are depictions of the nobility washing the feet of pilgrims, a custom which was started by San Filippo.
column56: CAMPO DE’ FIORI |

column4: Built on the site of a church erected by King Ine of Wessex, who died in Rome in the 8th century, Santo Spirito in Sassia is the work of Antonio da Sangallo the Younger. It was rebuilt (1538–44) after the Sack of Rome had left it in ruins in 1527. The façade was added under Pope Sixtus V (1585–90). The nave and side chapels are decorated with a series of light, lively frescoes. The pretty bell tower is earlier, dating from the reign of Sixtus IV (1471–84). It was probably the work of the pope’s architect, Baccio Pontelli, who also built the Hospital of Santo Spirito, and the Ponte Sisto further down the River Tiber.
column56: Churches, Temples and Shrines | VATICAN |
column249: Ponte Sisto, Hospital of Santo Spirito

column4:
Santo Stefano Rotondo’s unusual circular shape is thought to indicate one of two things – that it was built over Nero’s round Macellum Magnum (meat market), or that it was designed to imitate Jerusalem’s Church of the Holy Sepulchre. Whatever the case, the structure is known to be one of Rome’s earliest churches, built between 468 and 483.

The round inner area is surrounded by concentric corridors with 22 supporting Ionic columns. The high drum in the centre is 22 m (72 ft) high and just as wide. It is lit by 22 high windows, a few of them restored or blocked by restorations carried out under Pope Nicholas V (reigned 1447–55), who consulted the Florentine architect Leon Battista Alberti. The archway in the centre may have been added during this period. In the 16th century, the church’s walls were frescoed by Niccolò Pomarancio, with particularly gruesome illustrations of the martyrdom of innumerable saints. Some of the medieval decor remains: in the first chapel to the left of the entrance is a 7th-century mosaic of Christ with San Primo and San Feliciano.
column249: Ponte Sisto, Hospital of Santo Spirito

column4: A cool young crowd frequents Saponeria, where the music ranges from pop to house.

column4: The chef at Sapori del Lord Byron is known for his talent for creating works of art out of classic Italian cuisine, and inventive new dishes. The elegant restaurant is located inside one of Rome’s most exclusive small hotels, and is a great place for celebrity-spotting.
column6: Via Giuseppe de Notaris 5, Hotel Lord Byron
