column4: Jazz fans shouldn’t miss the warm and cosy Saxophone Pub, situated close to the Vatican. Enjoy the simple pub grub here, including salads and sandwiches, while listening to jazz and blues – either on the sound system, or played live by local bands who come here to jam.
column52: Cafés and Bars, Entertainment and Nightlife
column56: Trastevere and Prati | Live Music Venues | Nightlife |
column63: There’s live music every Friday night at this cheerfully chaotic pub.

column4:
Scala Santa and Sancta Sanctorum, two surviving parts of the old Lateran Palace, are today located in a building designed by Domenico Fontana (1589) on the east side of Piazza di San Giovanni in Laterano.

One is the holy staircase, the Scala Santa. The 28 steps, said to be those that Christ ascended in Pontius Pilate’s house during his trial, are thought to have been brought from Jerusalem by St Helena, mother of Emperor Constantine. This belief, however, cannot be traced back any earlier than the 7th century. The steps were moved to their present site by Pope Sixtus V (reigned 1585–90) when the old Lateran Palace was destroyed. No foot may touch the holy steps, so they are covered by wooden boards. They may only be climbed by the faithful on their knees, a penance that is performed especially on Good Friday. In the vestibule there are various 19th-century sculptures, including an Ecce Homo by Giosuè Meli (1874).

The Scala Santa and two side stairways lead to the Chapel of St Lawrence, or Sancta Sanctorum (Holy of Holies), built by Pope Nicholas III in 1278. Decorated with fine Cosmatesque marble-work, the chapel contains many important relics, the most precious being an image of Jesus – the Acheiropoeton, or “picture painted without hands” – said to be the work of St Luke, with the help of an angel. In medieval times, it was taken on procession to ward off the plague.

On the walls and in the vault, restoration work has revealed 13th-century frescoes, which, for 500 years, had been covered by later paintings. The frescoes, representing the legends of St Nicholas, St Lawrence, St Agnes and St Paul, show signs of the style that would characterize the frescoes of Giotto in Assisi, made a few years later.
column6: Piazza di San Giovanni in Laterano 14
column52: Religious Buildings, Historic Sights and Landmarks
column56: LATERAN |

column4: Scuderie del Quirinale houses some of the best temporary art exhibitions in Italy. The building started life as stables for the nearby Palazzo del Quirinale, and was built in the early 1700s by Ferdinando Fuga over the remains of the ancient Temple of Serapis. The stables were remodelled by Gae Aulenti at the end of the 20th century.
column39: Admission charge
column56: QUIRINAL |
column63: An exhibit dedicated to one of Mexico’s most famous painters, Frida Kahlo, features 40 of her masterpieces borrowed from important public and private collections around the world. Visitors can explore the entire span of her artistic career, including some of her best-known self-portraits, such as Self-Portrait in a Velvet Dress.
column249: Palazzo delle Esposizioni, Museo d’Arte Contemporanea di Roma, MAXXI (National Museum of 21st Century Arts)

column4: At one time, Sette Sale supplied vast quantities of water to the Baths of Trajan, which were built for Emperor Trajan in AD 104 on parts of the Domus Aurea that had been damaged by a fire. A set of stairs leads down into the cistern, well below street level. There is not much to see here now, but a walk through the huge, echoing space where light rays illuminate the watery surfaces is still an evocative experience. The nine sections, 30 m (98 ft) long and 5 m (16 ft) wide, had a capacity of eight million litres (two million gal).
column56: Ancient Sites | ESQUILINE |
column249: Colle Oppio, Baths of Caracalla, Baths of Diocletian

column4: Great-looking, great-tasting food is the hallmark of Settembrini’s talented chef, Gigi Nastri. The highlight of the creative Italian menu is the seafood.
Simple food served with a smile sums up old-fashioned Settimio al Pellegrino, a popular local haunt. Just knock if you find the door closed, and the chances are you won’t leave hungry.
Top-notch Roman classics with a modern twist, lovely wines and outdoor seating make Settimio all’Arancio a popular choice with locals and visitors alike.

column4: Simotti Rocchi is packed with Greek, Etruscan and Roman antiquities, from coins to vases to statuary – and all at a fraction of the price auction-goers pay (simple coins or terracotta heads start at around €75).
column56: Around the Pantheon | Shops | Shopping |

column4: Historic Sora Lella, which has been in the same family for generations, serves delicious Roman classics, though the portions are small by Italian standards. This is the only restaurant on Tiber Island (sadly, no river views). Watch out for the low wood-beam ceilings.
Sorpasso is all about Mediterranean cuisine. Check out the deli counter and pick up some mouthwatering picnic ingredients. The atmosphere is laid-back.

column3: Sotterranei di San Paolo alla Regola
column4: Sotterranei di San Paolo alla Regola, the remains of a perfectly preserved ancient Roman house dating from the 2nd–3rd centuries, is hidden away behind an old palace. At present, it is only possible to visit the ruins by special arrangement, though restoration work is being carried out in order to open the site to the public. A ramp leads down well below today’s street level to reveal the locations of ancient shops. One level above is the Stanza della Colonna, at one time an open courtyard, with traces of frescoes and mosaics on its walls.
column6: Via di San Paolo alla Regola
column52: Ancient Ruins, Historic Sights and Landmarks
column56: CAMPO DE’ FIORI |

column4:
The elegant, off-centre Spanish Steps are Rome’s most beloved Rococo monument. They are at their most memorable in May, when they are covered in azaleas, but all year round they are littered with people drinking in la dolce vita (sweet life) and musicians strumming guitars until late into the night.

In the 17th century, the French owners of Trinità dei Monti decided to link the church with Piazza di Spagna by building a magnificent new flight of steps. They also planned to place an equestrian statue of King Louis XIV at the top. Pope Alexander VII Chigi was not too happy at the prospect of erecting a statue of a French monarch in the papal city, and the arguments continued until the 1720s when an Italian architect, Francesco de Sanctis, produced a design that satisfied both parties. The steps, completed in 1726, combine straight sections, curves and terraces to create one of the city’s most dramatic and distinctive landmarks.
column6: Scalinata della Trinità dei Monti, Piazza di Spagna
column54: Spanish Steps Rome | Rome Spanish Steps
column55: The Spanish Steps in Rome climb to the Trinità dei Monti church. Plan your trip to Rome’s Spanish Steps with DK Trip Planner today.
column249: Babington’s Tea Room, Antico Caffè Greco, Colonna dell’Immacolata, Keats-Shelley Memorial House

column4: Set inside an extensively renovated 10th-century synagogue, the family-run Spirito Divino makes for a memorable dining experience. The owner delights in describing each exquisite and elaborate dish on the ever-changing menu to every guest himself, while his wife lovingly prepares them in the kitchen. Take a peek into the 2,100-year-old wine cellar, where a famous ancient sculpture, now in the Vatican collection, was found.
column54: Spirito Divino Rome | Visit Spirito Divino Restaurant
column55: Set inside a renovated tenth-century synagogue, Spirito Divino Restaurant has a wine cellar over 2,000 years old. Plan a visit to Spirito Divino here.

column4:
The centre of the Roman Catholic faith and the largest church in the world, St Peter’s draws pilgrims from all over the globe. Few are disappointed when they enter the sumptuously decorated basilica beneath Michelangelo’s vast dome.

A shrine was erected on the site of St Peter’s tomb in the 2nd century and the first great basilica, ordered by Emperor Constantine, was completed around AD 349. By the 15th century it was falling down, so in 1506 Pope Julius II laid the first stone of a new church. It took more than a century to build and all the great architects of the Roman Renaissance and Baroque had a hand in its design. It was finally completed in 1626.

The vast basilica’s 187-m- (615-ft-) long, marble-encrusted interior contains 11 chapels and 45 altars, and a wealth of precious works of art. Some were salvaged from the original basilica and others commissioned from late Renaissance and Baroque artists, but much of the elaborate decoration is owed to Bernini’s mid-17th-century work. The building’s central focus is the Papal Altar beneath Bernini’s great baldacchino, filling the space between the four piers that support the dome.

column4: The classy Stravinsky Bar is one of Rome’s most exclusive evening venues. Sip an impeccably prepared dry martini in the bar’s outdoor space, part of the enchanting garden of the Hotel de Russie.

column4:
The southern tip of the Capitoline is called the Tarpeian Rock (Rupe Tarpea), after Tarpeia, the young daughter of Spurius Tarpeius, defender of the Capitol during the 8th-century BC Sabine War.

The Sabines, bent on vengeance for the rape of their women by Romulus and his men, bribed Tarpeia to let them up on to the Capitol. As the Roman historian Livy records, the Sabines wore heavy gold bracelets and jewelled rings on their left hands, and Tarpeia’s reward for her treachery was to be “what they wore on their shield-arms”. The Sabines kept to the letter of the bargain if not to its spirit – they repaid Tarpeia not with their jewellery but by crushing her to death between their shields. Tarpeia was possibly the only casualty of her act of treachery – as the invading warriors met the Roman defenders, the Sabine women leapt between the two opposing armies, forcing reconciliation. Traitors and other condemned criminals were subsequently executed by being thrown over the sheer face of Tarpeian Rock.

The site has been considered dangerous and used to be fenced off, but restoration work is now under way.
column6: Via di Monte Caprino and Via del Tempio di Giove
column56: Ancient Sites | CAPITOL |

column4: Taverna Angelica is a cosy and popular restaurant producing creative seafood and meat specialities. The Sunday lunches are superb.

The whole family pitches in at Taverna dei Fori Imperiali, making this inviting trattoria a favourite with locals and tourists alike. The burrata (Italian cheese made from mozzarella and cream) ravioli is heavenly.
Taverna Trilussa is a bustling yet elegant traditional Roman restaurant where some lucky diners are served their pasta in the pan in which it was cooked.

One of the city’s most important theatres, the Teatro Argentina was founded by the powerful Sforza Cesarini family in 1732, though the façade dates from a century later.

Many famous operas, including those of Verdi, were first performed here. In 1816, the theatre saw the ill-fated début of Rossini’s Barber of Seville, during which the composer insulted the unappreciative audience, who then pursued him, enraged, through the streets of Rome.
column29:
Winter: 10am–2pm & 3pm–7pm Tue–Sat (in the absence of a show)

column4:
Opened in 1880, the Teatro dell’Opera is Rome’s prime opera venue. Critics rightly argue that Rome’s opera is not up to the standard of Milan’s La Scala or Naples’s San Carlo, but it still attracts world-class singers, mainly in premières or solo recitals.

Teatro dell’Opera concentrates on staging the great operas rather than experimental productions. In the summer months the theatre moves outdoors to stage opera and ballet in the ancient Baths of Caracalla; the acoustics are not perfect, but the unique setting more than makes up for it.
column54: Teatro dell Opera Rome | Rome Teatro dell Opera
column55: The Teatro dell Opera is Rome’s premier opera venue, with an outdoors stage for the summer. Plan your visit to Teatro dell Opera today with DK Trip Planner.
column63: Composed by Gioachino Rossetti in 1820 for Naples’ Teatro di San Carlo, with libretto by Cesare della Valle, Maometto II is set during the war between the Turks and the Venetians in the 15th century. It follows the political and romantic intrigues surrounding Mehmed the Conqueror, a Turkish sultan.
column72: Based on the legendary Spanish novel Don Quixote by Miguel de Cervantes, the students of the Scuola di Danza perform a ballet in three acts following the misguided adventures of the title character. The performance is directed by Laura Comi, with choreography by Marius Petipa and music by Ludwig Minkus.
column81: Choreographer Micha van Hoecke was inspired to create a ballet using the “danceable” pieces by Giuseppe Verdi, from his operas Jerusalem Delivered, Macbeth, Sicilian Vespers and others. Directed by David Garforth, Verdi Danse stars Dinu Tamazlacaru, Alessandra Amato, Gaia Straccamore, Riccardo Di Cosmo, Manuel Paruccini and Alessandro Tiburzi.
column90: Georges Bizet’s masterpiece, Carmen, is an opèra-comique in four acts with libretto by Henri Meilhac and Ludovic Halévy, based on the novel by Prosper Merimée. Directed by Emmanuel Villaume and Emilio Sagi, the Teatro dell’Opera’s orchestra and chorus perform alongside an international cast in collaboration with the Teatro de Santiago de Chile.
column99: “The Elixir of Love” is a comic opera in two acts, with music by Gaetano Donizetti and libretto by Felice Romani, based on the libretto by Eugène Scribe for Auber’s Le Philtre. The story follows a peasant who tries to win over a rich landowner with a magic love potion.
column108: The classic fairy tale Sleeping Beauty comes alive to Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky’s score in the ballet in four acts. Directed by David Garforth and choreographed by Paul Chalmer, the ballet stars Jurgita Dronina, Gaia Straccamore and Alessandra Amato as Princess Aurora alongside the Teatro dell’Opera’s ballet corps.
column117: With music by Russian composer Sergei Prokofiev, the classic rags-to-riches tale Cinderella is performed by the Teatro dell’Opera’s ballet corps and orchestra, directed by Nir Kabaretti and choreographed by David Bintley.
column126: Based on Victor Hugo’s play Le Roi s’amuse, the opera Rigoletto is a melodrama in three acts with music by Giuseppe Verdi and libretto by Francesco Maria Piave. Commissioned by the famous opera house La Fenice in Venice, it had a wildly successful premiere in 1851.

column4: Founded in 1867, Tebro is a department store that specializes in luxury bed linens, towels and lingerie. A made-to-measure service is also available.
column56: The Spanish Steps and Villa Borghese | Specialist Shops | Shopping |

column4:
Occupying a 20th-century house in the grounds of Villa Torlonia’s lush gardens, Technotown is a multimedia playhouse with fun and educational interactive exhibits covering new technologies like robotics and 3D photography.

Highlights include Sbong!, a virtual ball game, and Adventures in 3D, where visitors get to experience a tsunami in three dimensions before going on a 3D space trip in which challenges include flying between the rings of Saturn and avoiding falling into a black hole. The three-dimensional antics continue at Scultorobot – an imaging device that can take a photo, rotate it to show it in profile and finally sculpt it in polystyrene. Visitors are also given the chance to get hands-on experience with new materials, such as metals with memory and elastic foam, before finding out how to make superheroes fly and magicians disappear on a virtual film set.
column31: Mon, 25 Dec, 1 Jan, 1 May, 12 Aug–26 Aug
column38: Tours compulsory; check the website for details

column4: Tucked away behind a gate in a little courtyard alongside San Pietro in Montorio lies the Tempietto, or “little temple”, considered by many to be the first true Renaissance building in Rome. The Tempietto was built by Bramante in 1501 on the site where St Peter was believed to have been crucified. It is a perfectly circular Doric temple whose design and proportions adhere precisely to those laid down by the ancient Roman architectural writer Vitruvius. His book, De Architettura, describing Roman buildings and building techniques, became the driving force behind the revival of Classical architecture during the Renaissance. The Tempietto was the first building to be based entirely on these principles.
column6: Piazza San Pietro in Montorio (in courtyard)
column52: Historic Sights and Landmarks, Religious Buildings
column56: JANICULUM |

column4: Tempio di Iside serves fish of all kinds, much of it raw, including several varieties of oysters, in a romantic, candlelit interior with exposed brickwork.

The Temple of Hadrian honours the emperor as a god and was dedicated by his adoptive son and successor Emperor Antoninus Pius in AD 145.

The remains of the temple are visible on the southern side of Piazza di Pietra, incorporated into a 17th-century building that was originally a papal customs house, completed by Carlo Fontana and his son in the 1690s.

Eleven marble Corinthian columns, 15 m (49 ft) high, stand on a base of peperino, a volcanic rock quarried from the Alban hills to the south of Rome. The columns decorated the northern flank of the temple enclosing its inner shrine, the cella. The peperino wall of the cella is still visible behind the columns, as is part of the coffered portico ceiling.

A number of reliefs from the temple, representing conquered Roman provinces, are now in the courtyard of the Palazzo dei Conservatori. They reflect the mostly peaceful foreign policy of Hadrian’s reign.

The Temple of Jupiter, the most important in ancient Rome, was founded in honour of the arch-god around 509 BC on the southern summit of the Capitoline Hill.

From the few traces that remain, archaeologists have been able to reconstruct the rectangular, Greek appearance of the temple as it once stood. In places you can see remnants of its particularly Roman feature, the podium. Most of this lies beneath the Museo Nuovo wing of the Palazzo dei Conservatori.

By walking around the site, from the podium’s south-western corner in Via del Tempio di Giove to its south-eastern corner in Piazzale Caffarelli, you can see that the temple was about the same size as the Pantheon.
column56: Churches, Temples and Shrines | CAPITOL |

column4:
The miraculously well-preserved Republican Temples of the Forum Boarium are particularly appealing by moonlight, in their grassy enclave under the umbrella pines beside the Tiber.

They date from the 2nd century BC and were saved for posterity when they were re-consecrated as Christian churches in the Middle Ages. They offer rare examples of combined elements from Greek and Roman architecture.

The rectangular temple (formerly known as the Temple of Fortuna Virilis) was in fact dedicated to Portunus, the god of rivers and ports – a reference to the nearby port of ancient Rome. Set on a podium, it has four Ionic travertine columns fluted at the front and 12 half-columns embedded in the tufa wall of the cella – the room that housed the image of the god.

Nearby is the small circular Temple of Hercules. It is often referred to as the Temple of Vesta because of its similarity to the one in the Forum.
column54: Forum Boarium Rome
column55: Rome’s Temples of the Forum Boarium date from the 2nd century BC, and are incredibly well preserved. Plan your visit to the Forum Boarium with DK Trip Planner.
column56: AVENTINE |

column4: One of the best Tuscan restaurants in Rome, the family-run Terra di Siena features classic seasonal recipes from the farmers around their hometown near Siena. The family imports Sienese ingredients for their hearty Tuscan dishes, such as Florentine steak and ribollita soup. Seating is in a cheerful dining room or on the buzzing piazza.

The Baths of Trajan was a vast complex built by the emperor over the ruins of the Domus Aurea between AD 104 and 109.

There were sections for women as well as men, and the baths included a theatre, a gym and reading rooms, as well as warm, cold and hot pools. Besides these structures, an intricate system of subterranean passageways was also in place to service and maintain the facilities.

In 2011, a huge mosaic showing Apollo with the Muses was found beneath the Baths of Trajan, and below that, a huge fresco known as the “painted city”. It was painted high up on the exterior wall of a house, and would have been easily visible to passers-by. It probably dates from the time of Vespasian.

The baths can only be viewed from the Parco del Colle Oppio. Walk along the perimeter to see the high curved walls of the esedra, which probably held a garden with statues, and to read the interesting information boards, which will help to make sense of the place.

The water for the baths came from a vast cistern, the Cisterne delle Sette Sale, which could store up to eight million litres (two million gal) of water. Visit by appointment, and go down into the large cistern. It is an evocative experience, especially when it has water in it and the sun’s rays cover the walls with eerie reflections.

column4:
Rome’s Borgo is where the first pilgrims to St Peter’s were housed in hostels and hospices, often for quite lengthy periods. The name derives from the German burg, meaning town.

The first of these foreign colonies, called “schools”, was founded in AD 725 by a Saxon, King Ine of Wessex, who wished to live a life of penance and to be buried near the Tomb of St Peter.

These days hotels and hostels have made the Borgo a colony of international pilgrims once again. Much of the area’s character was lost after redevelopment in the 1930s, but it is still enjoyable to stroll the old narrow streets on either side of Via della Conciliazione.

column4: Located on a narrow back street, The Library is a miniscule and romantic spot with just a few tables. The first courses, such as the risotto with fresh truffle, are excellent, as is the wine.

Built by Emperor Augustus (27 BC–AD 14), who dedicated it to his nephew and son-in-law who had died aged 19 in 23 BC, the Theatre of Marcellus has supported generations of Roman buildings. The Middle Ages were a turbulent time of invasions and local conflicts, and by the 13th century the 20,000-seater theatre had been converted into the fortress of the Savelli family. In the 16th century Baldassarre Peruzzi built a great palace on the theatre ruins for the Orsini family. This included a garden that faced the Tiber. The lower arches were later occupied by humble dwellings and workshops. Close to the theatre stand three beautiful Corinthian columns and a section of frieze. These are from the Temple of Apollo, which housed many great works of art that the Romans had plundered from Greece in the 2nd century BC.

column4: Still evident in the curve of medieval buildings on Largo del Pollaro is the 61–55 BC Theatre of Pompey. Its fabric is visible only in the basements, including the downstairs rooms of the da Pancrazio restaurant in the ancient travertine corridors.

column4:
Since 293 BC, when a temple was dedicated here to Aesculapius, the god of healing and protector against the plague, Tiber Island has been associated with the sick, and there is still a hospital here.

In ancient times the island, which lay opposite the city’s port, had large structures of white travertine at either end, built to resemble the stern and prow of a ship. San Bartolomeo all’Isola, the church in the island’s central piazza, still stands and was built on the ruins of the Temple of Aesculapius in the 10th century. Its Romanesque bell tower is clearly visible from across the river. From the Ghetto area you can reach the island by a footbridge, the Ponte Fabricio. The oldest original bridge over the Tiber still in use, it was built in 62 BC. In medieval times two powerful families, the Pierleoni and then the Caetani, controlled this strategic point by means of a tower, still in situ. The other bridge to the island, the Ponte Cestio, is inscribed with the names of the Byzantine emperors associated with its restoration in AD 370.

Today,Tiber Island houses two hospitals and hosts a popular summer festival.
column52: Religious Buildings, Historic Sights and Landmarks
column62: Seasonal and Outside, Food and Drink, Theatre and Film
column63: One of the venues of the “Roman Summer” festival, the lower banks and island of the Tiber are set up with makeshift pizzerias, restaurants and bars, and stalls that stay open late into the night selling clothes, jewelry, decorations and food products. An open-air cinema on Tiber Island screens films nightly.

column4:
A fun and educational attraction, the Time Elevator is a multimedia cinema that presents 3,000 years of Roman history using vivid technology. The multisensory experience takes visitors on a palpable journey through time, right from the days of Rome’s foundation, through the glorious days of the ancient Roman Empire, up to the period of the Renaissance with its masterpieces of architecture and art. The high-adrenaline trip culminates in a virtual aerial flight over the Rome of today.

The flight simulator has three panoramic screens with seats on special moving platforms, and individual surround-sound headsets which bring alive events such as the legend of Romulus and Remus, and the betrayal of Julius Caesar at the hands of Brutus, and virtually reconstruct historic Roman monuments such as the Colosseum and the Baths of Caracalla. Special effects simulate the sensation of winds blowing, water dripping and mice nibbling at your toes!
column52: Family Friendly, Art Galleries and Museums
column54: Time Elevator Rome | Visit Time Elevator in Rome
column55: Rome’s Time Elevator is a multimedia cinema that presents over 3,000 years of Roman history as a show. Plan your trip to the Time Elevator today.

column4:
One of the most famous landmarks on the Via Appia Antica is the huge Tomb of Cecilia Metella, the resting place of a noblewoman about whom very little is known. We do know that her father and husband were rich patricians and successful generals of late Republican Rome. Lord Byron muses over her unknown destiny in his poem Childe Harold.

In 1302 Pope Boniface VIII donated the tomb to his family, the Caetani. They incorporated it into a fortified castle that blocked the Via Appia, allowing them to control the traffic on the road and exact high tolls. The marble facing of the tomb was pillaged by another pope, Sixtus V, at the end of the 16th century. On the opposite side of the road stands what remains of the early 14th-century church of San Nicola.
column56: FURTHER AFIELD |
column249: Mausoleum of Augustus, Columbarium of Pomponius Hylas, Pyramid of Caius Cestius, Tomb of the Scipios

column4:
Discovered in 1780, the Tomb of the Scipios contained various sarcophagi, statues and niches with terracotta burial urns. Many of the originals have now been moved to the Vatican Museums and copies stand in their place.

The Scipios were a family of conquering generals. Southern Italy, Corsica, Algeria, Spain and Asia Minor all fell to their victorious Roman armies. The most famous of these generals was Publius Cornelius Scipio Africanus, who defeated the great Carthaginian general Hannibal at the Battle of Zama in 202 BC. Scipio Africanus himself was not buried here in the family tomb, but at Liternum near Naples, where he owned a favourite villa. The earliest sarcophagus that was found in the Tomb of the Scipios was that of Cornelius Scipio Barbatus, consul in 298 BC, for whom the tomb was built. Members of his illustrious family continued to be buried here up to the middle of the 2nd century BC. Excavations in the area have revealed a columbarium similar to that of Pomponius Hylas, a Christian catacomb and a three-storey house dating from the 3rd century AD that was built over the Tomb of the Scipios.

column4: Built by Borromini to decorate one corner of the Convent of the Oratorians of San Filippo Neri in 1647–9, the Torre dell’ Orologio is typical of its maker with its concave front and rear and convex sides. The mosaic of the Madonna beneath the clock is by Pietro da Cortona, while on the corner of the building is a small tabernacle to the Madonna flanked by angels in the style of Bernini.

column4: Located in the Roman Forum, the Torre delle Milizie was thought to have been the one in which Nero stood watching Rome burn, after he had set it alight to clear the city’s slums. It is uncertain whether arson was among Nero’s crimes, but it is certain that he did not watch the fire from this tower – it was built in the 13th century.
column56: Historic Buildings, Streets and Piazzas | FORUM |

column4:
Created in AD 113 to celebrate two victorious Roman campaigns in Dacia (present-day Romania), Trajan’s Column, together with its base and pedestal, is 40 m (131 ft) high, precisely the height of the spur of the Quirinal Hill that was cut away to make room for Trajan’s Forum. Considered to represent Roman sculptural art at its peak, the column is decorated with intricate carvings, spiralling upwards and telling the stories of the campaigns. They are so full of detail that some archaeologists think they may have been based on Trajan’s own war diary. It is not just battles that are depicted, but the realities of life at war for both Romans and Dacians.

The Romans are shown arriving in Dacia with their supplies in boats, building a camp, cutting down trees, sinking wells and constructing huts. Battle scenes show the Dacians being attacked, as well as Dacian attacks on the Romans, and even the aftermath of a battle. After the first campaign, the Dacians continued to resist, before the Romans attacked a walled town and set fire to it. The carvings also show a Dacian priest distributing poison to those who prefered to die than be conquered. It is extremely difficult to see these scenes from the ground, which makes one wonder how the Romans would have been able to see it. Standing on the upper floor of the two libraries that flanked the column would have made some of the scenes visible, but there would still have been sections that were out of sight. Today, the best way to see the column in detail is to watch animated films in Palazzo Valentini or take the metro out to EUR in southern Rome to see casts at eye level.

Along with the intricate detail on the outside, the column is pierced with small windows to illuminate its internal spiral staircase (closed to the public). The column’s survival was largely thanks to the intervention of Pope Gregory the Great (reigned 590–604). He was so moved by a relief showing Trajan helping a woman whose son had been killed that he begged God to release the emperor’s soul from hell. God duly appeared to the pope to say that Trajan had been rescued, but asked him not to pray for the souls of any more pagans. According to legend, when Trajan’s ashes were exhumed his skull and tongue were not only intact, but his tongue told of his release from hell. The land around the column was then declared sacred and the column itself was spared. The statue of Trajan remained on top of the column until 1587, when it was replaced with one of St Peter.

The rich archaeological zone of Trajan’s Markets, rudely intruded upon by Mussolini’s Via dei Fori Imperiali, contains some of the most grandiose and noteworthy of Rome’s ancient remains.

Trajan’s Markets were the world’s first shopping mall, a complex of 150 shops laid out on five levels. Built in the 2nd century AD, the markets had shops that sold everything from fish – kept alive in fresh- and salt-water tanks – to spices, fruit, flowers, wine, oil and fabrics. The dour, red-brick complex is well preserved, with a main hall, a paved street with shops opening off it, and a three-storey crescent containing yet more shops.

Dominating the area is the mighty shell of the Colosseum, constructed in AD 72–80 under the Flavian emperors and originally known as the Flavian Amphitheatre. The quarter also holds other Imperial wonders, such as the Arch of Constantine, the gigantic fora of various emperors, most notably Trajan’s, and the 1st-century AD folly of Nero’s Golden House, now a subterranean revelation of Roman interior design. The Comune di Roma is constantly working on excavating the area and new discoveries are made every year. Since August 1013, most of Via dei Fori Imperiali is closed to traffic to allow visitors to walk around the site undisturbed.

column4: A friendly, intimate restaurant, Trattoria Monti serves creative dishes from the Marche region. The day’s specials, all featuring seasonal ingredients, are explained in detail by the brothers who own this heavenly spot. The tagliatelle con ragù is excellent and the house wine is above average. Book in advance.

Right on Piazza Navona, historic Tre Scalini is renowned for its delectable chocolate tartufo (truffle) ice cream ball. The decadent home-made dessert consists of an outer layer of chocolate ice cream with a heart of fudge and cherries, all covered in dark chocolate shavings.

column4:
Built in the flamboyant Rococo style, the Trevi Fountain is one of Rome’s most familiar sites. Too often the fountain is thronged by tourists, yet the sheer beauty and power of this creation are nevertheless overwhelming, day or night.

Most visitors gathering around the Trevi assume that it has always been here, but by the standards of the Eternal City it is a fairly recent creation. Nicola Salvi’s theatrical design for Rome’s largest and most famous fountain was completed only in 1762. The central figures are Neptune, flanked by two Tritons.

The fountain’s waters come from the Acqua Vergine, a Roman aqueduct built in 19 BC and fed by springs 22 km (14 miles) from the city; one of the first-storey reliefs shows a young girl (the legendary virgin after whom the aqueduct was named) pointing towards the springs.

Most visitors to the Trevi come with coins ready for tossing in – backwards – to ensure they return to Rome.

column4: Crowning the French-commissioned Spanish Steps, Trinità dei Monti was part of a convent founded by Louis XII in 1503, but the views of Rome from the platform in front of the twin bell-towered façade are so beautiful that the church itself is often ignored. It is, however, unusual for Rome, for it was founded by the French in 1495, and although it was later badly damaged, there are still traces of attractive late Gothic latticework in the vaults of the transept. The twin-towered façade (1584) is by Giacomo della Porta; the double staircase (1587) by Domenico Fontana. The Baroque interior has three chapels. The interconnecting side chapels are decorated with Mannerist paintings, including two fine works by Daniele da Volterra. A pupil of Michelangelo, Volterra had to paint clothes on the nudes in the Last Judgment in the Sistine Chapel, in response to the objections of Pope Pius IV, earning the artist the nickname “Il Braghettone” (the breeches-maker). Michelangelo’s influence is obvious in the powerfully muscled bodies shown in the Deposition (second chapel on the left). The circles of gesturing figures and dancing angels surrounding the Virgin Mary in the Assumption (third chapel on the right) include a portrait of his teacher Michelangelo as the far right figure, but this painting actually has more in common with the graceful style of Raphael.

column4: An ever-popular pub off the Corso, Trinity College serves tasty food upstairs and has a standard bar downstairs. Stepping inside the two-floored pub is like entering a time-warp that lands you up in Ireland. It can get very noisy and packed, but it always stays cheerful.

column4:
The Vatican City, home of the papacy since 1377 and the centre of Catholicism, contains a stunning collection of sights, including St Peter’s basilica, the Sistine Chapel and some 10 museums.

The Vatican is the world’s smallest country, covering just 0.3 sq km (0.2 sq miles), and is a theocracy of around 1,000 citizens ruled by the pope. There is a post office and shops, the Vatican radio station, broadcasting to the world in over 20 languages, a daily newspaper (L’Osservatore Romano), Vatican offices and a publishing house. The borders of the nation are marked by the walls that encircle the papal palaces and gardens, the colonnade that surrounds Piazza San Pietro and by a white line between the end of the piazza and the beginning of Via della Conciliazione. The Vatican became a sovereign state, independent of Italy, in February 1929. Decisions taken here have long shaped the destiny of Europe, and have affected the lives of Catholics throughout the world.

The great basilica of St Peter’s and Piazza San Pietro draw a large number of Christian pilgrims, many of whom come to listen to the weekly addresses delivered by the pope. The papal palaces beside St Peter’s basilica house the Vatican Museums. With the added attractions of Michelangelo’s Sistine Chapel and the Raphael Rooms, their wonderful collections of Classical sculpture make them the finest museums in Rome. The other Vatican museums include fine collections of Egyptian, Greek, Etruscan and Roman antiquities; Paleochristian, Renaissance and modern art; and a world-class ethnographic collection.

column4:
Known locally as the Passetto (small corridor), the Vatican Corridor is a long, fortified passageway built during medieval times; it was intended as a link between the Vatican and the fortress of Castel Sant’Angelo.

It constituted an escape route which could also be used to control the strategic Borgo area. Arrows and other missiles could be fired from its bastions onto the streets and houses below. The corridor was used in 1494 by Pope Alexander VI Borgia when Rome was invaded by King Charles VIII of France. In 1527, it enabled Pope Clement VII to take refuge in Castel Sant’Angelo as the troops commanded by the Constable of Bourbon began the Sack of Rome.
column52: Religious Buildings, Historic Sights and Landmarks
column56: VATICAN |

column4: The Vatican Gardens are typical 16th-century Italianate gardens of landscaped lawns, woods, grottoes and fountains. Structures include the first Vatican radio tower, designed by Marconi in 1931, Pier Luigi Nervi’s shell-shaped audience hall (1971) and the Mannerist Casina of Pius IV (1558–61), home to the Pontifical Academy of Sciences.

column4:
After four centuries of papal patronage and connoisseurship, the Vatican Museums house one of the world’s great collections of Classical and Renaissance art.

The long courtyards and galleries, linking Innocent VIII’s Belvedere Palace to the other buildings, are by Donato Bramante and were commissioned for Julius II in 1503. Most of the later additions to the buildings were made in the 18th century, when priceless works of art were first put on show. The Vatican also houses many of the great archaeological finds of central Italy, including the Laocoön group, the Apollo del Belvedere and the Etruscan bronze known as the Mars of Todi. This complex of museums houses the Sistine Chapel and the Raphael Rooms, which should not be missed.

Sistine Chapel

The walls of the Sistine Chapel, the main chapel in the Vatican Palace, were frescoed by some of the finest artists of the 15th and 16th centuries. The 12 paintings on the side walls, by artists including Perugino, Ghirlandaio, Botticelli and Signorelli, show parallel episodes from the lives of Moses and Christ. Restored in the 1980s, Michelangelo’s stunning ceiling fresco (1508–12) contains 366 figures, illustrating the biblical stories of the Creation of the World, the Fall of Man and the Coming of Christ.

Raphael Rooms

Pope Julius II’s private apartments were built above those of his hated predecessor, Alexander VI, who died in 1503. Julius was impressed with Raphael’s work and chose him to redecorate the four rooms. Raphael and his pupils began the task in 1508, replacing existing works by several better-known artists, including Raphael’s teacher, Perugino. The frescoes, which took over 16 years to complete, express the religious and philosophical ideas of the Renaissance. They quickly established Raphael’s reputation as an artist in Rome, putting him on a par with Michelangelo.

Veranda’s stunning setting in a frescoed palace with vaulted ceilings and low lighting make dining here a real experience. The selective menu offers finely-tuned pasta, meat and fish dishes.

column4: Selling hundreds of types of pens, thousands of notebooks and the very best in art supplies, Vertecchi is the queen of Rome’s stationery stores. Fancier items are stocked next door at No. 72.
column56: The Spanish Steps and Villa Borghese | Specialist Shops | Shopping |

column4:
Begun in 312 BC, Via Appia Antica was first designed as a 560-km (300-mile) road connecting Circus Maximus to the southern port of Brindisi and the Adriatic Coast. When it was extended to the ports of Benevento, Taranto and Brindisi in 190 BC, the road became Rome’s link with its expanding empire in the East. Via Appia Antica was the route taken by the funeral processions of the dictator Sulla (78 BC) and Emperor Augustus (AD 14), and it was along this road that St Paul was led, as a prisoner to Rome, in AD 56. Gradually abandoned during the Middle Ages, the road was restored by Pope Pius IV in the mid-16th century.

Today “The Queen of Roads” is lined with ruined family tombs and collective burial places known as columbaria. Important Christian sights along the way include the church of Domine Quo Vadis and the catacombs of San Callisto and San Sebastiano.
column6: Catacombs of San Callisto: Via Appia Antica 126, Catacombs of Domitilla: Via delle Sette Chiese 282, Catacombs of San Sebastiano: Via Appia Antica 136, Tomb of Cecilia Metella: Via Appia Antica 161, Parco della Caffarella office: Largo Tacchi Venturi

column4:
Known as the “Fifth Avenue” of Rome, Via dei Condotti is lined with chic shops, fashion boutiques and top-name designers.

After flirting with high street retail chains in the 1990s, the street has been re-conquered by the haute couture that made it famous. Expect everything from younger designers, such as Laura Biagiotti and the Fendi sisters, to fashion giants such as Valentino and Giorgio Armani. Stores selling shoes and other leather goods are also well represented.
column54: Via Condotti Rome | Shopping at Via dei Condotti
column55: Via dei Condotti is known as the "Fifth Avenue" of Rome, and is lined with fashion boutiques. Plan your shopping trip to Via dei Condotti with DK Trip Planner.

column4:
Named after the rosary sellers (coronari) that used to line the way when it was on the main pilgrimage route to St Peter’s, Via dei Coronari now has a reputation for antiques.

The street followed the course of the ancient Roman Via Recta (straight street), which originally ran from today’s Piazza Colonna to the Tiber. Navigating through the vast throng of people in Via dei Coronari could be extremely hazardous. In the Holy Year of 1450, some 200 pilgrims died, crushed by the crowds or drowned in the Tiber. Following the tragedy, Pope Nicholas V demolished the Roman triumphal arch that stood at the entrance to Ponte Sant’Angelo. In the late 15th century, Pope Sixtus IV encouraged the building of private houses and palaces along the street.

Although the rosary sellers have been replaced by antiques dealers, the street still has many original buildings from the 15th and 16th centuries. One of the earliest, at Nos. 156–7, is known as the House of Fiammetta, the mistress of Cesare Borgia. Via dei Coronari is at its most magical in May and October during the Mostra dell’Antiquariato, when a red carpet is thrown down, torches are lit outside the shops, and lemon and kumquat trees in pots line the street.
column54: Via dei Coronari Rome | Shopping at Via dei Coronari
column55: Via dei Coronari is a street in Rome named after the rosary sellers that used to line it. It’s now famous for antique shops. Plan your trip to Via dei Coronari here.
column63: The antique shops of Via dei Coronari open their doors until late, lay a red carpet over the cobbles and illuminate the street with torchlight. Held in the second half of May.

column4: Named after the traditional giubbotti (jackets) whose makers and sellers used to populate this street, Via dei Giubbonari is still known for its stylish clothing and down-to-earth prices. Sportswear, shoes and contemporary fashion are all available here.

column4: An imposing blend of high fashion and antiques makes Via del Babuino one of Rome’s most elegant streets. Armani, Chanel and Tiffany & Co. all have stores here, though it is worth a stroll just to peek into some of the finer antiques shops – they’re full of Baroque furniture, paintings and antiquities.

column4: Once part of the Via Papalis, the processional route leading from the Lateran to St Peter’s, Via del Governo Vecchio is lined with 15th- and 16th-century houses and small workshops. Particularly impressive are those at Nos. 104 and 106. The small palazzo at No. 123 was once thought to have been the home of Bramante. Opposite is Palazzo del Governo Vecchio, also known as Palazzo Nardini, as inscribed on the first-floor windows along with the date 1477.
column56: Historic Buildings, Streets and Piazzas | PIAZZA NAVONA |

column4:
A perfectly straight, cobbled street lined with Renaissance palaces and churches, Via Giulia was laid out in the early 16th century on the orders of Pope Julius II to link the centre of Rome with St Peter’s.

On approaching from Piazza Farnese, look out for an arch covered with creepers. This was intended to be the first arch of a viaduct designed by Michelangelo to link Palazzo Farnese with Villa Farnese on the other side of the Tiber, but it was never finished. Just below the arch is a grotesque fountain, the Mascherone. Also on the street is a church decorated with grimacing skulls, Santa Maria dell’Orazione e Morte, whose priests had the job of collecting the corpses of poor people and giving them a Christian burial. Beyond this is a huge orange building – once the city prison and the church of San Biagio della Pagnotta. The church’s patron saint is believed to have the power to cure sore throats, and people still visit to be healed by holding two candles to their throats.
column52: Religious Buildings, Shopping, Fountains and Obelisks, Historic Sights and Landmarks

column4: Located in a huge covered square, Via Mamiani Market is Rome’s largest market for the freshest foodstuffs, as well as clothing, luggage, leather goods and wine.

The cobbled Via Margutta is famous for its wonderful range of art, antiques and antiquities shops. Nos. 45 and 86 often have stunning merchandise for sale, whereas No. 109 specializes in more affordable copies of antiquities.
column54: Via Margutta Rome | Shopping at Via Margutta
column55: Via Margutta is a street in Rome famous for its antique and art shops. Plan your shopping trip to Via Margutta in Rome with DK Trip Planner today.

column4: Via Sannio Market is a good bet for new, reasonably priced leather jackets and good-condition second-hand clothing, as well as a variety of fake designer brands.

Lined in its upper reaches with exuberant hotels and canopied pavement cafés, Via Veneto is one of Rome’s best-known (and most expensive) streets.

Descending in a lazy curve from the Porta Pinciana to Piazza Barberini, the street was laid out in 1879 over a large estate sold by the Ludovisi family in the great building boom of Rome’s first years as capital of Italy. Palazzo Margherita, intended to be the new Ludovisi family palazzo, was completed in 1890. In the 1960s Via Veneto was the most glamorous street in Rome, its luxury hotels and cafés patronized by film stars and plagued by paparazzi. It had a starring role in Federico Fellini’s film La Dolce Vita (1960). At the foot of Via Veneto is the plain, unassuming church of Santa Maria della Concezione, with the haunting Capuchin Crypt catacombs located underneath.

column4: Originally the hunting reserve of King Vittorio Emanuele III, the expansive Villa Ada has rolling lawns, serene waters and copses. This is the perfect spot for those in need of an antidote to the fumes and noise of the city.

column63: Since 1994, the “Rome Meets the World” festival has taken place in Villa Ada park every summer from June to August. The nightly concerts focus on the theme of “world music” and include musicians performing a variety of styles from countries all over the world. Some Italian artists also take part.

column4:
The stunning 16th-century Villa Aldobrandini is closed to the public, but its gardens and terraces – hidden behind a high wall that runs along Via Nazionale – offer an oasis of tranquility in the centre of the city.

Built for the Dukes of Urbino and acquired for his family by Pope Clement VIII Aldobrandini (reigned 1592–1605), the villa is now government property and houses an international law library. Access to the grounds is reached through an iron gate in Via Mazzarino, where steps lead up past 2nd-century AD ruins. Gravel paths lead between formal lawns and clearly marked specimen trees, and benches are provided for the weary. Since the garden is raised some 10 m (30 ft) above street level, the views are excellent.
column6: Via Panisperna, entrance to gardens: Via Mazzarino 1
column29:
Gardens: dawn–dusk daily

Villa: closed to the public
column56: QUIRINAL |

column4:
One of Rome’s largest green spaces, the elegant Villa Borghese was designed in 1605 as a private pleasure park for Cardinal Scipione Borghese. Most of the original attractions have now gone, although there is still plenty to do in this charming Renaissance villa.

The park was the first of its kind in Rome, containing 400 newly planted pine trees, a garden sculpture by Bernini’s father, Pietro, and dramatic waterworks built by Giovanni Fontana. The layout of the formal gardens was imitated by other prominent Roman families at Villa Ludovisi and Villa Doria Pamphilj. In the early 19th century, Prince Camillo Borghese assembled the family’s magnificent art collection in the Casino Borghese, now the home of the Galleria and Museo Borghese. There are two other world-class museums within the grounds: Villa Giulia and the Galleria Nazionale d’arte Moderna. Within its 6-km (4-mile) circumference there are also foreign academies, schools of archaeology, a zoo, a riding school, a grassy amphitheatre, an artificial lake, an aviary, and an array of summerhouses, fountains, Neo-Classical statuary and exotic follies.

In the centre of the park is the Giardino del Lago, its main entrance marked by an 18th-century copy of the Arch of Septimius Severus. The garden has an artificial lake complete with an Ionic temple to Aesculapius, the god of healing, by the 18th-century architect Antonio Asprucci. Rowing boats and ducks make the lake a favourite with children; banana trees and bamboo grow around the shore, and clearings are studded with sculptures. The park is a delight to explore on two wheels: bike rental stands are scattered throughout the grounds.

column4:
Continuing a tradition that has lasted for 500 years, Villa Celimontana is Rome’s favourite picnicking spot.

The Dukes of Mattei bought this land in 1553 and transformed the vineyards that covered the hillside into a formal garden. As well as palms and other exotic trees, the garden has its own Egyptian obelisk. Villa Mattei, built in the 1580s and now known as Villa Celimontana, houses the Italian Geographical Society. The Mattei family used to open the park to the public on the day of the Visit of the Seven Churches, an annual event instituted by San Filippo Neri in 1552. Starting from the Chiesa Nuova, Romans went on foot to the city’s seven major churches and, on reaching Villa Mattei, were given bread, wine, salami, cheese, an egg and two apples.
column54: Villa Celimontana Rome | Villa Celimontana Gardens
column55: Villa Celimontana houses the Italian Geographical Society and is best known for its pretty gardens. Plan your trip to Villa Celimontana in Rome here.
column62: Seasonal and Outside, Classical and Contemporary Music
column63: Rome’s annual summer jazz festival takes place outdoors in Villa Celimontana park, close to the Colosseum. Featuring big names in Italian jazz, as well as some international artists, the concerts take place several nights a week and include the possibilty of booking a table for drinks or dinner during the show.

column4:
A vast expanse of hills, lakes and orangeries, Villa Doria Pamphilj is the largest green area in Rome. It is also one of the few places in the city where, at times, it is possible to be out of earshot of traffic.

The villa was laid out in the mid-17th century for Prince Camillo Pamphilj. His uncle, Pope Innocent X, paid for the magnificent summer residence, the Casino del Bel Respiro, and the fountains and summerhouses, some of which still survive today.
column54: Villa Doria Pamphilj Rome | Villa Doria Pamphili in Rome
column55: Villa Doria Pamphilj is the largest green space in Rome, containing hills, lakes and orangeries. Plan your visit to Villa Doria Pamphili in Rome here.
column62: Seasonal and Outside, Classical and Contemporary Music
column63: A series of outdoor concerts are held in the park every summer in the evenings.

column4:
A perfect example of Renaissance architecture, elegant Villa Farnesina was built in the early 16th century for Agostino Chigi, a wealthy banking tycoon, and served as a sophisticated retreat where he could entertain and hold magnificent banquets.

The simple, harmonious design, with a central block and projecting wings, made this one of the earliest true Renaissance villas. The decoration was carried out between 1510 and 1519 and has since been restored. The artist Peruzzi frescoed some of the interiors himself. Later, Sebastiano del Piombo, Raphael and his pupils added more elaborate works. The frescoes illustrate Classical myths, and the vault of the main hall, the Sala di Galatea, is adorned with astrological scenes showing the position of the stars at the time of Chigi’s birth. Artists, poets, cardinals, princes and the pope himself were entertained here in magnificent style by their wealthy and influential host. In 1577, the villa was bought by Cardinal Alessandro Farnese and since then it has been known as the Villa Farnesina.

column4:
Built as a country retreat for Pope Julius III, Villa Giulia boasts a sublime courtyard, gardens and nymphaeum, as well as an excellent collection of Etruscan artifacts.

The villa once housed an impressive collection of statues – 160 boatloads were sent to the Vatican after the pope died in 1555. The villa, gardens, pavilions and fountains were designed by exceptional architects: Vignola (designer of the Gesù), Vasari and the sculptor Ammannati; Michelangelo also contributed.

Since 1889, Villa Giulia has housed the Museo Nazionale Etrusco. The Etruscans, who lived in central Italy before the Romans, mined metals, which they traded for ceramics and luxury objects made by the Greeks and Phoenicians. The collection includes several important pieces that were returned to Italy after being illegally excavated and sold to collectors and museums.

column4:
Superbly positioned on the Pincio Hill above Piazza di Spagna, Villa Medici hosts exhibitions and concerts, though the views stretching across the city are worth the visit alone.

Built in 1540 and bought by Cardinal Ferdinando de’ Medici in 1576, this villa was used as a prison for those who fell foul of the Inquisition. Its most famous prisoner was scientist Galileo Galilei, who is remembered in an inscription on a column just beyond the villa. Today, the villa is home to the French Academy, founded by Louis XIV in 1666 to give a few select painters the chance to study in Rome. Nicolas Poussin was one of the first advisers to the Academy, Ingres was a director and ex-students include Jean-Honoré Fragonard and François Boucher. After 1803, when the French Academy moved to the Villa Medici, musicians were also admitted; both Berlioz and Debussy came to Rome as students of the Academy.


The highlight of the villa is the Stanza degli Uccelli, a pavilion in the garden frescoed with birds, flowers, fruit and trees. The garden also features an Egyptian obelisk standing on four bronze tortoises, and an unsettling group of statues, the Niobidi, laid out on the lawn.

column63: Six years after his death, 40 of Simon Hantaï’s abstract paintings are on display in the first important retrospective of his work in Italy. The Hungarian-born painter is best known for his pliage comme method in which the canvas is crumpled and dipped in paint, leaving white patterns when unfolded.
column71: Classical and Contemporary Music, Seasonal and Outside
column72: Open Villa, an Electro Pop Rock Festival, takes place in the Villa Medici gardens. Four concerts will be held featuring new, emerging groups as well as established groups that have helped make the history of modern music. Every possible genre of contemporary music will be showcased.

column4: The site of a nymph’s sanctuary in Roman times, Villa Sciarra is a pleasant park decorated with fountains, gazebos, ponds, loggias and statuary. It is especially picturesque in spring, when the wisterias are in full bloom. The splendid views over the bastions of the Janiculum are worth the visit alone.
column54: Villa Sciarra Rome | Visit Villa Sciarra Park
column55: Villa Sciarra is a pleasant park in Rome, with fountains, ponds and excellent views over the bastions of the Janiculum. Plan your trip to Villa Sciarra here.

column4: Great vegetarian options, as well as meat and fish, are served at Vinando, a chic bar with over 600 varieties of wine.
column52: Food and Drink, Cafés and Bars

column4: Vino e Camino is the essence of cozy with wine bottles covering the walls and a working fireplace. The food is good and the wine excellent.
Vittorio Bagagli has been the purveyor of fine housewares since 1855, including design-led Alessi kitchen gadgets and Pavoni espresso machines.
column56: Around the Pantheon | Shops | Shopping |

column4: Vivendo’s luxurious decor provides an elegant backdrop to the fabulous Mediterranean cuisine. Wine tasting is offered in the elegant cellar.
In the heart of the grounds of Villa Pamphilj, Vivi Bistrot serves full American-style breakfasts, as well as picnic options and aperitivi on the grass in summer.
Run by brothers Claudio and Emilio, Volpetti is Rome’s premier delicatessen and the ideal place to have either a lunchtime sandwich or a whole picnic made to order.

column4: An extensive kosher menu is on offer at Yotvata. Good for pizza, fresh fish and hearty pasta dishes. Excellent desserts.
