column4: Zio Ciro pizzeria is popular for its alfresco dining and the chance to order large pizzas with two or three different toppings.
column39: For a three-course meal for one with half a bottle of wine (or equivalent meal), taxes and extra charges. : under €30
column56: Around Piazza Navona | Places to Eat | Restaurant |

column4: Trapizzino, a hugely popular Testaccio takeaway, has gained a reputation for its tasty “trapizzini”, a new Roman street food that has gained a legion of fans. A cross between a sandwich (tramezzino in Italian) and a pizza, these pockets of pizza bianca (flatbread) are stuffed with the classics of cucina romana: tripe, tongue, oxtail, meatballs or salt cod.

Recently opened on Monti’s main street, 2Periodico Café is a café-bar-restaurant-club that makes a great pitstop at any time of day. Eclectically furnished with kitsch details and retro furnishings, it’s a cheery café for breakfast, a tearoom in the afternoon, a cool bar at aperitivo time (from 6:30pm), and a clubby space for after-dinner cocktails. The weekend brunch (Sat & Sun from 12:30pm; €20 including drinks) is very popular; a DJ plays during the Sunday session.

Yeah! Pigneto is a great spot for a light lunch (couscous is a speciality), a slice of homemade orange cake or a veggie smoothie, and you can curl up on the comfy sofas and use the free wi-fi at any time of day. On weekend evenings, music takes centre stage, from live bands to DJ sets. There’s an impressive collection of vinyl, and you’re free to pick out a favourite record and take it to the DJ for a spin, or have a listen on one of the retro record players dotted around the place.
column63: Occasional live jazz, blues, soul, folk and rock concerts are held on the stage at this trendy locale.

column4: A café in a chocolate factory (operating since 1923), SAID dal 1923 scores points for originality: the elegant space is decked out with old chocolate-making instruments and antique moulds. The two-course set lunch (Tues–Fri; €12) and Sunday brunch (€25) are great value, and chocoholics will swoon over the huge selection of deliciously gooey cakes and desserts.

A stone’s throw from Piazza Navona, Society is a treasure-trove of beautiful fabrics, woven from ultra-fine cotton, linen, wool and silk. The airy space is artfully decorated with gorgeous, faded linens in warm neutrals and sun-baked shades that conjure up the warmth of a Mediterranean summer. You’ll find blankets, sheets and towels here, as well as more luggage-friendly items such as napkins, mats, stylish loungewear and tasteful totes. The quality is excellent, and the soft, tactile fabrics age well, too.

The Monti district is a hub of independent, arty boutiques, and the Super concept store, on one of the district’s liveliest streets, is one of the best. It’s great for cool clothing from the likes of Baum und Pferdgarten and Ba-sh, as well as quirky homeware and jewellery you won’t find anywhere else. It’s a good place to browse for up-and-coming designers, and although stock is limited there’s always something of interest here.

One of Rome’s newest and most popular clubs, Shari Vari Playhouse is glamorous and fun, spread across several different spaces. There are quality DJ sets most nights of the week. Come on Tuesday for electronica and underground, Wednesday for hip-hop and a more studenty vibe, Thursday for rock, Friday for feel-good pop and house, Saturday for a glam, clubby atmosphere, and Sunday for chilled-out jazz. There’s also a restaurant, serving up burgers and steaks in refined surroundings.

Lying derelict and unoccupied for almost thirty years, Palazzo Incontro has been restored to its former glory in recent years. Initially just an exhibition venue, it has benefited from council funds to become a dynamic cultural centre. Its two exhibition floors tend to focus on genres such as cartoons, photography and illustrations, with offbeat and often surprising exhibitions. Shows are accompanied by a varied programme of events, from talks to drama workshops. On the ground floor is Fandango Incontro, a cultural meeting point, relaxed literary café and bookshop with free wif-fi.
column63: Prolific German filmmaker Wim Wenders is also a renowned photographer who focuses mainly on the theme of landscape. The exhibit Urban Solitude showcases 25 analog photos that capture and preserve the reality of the modern urban landscape.

column4: Just a 10-minute taxi ride (or a short hop on the tram) from Termini station, Pigneto has evolved into one of Rome’s hippest areas. Historically a working class neighbourhood, it has seen an influx of creative professionals in recent years. The area comes into its own after dark – packed with restaurants and bars, Pigneto is known for a low-key, slightly edgier scene than you’d find in the centre of Rome. Its numerous restaurants are full of locals – there’s a strong community feel here – and its quirky bars put on all manner of events, from poetry slams to alternative live music nights.
column52: Cafés and Bars, Entertainment and Nightlife

column4: Room26 is a superclub in Rome with one of the best sound systems in Europe, designed by Steve Dash. It is overwhelmingly loud (the “26” of the name refers to the number of amps inside) but with a clarity of sound you won’t find anywhere else. This, plus a great line-up of international DJs spinning mainly house, is the reason Rome’s die-hard clubbers keep coming back. It’s at its best on Friday and Saturday nights, from midnight onwards.

Run by a cultural foundation that aims to bring art to the masses, Palazzo Cipolla – Fondazione Roma is a major exhibition space on Rome’s busiest shopping street, Via del Corso. Thanks to collaborations with prestigious museums across the world, exhibitions here are high-profile: past shows have featured Modigliani, Georgia O’Keeffe and Edward Hopper.
column63: Warhol features one of the artist’s most important groups of pieces, gathered by his close friend, collector Peter Brant. More than 150 canvases, photographs and sculptures of the Father of the American Pop Art movement of the 1960s and 1970s are on display.

column3: Museo della Repubblica Romana e della Memoria Garibaldina
column4: Situated on the Janiculum Hill, the Museo della Repubblica Romana e della Memoria Garibaldina is dedicated to Giuseppe Garibaldi’s dramatic defence of the Roman republic in the spring and summer of 1849. The museum is housed in the Porta di San Pancrazio, a structure that played a pivotal role in the conflict, which saw Rome under siege by French troops for a month. Photographs and artefacts, as well as a film (narrated in Italian only), help to bring the story to life. Exhibits include assorted weaponry and recruitment posters, as well as Garibaldi’s shirt (red, like those worn by his volunteers) and walking stick.
column29: 10am–2pm Tue–Fri (last adm 1pm), 10am–6pm Sat, Sun & public hols (last adm 5:30pm)

column4: A French-style restaurant and bar, Josephine Bistrot has a chic feel with brass mirrors, low-lit beaded lamps and cool jazz. The candlelit aperitivo buffet (6–9:30pm) is one of the best in town and includes mini-pizzas, arancini and an array of salads, accompanied by prosecco, wine or cocktails. With a restaurant on the first floor and evening events – tango on Monday, cabaret on Friday and jazz on Saturday – you can make a night of it at Josephine Bistrot.
column52: Cafés and Bars, Food and Drink
column63: Every Monday night live tango music accompanies a milonga lesson and practice. A drink is included in the price, and for a little extra, a light buffet meal, too.

column4: Themed around Kubrick’s A Clockwork Orange, LattePiù’s appeal is the futuristic décor and expertly mixed milk cocktails. The classical, lounge and chill-out music – interspersed with the Clockwork Orange soundtrack – underline the theme nicely, as do the fantastic furnishings: the chairs shaped like body parts almost seem like works of modern art. If you don’t fancy a milk-and-mezcal cocktail, you could try the house speciality, the “Green fairy” – a potent absinthe-based concoction.
column52: Entertainment and Nightlife, Cafés and Bars

column4: A lively, untouristed restaurant near the Colosseum, Li Rioni is decked out to look like a quaint Italian village, with tiled roofs, street lamps and brick arches adding to the atmosphere. The food is simple but excellent – bruschetta, grilled scamorza cheese and crispy pizzas – and it’s always busy, so book ahead.

Louis Vuitton’s vast new Rome flagship is worth a visit for the décor alone: the site used to house Rome’s first cinema, and the glamorous design incorporates a grand staircase built to look like a reel of film. A 19-seat cinema on the top floor shows films on a loop that change monthly. Accessories dominate the ground floor – the famous monogrammed trunks and bags are displayed like works of art – while menswear and womenswear have a floor each.

The Renaissance Chiostro del Bramante, designed by Donato Bramante, was once the heart of a monastery complex that also incorporated the church of Santa Maria della Pace. The design is typical of the Renaissance – harmonious, geometric, with all lines and angles perfectly balanced, and its decoration restrained. The monastery was commissioned by Cardinal Carafa around the year 1500, and the Cardinal is remembered in the inscription around the inner walls of the Chiostro (cloister); his coat of arms can be seen on the columns and doors. These days, the Chiostro is a major exhibition space, hosting well curated art exhibitions.
column38: Audioguide: free
column43: Free entry for the caffeteria, bookshop and giftshop; exhibition prices vary
column60: Alma-Tadema e i pittori dell'800 inglese. Collezione Perez Simon
column63: “Alma-Tadema and the English Painters of the 1800s: the Perez Simon Collection” brings together 50 paintings by the fathers of the Aesthetic Movement, united by a similar trend but each with his own distinct personality, themes and style. The exhibit includes paintings by Alma-Tadema, Millais, Rossetti, Burne-Jones, Leighton and Waterhouse.
column249: Palazzo Incontro, Bistrot at Chiostro del Bramante

column4: Ciao Checca offers fast food with a difference: all of the dishes are tasty and healthy, and are prepared with restaurant-grade ingredients in the open kitchen as you wait. It’s quick and easy – you can take away or eat around the communal table – but standards are high. Highlights of the menu include the wonderfully dense pasta e fagioli soup and the pasta alla checca (with tomatoes, mozzarella and basil). There are gluten-free options, too.
column54: Ciao Checca | Rome | DK Trip Planner
column55: Ciao Checca is a restaurant in Rome that offers healthy fast food. Check out DK Trip Planner for more on restaurants in Rome.

column4: A low-key venue with lively club nights, Circolo degli Artisti has established itself as the best place in Rome for alternative live music. Saturday’s popular “Screamadelica” night has a live concert followed by a DJ spinning ska, punk or electric pop tunes. The music is the main draw here, but the venue also puts on some interesting events, from photography exhibitions to poetry readings. The Circolo is at its best in the spring and summer, when the huge garden, dotted with bars, is a popular chill-out area, where you can eat pizza and listen to music under the stars.
column63: Live music concerts are held on the main stage two or three nights a week, featuring rock, electronic, or other danceable bands. DJs spin on the other nights of the week.

column4: Tucked away on a backstreet, Circus is a quirky café-bar that serves smoothies, light meals, gourmet teas and killer cocktails. You can sit in the bright café out front and use the free wi-fi, prop up the cosy back-lit bar or chill out in the lounge area. Filled with the work of local artists, there’s also international magazines to browse. With a daily aperitivo buffet (€5; 6:30–9pm), DJ sets at weekends and a great Sunday brunch, there’s always something going on here.
column52: Cafés and Bars, Entertainment and Nightlife

column4:
The Convento dei Cappuccini houses a new, eight-room museum offering a glimpse into the day-to-day existence of the Capuchin friars, and gives access to the church’s crypt, ornately decorated with human bones.

The museum’s star exhibit is Caravaggio’s serene St Francis in Meditation, which has a room to itself. Other displays focus on the friars’ daily lives – chants inscribed on ancient manuscripts, pharmacological apparatus for making medicine, metal scourges used to discipline the disobedient, and a collection of watches, important to the friars as a reminder of the passing of time and their own mortality.

The crypt, seen at the end of the museum, is the highlight, consisting of a series of chapels decorated with the bones of some 4,000 Capuchin friars and Roman paupers. Bones of all shapes and sizes have been fashioned into intricate – and macabre – works of art, as well as door frames, shelves and even chandeliers: an astonishing sight.
column33: Access to the museum but not to the crypt
column52: Family Friendly, Art Galleries and Museums
column54: Capuchin Crypt Rome | Rome Capuchin Crypt
column55: The Capuchin Crypt in Rome is a ghoulish affair: the bones of monks are used as decoration! Plan a visit to Rome’s Cauchin Crypt today with DK Trip Planner.

column4: Off the tourist trail in the trendy Pigneto district, I Porchettoni der Pigneto is a rowdy, informal place that specializes in porchetta – roast suckling pig, thickly sliced and served up in paper on rustic wooden tables. In addition to the obligatory porchetta and crusty bread, order sides of mozzarella and salami, and wash it down with some robust red wine.

The best of a new breed of gourmet gelaterias, Il Gelato di Claudio Torcè is known for its unusual flavour combinations such as green tea and strawberry, or Sichuan pepper and black sesame. The old faithfuls such as chocolate and hazelnut are top-quality, too. Such is the success of Torcè’s recipes that there are now seven branches across the city.

Trastevere is full of simple, no-frills restaurants, but Glass Hostaria stands out from the crowd by offering a gourmet experience. The elegant food served here is matched by sophisticated décor: bare brick walls, contemporary lighting and glass floor panels create an intimate atmosphere. The cuisine is creative, with plenty of strong flavours: primi include foie gras risotto and parmesan-stuffed ravioli, and the crab with truffle sauce and endive makes a punchy main. Be sure to leave room for the delicious desserts.
column54: Glass Hostaria | Rome | DK Trip Planner
column55: Glass Hostaria is an elegant restaurant in Trastevere, Rome. For more on Glass Hostaria, go to DK Trip Planner.

column4: Dal Paino’s pizzas are satisfyingly huge, as thin and crispy as Roman tradition dictates, and at fair prices too (a margherita in nearby Piazza Navona will set you back twice as much). There’s a cosy, convivial dining room or parasol-shaded tables outside.

A fourth-generation Fendi, Delfina Delettrez has an impeccable fashion pedigree, and her jewellery – glamorous and modern with a retro twist – has a legion of fans. Her store, on trendy Via del Governo Vecchio, is a must for jewellery-lovers. An intimate, cabinet-lined space that feels like a jewellery box, it perfectly offsets the eye-catching, fashion-forward creations, which blend polished metals with sparkling gemstones, as well as materials such as leather and bone.

The high-end supermarket chain Eataly has recently opened a new branch in Rome – its biggest outpost yet. This multi-storey foodie emporium, organized by food type, is full of restaurants, bars and food shops, and sells everything from gourmet meatballs to microbrewed beer, via dizzying displays of cheeses, oils, pasta, coffee and chocolate. Prices are higher here than in the centre, but it’s a fun experience, and a must for foodies and wine aficionados.
column6: Air Terminal Ostiense, Piazzale XII Ottobre 1492

column4: A handsome building near Via del Corso, Palazzo Sciarra – Fondazione Roma holds an impressive gallery space showing high-calibre exhibitions. Twinned with nearby gallery Palazzo Cipolla, it is known for its thoughtfully curated shows, with careful consideration given to lighting and presentation. Past exhibitions have focused on Indian art and priceless jewels from Naples’ Duomo.
column60: Hogarth, Reynolds, Turner. Pittura inglese verso la modernità
column63: “Hogarth, Reynolds, Turner: English Painting Toward Modernity” touches on the connection between artistic and social development in 18th-century Great Britain as the nation developed economically and politically. More than 100 pieces include paintings by Hogarth, Reynolds, Gainsborough, Wright of Derby, Stubbs, Füssli, Constable and Turner.

column4: A beautifully presented concept store, Fleur Luxury Living was originally known for its fine furniture but is now branching out into designer womenswear, jewellery and perfume. A temple of taste, the store is full of carefully chosen furniture and objets, as well as high-end women’s fashion, including Alessandro dell’Acqua and Tara Jarmon, with statement jewellery from Philippe Audibert, among other designers, and a selection of cult fragrances. The in-house café is just the place to take a break from shopping and sip a gourmet tea.

With no sign outside it’s a little hard to find, but Trastevere bakery Biscottificio Innocenti (run by three generations of the same family) is worth seeking out. There’s usually a gaggle of hungry locals here lining up for a bag of warm, freshly baked mielini (honey biscuits) or tasty jam tarts.

For beautifully cooked, traditional cuisine in a smart setting, look no further than Al Ceppo. The elegant dining room – cosy, wood-panelled and hung with antique paintings – is the perfect backdrop for classic cuisine from Le Marche. The wood-burning fireplace where fish and meats are grilled adds to the warm, intimate feel.

Michelin-starred All’Oro, in the trendy First Luxury Art Hotel, is a modern, all-white space with bright, splashy art on the walls. The restaurant serves up creative Italian cuisine, such as roast suckling pig with potatoes and black truffle sauce, while the rooftop bar, 0°-300°, serves a menu of raw (0°) and grilled or baked (300°) dishes, with lovely views of Rome.

With rail upon rail of designer vintage clothes, Blue Goose is a Monti shop that offers a great alternative if your budget won’t stretch to this season’s Gucci and Versace. The tiny space holds a well-edited selection of upmarket womenswear at reasonable prices and in very good condition, as well as vintage leather bags and one-off jewellery items. You might have to rummage a bit, but fans of vintage are bound to find something special here.

Tucked away in the Ghetto, Beppe e i suoi Formaggi is a fantastic cheese shop and restaurant specializing in products from Piemonte and Sardinia. If you’re just after a glass of wine and a platter of delicious cheeses, this is the place, though they also do great pastas and hearty mains such as cassoulet of duck and pork, as well as gourmet breakfasts. The adjoining shop sells a tempting array of cheeses, as well as chutneys, chocolates and wine.
column6: Via di Santa Maria del Pianto 9A/11
column54: Beppe e I suoi Formaggi | Rome | DK Trip Planner
column55: Beppe e i suoi Formaggi is a fantastic cheese shop and restaurant in Rome specializing in products from Piemonte and Sardinia. For more information, visit DK Trip Planner.

column4: A stone’s throw from the Spanish Steps, the Casa-Museo di Giorgio de Chirico was the home of the Greek-Italian artist for thirty years until his death in 1978. There are plenty of his works on display – he’s best known for his surrealist paintings, but you’ll also find some self-portraits and studies of his wife, Isabella. Upstairs, the artist’s living quarters have been left virtually untouched, providing a unique glimpse into his day-to-day life. His studio is the most evocative room: complete with paintbrushes and tubes of paint as well as De Chirico’s palette, it gives the sense that the artist has just stepped out of the room.
column29: 9am–1pm Tues–Sat & first Sun of the month
column38: Book in advance

column4:
Located 48 km (30 miles) outside of Rome, Tivoli has been a popular summer resort since the days of the Roman Republic. Among the famous men who owned villas here were the poets Catullus and Horace, Caesar’s assassins Brutus and Cassius, and the Emperors Trajan and Hadrian. Tivoli’s main attractions were its clean air and beautiful situation on the slopes of the Tiburtini hills, its healthy sulphur springs and the waterfalls of the Aniene – the Emperor Augustus said these had cured him of insomnia. The Romans’ luxurious lifestyle was revived in Renaissance times by the owners of the Villa d’Este, the town’s most famous sight.

In the Middle Ages Tivoli suffered frequent invasions as its position made it an ideal base for an advance on Rome. In 1461 Pope Pius II built a fortress here, the Rocca Pia, declaring: “It is easier to regain Rome while possessing Tivoli, than to regain Tivoli while possessing Rome.”

After suffering heavy bomb-damage in 1944, Tivoli’s main buildings and churches were speedily restored. The town’s cobbled streets are still lined with medieval houses. The Duomo (cathedral) houses a beautiful 13th-century life-size wooden group representing the Deposition from the Cross. Tivoli makes a good place to stop either before or after visiting Hadrian’s Villa.

Built in the 16th century by Cardinal Ippolito d’Este, son of Lucrezia Borgia, the hilltop Villa d’Este occupies the site of an old Benedictine convent and is famed for its beautiful terraced gardens and fountains laid out by Ligorio and Giacomo della Porta. The gardens have suffered neglect in the past, but the grottoes and fountains still give a vivid impression of the great luxury which the princes of the church enjoyed.

From the great loggia of the palace you descend through the privet-lined paths to the Grotto of Diana and Bernini’s Fontana del Bicchierone. Below to the right is the Rometta (little Rome), a model of Tiber Island with allegorical figures and the legendary she-wolf. The Rometta is at one end of the Viale delle Cento Fontane, 100 fountains in the shapes of grotesques, obelisks, ships and the eagles of the d’Este coat of arms. Other fountains are now being restored to their former glory. The Fontana dell’Organo is a water-organ, in which the force of the water pumps air through the pipes. The garden’s lowest level has flower beds and fountains as well as some splendid views out over the plain below.
column29:
Villa d'Este: 8:30am–1 hour before sunset Tue–Sun

Hydraulic Organ: from 10:30am and every two hours thereafter

Fontana della Civetta: from 10am and every two hours thereafter
column43: EU residents: €4 (18–24 years); free (under-18s and over 65s)
column52: Historic Sights and Landmarks, Green Spaces

column4:
Shaded by pines and beautifully set in the countryside, Hadrian’s Villa was built by the emperor in AD 128 as a magnificent private retreat, with bath houses, libraries, a fire station, temples and theatres as well as a palace. Hadrian had been very impressed with the buildings he had seen during his travels in Greece and Egypt and had a few of them reproduced here, creating a vast open-air museum of the finest architecture of the Roman world. Today, the villa is a wonderful place for a peaceful day out, with plenty of space to relax and enjoy picnics and games.

Excavations on the 120 hectare (300 acre) site began in the 16th century, though many of the ruins lying scattered in the surrounding fields have yet to be identified with any certainty. For an idea of how the whole complex would have looked in its heyday, study the scale model in the building beside the car park. The most important buildings are signposted and several have been partially restored or reconstructed. One of the most impressive is the so-called Maritime Theatre. This is a round pool with an island in the middle, surrounded by columns. The island, reached by means of a swing bridge, was probably Hadrian’s private studio, where he withdrew from the cares of the Empire to indulge in his two favourite pastimes, painting and architecture. There were also theatres, Greek and Latin libraries, two bathhouses, extensive housing for guests and the palace staff, and formal gardens with fountains, statues and pools.

Hadrian also loved Greek philosophy. One part of the gardens is thought to have been Hadrian’s reproduction of the Grove of Academe, where Plato lectured to his students. He also had a replica made of the Stoà Poikile, a beautiful painted colonnade in Athens, from which the Stoic philosophers took their name. This copy enclosed a great piazza with a central pool. The so-called Hall of the Philosophers close to the Poikile was probably a library.

The most ambitious of Hadrian’s replicas was the Canopus, a sanctuary of the god Serapis near Alexandria. For this a canal 119 metres (130 yards) long was dug and Egyptian statues were imported to decorate the temple and its grounds. This impressive piece of engineering has been restored and the banks of the canal are lined with caryatids.

Another picturesque spot in the grounds is the Vale of Tempe, the legendary haunt of the goddess Diana with a stream representing the river Peneios. Below ground the emperor even built a fanciful re-creation of the underworld, Hades, reached through underground tunnels, of which there were many linking the various parts of the villa.

Plundered by barbarians who camped here in the 6th and 8th centuries, the villa fell into disrepair. Its marble was burned to make lime for cement and Renaissance antiquarians contributed even further to its destruction. Statues unearthed in the grounds are on show in museums around Europe. The Vatican’s Egyptian Collection has many fine works that were found here.
column28: COTRAL bus from Ponte Mammolo, CAT 4 from Tivoli

Apr–Sep: 9am–7pm daily; May–Aug: 9am–7:30pm daily

column52: Ancient Ruins, Historic Sights and Landmarks

column4:
The remains of an ancient port, Ostia Antica is one of the most extensive and evocative Roman sites in Italy. The city was originally built on the coast but, over the centuries, the Tiber shifted course further west and Ostia now lies stranded quite a distance from the sea. Buried for centuries by sand, the city is remarkably well preserved. The site is less spectacular than Pompeii or Herculaneum because Ostia died a gradual death, but it gives a more complete picture of life under the Roman Empire.

Ostia was founded in the 4th century BC, first as a simple fort, but as Rome grew, the town became ever more important, as the distribution point for imports from around the Mediterranean. The port continued to flourish under the Empire, despite the development of Portus, a new port slightly to the northwest, in the 2nd century AD. Ostia’s decline began in the 4th century, when a reduction in trade was combined with the gradual silting up of the harbour. Then malaria became endemic in the area and the city, whose population may have been nearly 100,000 at its peak, was totally abandoned. 

Visitors can understand the layout of Ostia’s streets almost at a glance. The main road through the town, the Decumanus Maximus, would have been filled with hurrying slaves and citizens, avoiding the jostling carriages and carts, while tradesmen pursued their business under the porticoes lining the street. The floorplans of the public buildings along the road are very clear. Many were bathhouses, such as the Baths of the Cisiarii (carters) and the grander Baths of Neptune, named after their fine black-and-white floor mosaics. Beside the theatre, three large masks, originally part of the decoration of the stage, have been mounted on large blocks of tufa. Beneath the great brick arches that supported the semicircular tiers of seats were taverns and shops. Classical plays are put on here in the summer.

The Tiber’s course has changed considerably since Ostia was the port of Rome. It once flowed past just to the north of Piazzale delle Corporazioni, the square behind the theatre. The corporations were the guilds of the various trades involved in fitting out and supplying ships: tanners and rope-makers, ship-builders and timber merchants, ships’ chandlers and corn weighers. There were some 60 or 70 offices around the square. Mosaics showing scenes of everyday life in the port and the names and symbols of the corporations can still be seen. There were also offices used by ship-owners and their agents from places as far apart as Tunisia and the south of France, Sardinia and Egypt. In one office, belonging to a merchant from the town of Sabratha in North Africa, there is a delightful mosaic of an elephant.

The main cargo coming into Rome was grain from Africa. Much of this was distributed free to prevent social unrest. Although only men received this annona or corn dole, at times over 300,000 were eligible. In the centre of the square was a temple, probably dedicated to Ceres, goddess of the harvest. Among the buildings excavated are many large warehouses in which grain was stored before it was shipped on to Rome.

The Decumanus leads to the Forum and the city’s principal temple, erected by Hadrian in the 2nd century AD and dedicated to Jove, Juno and Minerva. In this rather romantic, lonely spot, it is hard to imagine the Forum as a bustling centre, where justice was dispensed and officials met to discuss the city’s affairs. In the 18th century it was used as a sheepfold.

Away from the main street are the buildings where Ostia’s inhabitants lived. The great majority were housed in rented apartments in blocks three or four storeys high known as insulae. These varied considerably in their comfort and decoration. The House of Diana was one of the smarter ones, with a balcony around the second floor, a private bathhouse and a central courtyard with a cistern where tenants came to collect their water. Around the ground floor of the block were shops, taverns and bars selling snacks and drinks. In the bar at the House of Diana you can see the marble counter used by customers buying their sausages and hot wine sweetened with honey. For the wealthy there were detached houses (domus) such as the House of the Dioscuri, which has fine mosaics, and the House of Cupid and Psyche, named after a statue there. This is now in the site’s Museo Ostiense, near the Forum, along with other sculptures and reliefs found in Ostia. Among the houses and shops there are other fascinating buildings including a laundry and the firemen’s barracks.

The religions practised in Ostia reflect the cosmopolitan nature of the port. There are also no fewer than 18 temples dedicated to the Persian god Mithras, as well as a Jewish synagogue dating from the 1st century AD and a Christian basilica. A plaque records the death of St Augustine’s mother in a hotel here in AD 387.
